div2.head: SPECIAL LAWS.

div3.head: CHAPTER I.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Magnolia Grove Association.

div3.p:
Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, Section 1. That James P. Cole, Philip C. Tucker, Jacob L. Briggs, John S. Thrasher, James Sorley, P. Gloor, John H. Westerlage, hi. B. Yard, John B. Root, George W. Glover and Sidney Scndder, and their asso-
ciates and successors, are hereby constituted a body corporate by the name of “The Magnolia Grove Association,” and as such corporation shall have power to contract and be contracted with, sue and be sued, have and use a corporate seal, purchase and hold, in fee or otherwise, lands, goods and property, make and alter by-laws, and do all other acts and things, and have and enjoy all other franchises incident to and necessary and proper for effecting the object of their incorporation, which is to provide and maintain forever a place of repose for the dead.

Sec. 2. Said incorporation shall have no power to sell or convey any land purchased by it, for other purpose than that of providing a resting place for the dead, nor to create a lien thereon to insure the payment of money for any purpose except as hereinafter specially provided; neither shall said land or any improvements thereon be subject to levy or sale upon any process issued upon any judgment from any court in this State, and shall be forever exempt from any appropriation to public uses.

Sec. 3. For the purpose of organizing and establishing the Magnolia Grove Association, a capital stock of thirty thousand dollars shall be raised by subscription, in shares of one hundred dol-
lars, each, which shall be deemed personal property, and be transferable on the books of the corporation in such manner as the said cor-
poration shall, by its by-laws, direct; and which stock shall be redeemed, with twelve per cent. annual interest, within ten years from the date of its charter; the redemption of which is hereby
Laws of the State of Texas.ensured by a lien upon the lands purchased by the corporation, and im-
provements thereon, in the nature of a vendor’s lien, the holders of said stock being substituted to the rights of the vendor or vendors, from whom said property may be purchased.

Sec. 4. The lands so purchased shall be properly enclosed; and it shall not be lawful for any public highway, street, road or alley for the use of the public to be laid through the same by any court whatever, or by the authorities of the county of Galveston, or of any other county, town, city or other municipality; neither shall said lands or improvements thereon be subject to the payment of public taxes.

Sec. 5. The lands so purchased shall be laid off with avenues and walks, divided into suitable lots for the purpose of burying the dead, and arranged and improved according to any plan which may be adopted by vote of the trustees of said corporation.

Sec. 6. All lots or parcels of ground shall be designated and num-
bered as lots by said corporation, and shall be indivisible. They may be afterwards owned and held by purchasers thereof, in individual shares.

Sec. 7. The said corporation may sell or otherwise dispose of said lots to be used exclusively as a cemetery, or a place for the burial of the dead; and all moneys obtained for or on account of the capital stock or from the sale of lots, shall be first applied by the said corporation to the en-
closure of the land acquired by said corporation; and the residue thereof shall be applied, one-half to the redemption of the capital stock and interest thereon, until the same is entirely redeemed as stipulated in article three of this charter, and the other half shall be applied to the incidental expenses of the cemetery establishment, improving or em-
bellishing such land as cemetery or burial ground; and after payment of the purchase money, the proceeds from all future sales of lots and other sources shall be applied to the preservation, improvement and em-
bellishment of the said cemetery, and to incidental expenses thereof, and to no other purpose whatsoever.

Sec. 8. It shall be lawful for the stockholders of said Magnolia Grove Association to surrender and extinguish their stock in exchange for lots, or in such other manner as the board of trustees shall prescribe; and all persons who shall become proprietors of lots or parcels of ground, as ex-
pressed in section nine of this charter, conveyed to them by said cor-
poration, shall become members of said body corporate.

Sec. 9. The estate and property of said corporation shall be held, and its affairs shall be managed, by a board of trustees who shall be lot proprietors entitled to vote, a majority of whom shall
Laws of the State of Texas.constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. And said board of trustees shall be elected by ballot; and every proprietor of a lot or parcel of ground of not less than two hundred and fifty-six square feet, shall be entitled to vote at all meetings of the proprietors, in person or by proxy, one vote for each such lot or parcel. The trustees of such corporation shall, in all cases, be chosen from among the lot proprietors as aforesaid, and shall have power to fill vacancies that may occur during the period for which they shall hold office, and to establish by-laws for the associa-
tion, and rules for the regulation of the cemetery. The first board of trustees shall be composed of the persons hereinbefore named as cor-
porators, and they shall hold office until their successors are duly elected and installed.

Sec. 10. Any person who shall wilfully destroy, mutilate, deface, in-
jure, or remove any tomb, monument, or gravestone, or any other struc-
ture placed in the cemetery aforesaid, or any fence, railing, or other work for the protection or ornament of said cemetery, or any tomb, monu-
ment, or gravestone, or other structure aforesaid, on any cemetery lot within the cemetery aforesaid, or shall wilfully destroy, cut-, break, or in-
jure any tree, shrub, or plant within the limits of said cemetery, or re-
move from any grave or lot, any flowers, wreaths, leaves, crosses, or other ornament within the said cemetery, shall be deemed guilty of a misde-
meanor, and shall, upon conviction thereof before any justice of the peace, or any court of criminal jurisdiction, be punished by a fine of not less than ten dollars nor more than fifty dollars, according to the nature and aggravation of the offense, and such offender shall also be liable in an action of trespass to be brought against him in any court of com-
petent jurisdiction in the name of said corporation, to pay to said cor-
poration all such damages as shall have been occasioned by his unlawful act or acts; and members of said corporation shall be competent witnesses in such suits. And for a repetition of said offense such offender shall be subject to imprisonment for a term of not less than ten nor more than sixty days in any jail or place of confinement that any court of compe-
tent jurisdiction may order.

Sec. 11. It shall not be lawful for any person whatever to turn upon said cemetery grounds, or permit to be turned upon, or to run at large therein, any animal for the purpose of grazing, or for any other purpose whatever, under the penalties prescribed in section ten of this charter.

Sec. 12. It shall not be lawful for any lot owner or owners to per-
mit interments thereon for money or other pecuniary considera-
tion, nor for any person to build or maintain upon the grounds of said cemetery, any building or receptacle wherein to be deposited.
Laws of the State of Texas.permanently or otherwise, the remains of the dead for like considera-
tion, without the consent of the board of trustees previously obtained, under the penalty of forfeiture to the corporation of such lots with im-
provements thereon.

Sec. 13. Any lot or lots hereinafter to be conveyed by said corpora-
tion may be so conveyed, that upon such conveyance thereof, such lot or lots Shall be forever thereafter inalienable, and shall, upon the death of the holder, descend to all, any, or either of the heirs-at-law, or to such person or persons, or to such class or classes of persons as may, in the conveyance thereof from said corporation, be designated for that purpose; but any one or more of the persons who shall become the joint owners or proprietors of any lot or lots, may release or convey to any other or others of said persons his, her, or their interest in the same; and such lots shall not be levied upon, nor taken in execution by any process of law or equity, nor shall the same be devised so as to vest any right or title in the devisee. In case of the permanent removal of any lot-owner from the State, or the death of such lot-owner without heirs, or the extinction of any society or other class of lot-owners, the care, custody, and main-
tenance in good order of said lot or lots shall devolve upon this cor-
poration as trustees for the owner thereof.

Sec. 14. Any religions, charitable, or benevolent society, or any or-
ganization for the benefit of mankind, may purchase and hold, subject to this charter and the rules and regulations of the corporation, any lot or lots offered for sale by the said corporation, and may dedicate or consecrate the same by the ceremonies or services which they may deem proper, or according to their usage, and may bold and pass the Same to their successors forever.

Sec. 15. The persons hereinbefore named as corporators, having acted as commissioners to receive subscriptions to said capital stock, and hav-
ing obtained subscriptions to the same to the amount of more than fif-
teen thousand dollars, are hereby empowered to organize as the board of trustees of the Magnolia Grove Association; and it shall be lawful for the said commissioners, or a majority of them, to receive subscriptions, and to require payments of the sums to be subscribed to the capital stock, at such time and in such payments and on such conditions as they, or a majority of them, shall deem fit, under the penalty of the forfeiture of all previous payments thereon, and shall give notice of the payments thus required, and of the place and time when the same are to be paid, at least thirty days previous to the payment of the same, in at least two public newspapers of the city of Galveston.

Sec. 16. The said corporation may take and hold, subject to such regulations of the board of trustees as may be determined by
Laws of the State of Texas.said board, any grant, donation, or bequest of property upon trust to apply the same, or the income thereof, under the direction of the board of trustees, for the improvement or the embellishment of said cemetery, or for the erection, repair, preservation, or renewal of any tomb, monu-
ment, or gravestone, fence, railing, or other erection, or for the planting or cultivation of trees, shrubs, flowers or plants in any other manner or form consistent with the design and purposes of this charter, according to the terms of such grant, donation or bequest.

Sec. 17. The superintendents and keepers of the gates, and their as-
sistants shall, by virtue of their office, be invested with all the powers of police officers within the cemetery grounds, and within two hundred yards of its boundaries, for the purpose of the preservation of the public peace, protection of the grounds and improvements, prevention of indecency, and enforcing the provisions of this charter, the by-laws of the corpora-
tion, and the laws of the State. It shall be the duty of said corporation to keep an accurate record of all interments in said cemetery, stating the nativity, age, occupation, cause of death, and time of death of the person to be buried; and no interment shall be made in said cemetery without the certificate of some physician of the cause of the death and the fact thereof.

Sec. 18. The annual meeting of the lot-owners of the Magnolia Grove Association shall be held in Galveston at such place and hour as the board of trustees provide, on the first Monday of April of each year. This act shall take effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER II.
div3.p:
An Act to confirm the compromises and settlements between the corpora-
tion of the city of Galveston, the Galveston City Company, the Hous-
ton and Galveston Wharf and Press Company, and the Galveston Wharf Company.

Whereas, On the 8th day of December, 1851, an act was passed by the Legislature entitled “An act granting certain powers to the corporation of Galveston city,” and on the 16th day of February
Laws of the State of Texas.1852, an act was passed entitled “An act supplementary to ‘an act grant-
ing certain powers to the corporation of Galveston city,’" approved De-
cember 8, 1851; and

Whereas, litigation in regard to the property known as the “Flats,” within the corporate limits of said city existed for many years, retarding the improvement and prosperity of said city, which said litigation was compromised and settled by a consent decree rendered in the District Court of Brazoria county on the first day of April, 1869, in a suit wherein the said corporation of the city of Galveston was plaintiff, and the Gal-
veston Wharf Company was defendant; and by a further consent decree rendered in said District Court on the 2d day of November, 1869, in a suit wherein the Galveston City Company was plaintiff, and the corpora-
tion of the city of Galveston was defendant, and by a sale by the said Houston and Galveston Wharf and Press Company to the said Galveston Wharf Company; therefore

Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the said compromises and settlements between said parties, and the said decrees of the District Court of Brazoria county, recited in the preamble hereto, are, in all respects, validated, ratified and confirmed; provided, however, that this act shall not be so construed as to affect the right or claim of any person whatever, not a party to said suits, decrees or compromises.

div3.head: CHAPTER III.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the Island City Real Estate and Homestead Asso-
ciation.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the subscribers of the moneys heretofore paid in, under and in pursuance of an undertaking conducted in the name of T. H. McMahan, T. F. White, A. C. Baker, A. H. Belo, C. M. Mason, J. S. Vedder, W. B. Sorley, T. C. Armstrong and Cyrus Thompson, as trustees of the Island City Beal Estate and Home-
stead Association, be and they are hereby incorporated under the name and style of “The Island City Beal Estate and Homestead Association.” and under said name and style shall take, receive and become possessed, in fee of all and singular, the real estate heretofore
Laws of the State of Texas.acquired and to be acquired by the said trustees as such; and under the said name and style they may transfer their rights by succession or as-
signment, and shall be persons capable in law of suing and being sued, pleading and being impleaded, answering and being answered unto, de-
fending and being defended, in all courts and tribunals and places what-
soever; and also that they and their successors, by the same name and style, shall be in law capable of holding and of conveying any estate, real, personal or mixed, and doing and performing all things in relation to any such estates that they may think proper to do, and that may be necessary to be done, and not in contravention of the laws and the Con-
stitution of the State of Texas; and especially to purchase real estate in the city and county of Galveston, State of Texas, with powers to bargain, sell and convey the same for money, cash in hand, or on time, or ex-
change the same for other property in said city and county, and to build upon and improve any of such property, as to them may appear right and proper.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the management of the affairs of said company shall be conducted by a board of nine (9) directors, each of whom shall be a stockholder of the stock of said company, and five (5) of whom shall be a quorum to do and perform all the business necessary to the successful operation of said company. A majority of said directors shall appoint a president from their own number, and shall fill all va-
cancies in the directory as may, from time to time, take place from death, resignation or otherwise. The election of directors shall take place in the city of Galveston on the first Monday in April in each year and every year after the organization under this act, and in case of failure to so elect said directors, the corporation shall not be dissolved for that cause, but the president and directors for the time being shall continue in office until there shall be an election; provided, also, that it shall be the duty of said directors to call a meeting of the stockholders at an early day to elect the directory so omitted to be elected at the regular period.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That each stockholder shall have one vote for each share that he, she or they may own, and may vote in per-
son or by proxy.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That it shall be the duty of the said trustees, now acting in the premises of the present associa-
tion, by and through their acting secretary, to call a meeting of the present association, as soon as practicable, after the passage and approval of this act, for the purposes of an organization under this act; and that until such organization shall have been perfected, the affairs of said association shall be conducted as heretofore, and that
Laws of the State of Texas.the mode of electing the directory, at the first meeting aforesaid, herein-
before named, shall be the same as that by which the present trustees were elected, except that mode be altered by a vote of two-thirds of the members present at such meeting; the mode of such election being and to be by a majority of votes cast.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That the capital stock shall be seventy-
five thousand dollars, and it may be increased to three hundred and seventy-five thousand dollars, or any intermediate amount by a two-
thirds vote of the shareholders.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That the capital stock shall consist of the moneys heretofore paid in under the management of the said trustees, and the further sum of ten (10) dollars to be hereafter paid in monthly installments on each and every share of stock; the capital stock to be divided into one hundred and twenty-five shares, of six hundred dollars per share.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That the president and directors shall have authority to adopt all such rules, regulations and by-laws as they may consider necessary for the proper management of said company, not in contravention of the terms of this act.
Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, That the said company may have a common seal, to be provided by the president and directors as they like.
Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That the number of shareholders shall never exceed one hundred and twenty-five.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, That service of all legal processes upon the president or secretary of the board of directors, (which said secretary shall be appointed by the directors) shall be considered as service on the said company.

Sec. 11. Be it further enacted, That this act or charter shall remain in full force and effect from and after the date of its passage, for and dur-
ing the period of twenty years.

div3.head: CHAPTER IV.

opener.salute: An Act authorizing F. A. Vaughan, William Saffold and George P. Smith, of Guadalupe County, to construct and build a bridge across the Guadalupe river, near the town of Seguin.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of
Laws of the State of Texas.Texas, That F. A. Vaughan, William Saffold and George P. Smith, of the county of Guadalupe, be and they are hereby authorized and em-
powered to construct a bridge across the Guadalupe river at such place as they may select, within four miles of the town of Seguin, in Guadal-
upe county.

Sec. 2. That said Vaughan, Saffold and Smith, or either of them, shall construct said bridge in a durable and substantial manner, and shall complete the same within three years from the first day of January, 1871, and shall keep said bridge in good repair for all passengers, for the term of thirty years from the completion of the same, and shall be ready at all times to pass persons, carriages, wagons, teams and stock across on said bridge.

Sec. 3. That said parties shall have the right of way from said bridge to the town of Seguin, and also from the west side of the said Guadalupe river, and shall have the privilege of opening roads for the public con-
venience over the said right of way, to be not less than thirty feet in width; provided, said parties shall pay to the owners of the land, through, which said road shall pass, such damage as the Police Court of Guadal-
upe county may assess.

Sec. 4. That said Vaughan, Saffold and Smith, and their successors, shall be entitled to collect and receive such tolls as the said Police Court of Guadalupe county may, in their judgment, think proper and just to allow.

Sec. 5. That no other bridge shall be constructed across the Guad-
alupe river within five miles of the bridge herein provided for, until the expiration of this charter; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to any railroad bridge for the passage of railroad oars, that may become necessary for any railroad company to build.
Sec. 6. That this act take effect from and after its passase.

div3.head: CHAPTER V.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Texas Banking and Insurance Company.

div3.p:
Whereas, A large number of the merchants of Galveston are desirous of forming an Insurance and Exchange and Deposit Association, for the purpose of securing to themselves and the State, the
Laws of the State of Texas.use and benefit of large sums of money which are now sent out of the State, to pay premium’s on insurance; and further, for the purpose of securing to themselves and their business friends throughout the State, a safe and reliable place for the deposit of money, and where the de-
positors may reap some benefit from the results of their deposits:

Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. M. Brandon, E. S. Jamison, W. L. Moody, R. S. Willis, M. Quin, George Schneider, J. C. Wallis, C. L. Cleveland, W. A. Port, W. B. Wall, J. D. Skinner, Leon Blum, J. H. Littlefield, E. Randall, Thomas Comp-
ton, Selim Rinker, and their present and future associates, successors, and assigns, be and hereby are incorporated and created a body politic and corporate, by the name of the Texas Banking and Insurance Com-
pany, and by the same name and style they and their successors shall be capable of suing and being sued, and maintaining any action to final judgment and execution; and shall be in law capable of purchasing, holding, improving and conveying any estate, real, personal or mixed, for the use of said corporation; provided, that no real estate be acquired than for the purpose of erecting thereon a suitable building for the com-
pany’s office. And the said corporation shall have the power to ordain, establish, and put in execution such by-laws, ordinances and regulations as shall be necessary for the government thereof; but for the enactment, altering, or amending of such by-laws, it shall require an affirmative vote of two-thirds of all stock issued, while, for the transaction of ordi-
nary business, a majority of stock shall constitute a quorum. And it shall be lawful for the said corporation, after the expiration of the term for which it is incorporated, to use the corporate name and style and capacity, for the purpose of suits for the final settlement and liquidation of the affairs and accounts of the corporation, and for sale and distribu-
tion of their estate, real, personal and mixed, but not for any other pur-
pose, nor for a period exceeding three years after the expiration of charter.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the capital stock of said corporation shall be not less than one hundred and fifty thousand dollars, and divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, with the privilege of increasing the same, at the discretion Of the board of directors, to a sum not exceed-
ing five hundred thousand dollars; provided, that after the organization of this company, and after they shall have elected their directory, there shall be no further increase of stock until after the first day of October; 1871; and provided, further, that whenever the directory shall determine to increase the stock, they shall give notice of the same in at least two news-
papers published in the city of Galveston, daily, for thirty days, stating
Laws of the State of Texas.intended rate of increase; and sealed proposals for sale of the same shall be received at their office until three o’clock P. M. of the day preceding the one appointed for awarding the sale, on which day the sealed pro-
posals shall be opened at their office, and in the presence of the president and directors; and the stock shall be awarded to the highest bidders; provided, that no bid shall be received at less than the par value of one hundred dollars per share, and only for cash; and provided, further, that when two bids, being of equal amount, are made, then it shall be deter-
mined by the directory which one of the equal bidders shall be preferred.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That for the well ordering of the af-
fairs of said corporation, there shall be thirteen directors, who shall be stockholders in said corporation, nine of whom shall be residents of the city of Galveston; and the said directors shall be elected annually by the stockholders at their annual meeting, to be held on the first Monday in January of each year; provided, that the directors elected at the first general meeting and organization of this company shall hold their of-
fices until such time as their successors shall be elected, on the first Mon-
day in January, 1872; and the voting for directors shall be by ballot, each share represented being entitled to one vote, and stockholders ab-
sent may be represented by written proxy; provided, that after the first election no stockholder shall be entitled to vote on any share or shares which he or she may represent, unless the stock so represented shall have been standing on the company’s books in his or her name for at least ninety days previous to the day of election. And the directory so chosen shall, at the first meeting after their election (which shall be within thirty days after their election) choose one of their own number for president and another for vice-president, who shall hold their offices for one year, or until such time as their successors shall have been selected as here-
tofore provided.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That the directors of said corporation for the time being, seven of whom, including the president, shall con-
stitute a quorum, shall have power to appoint such officers, clerks, agents and other persons as shall be necessary to conduct the business of said corporation, and to allow said persons such compensation for their serv-
ices as they shall deem proper, and generally to exercise all other powers and privileges which are given by law to corporations.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted. That it shall be lawful for said corporation to employ the funds thereof in establishing and sus-
taining the business of marine and fire insurance; to insure sea-
going vessels of all kinds, both in port and at sea; steamboats and other craft engaged in coast or river navigation, and all merehan-
Laws of the State of Texas.dise in transit; buildings and merchandise, and all other perishable prop-
erty on land against loss or damage by fire; to make all and every insur-
ance appertaining to or connected with marine, inland or transportation risks; and to charge, collect and receive for the same such premiums of insurance as the president and directors of said corporation may deem just and reasonable. Further, it shall be lawful for said company to buy and sell exchange, and to loan money at interest on securities, both real and personal, and to receive deposits, both special and general, and to issue their certificates for the same, and to do generally all such business as pertains to a bank of exchange and deposit.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted. That the shares of said corporation shall be assignable and transferable upon the books of said company ac-
cording to such regulations as the president and directors thereof shall ordain and establish for that purpose.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That the president and directors shall render to the stockholders an annual statement of the liabilities and assets of said corporation, which statement shall be verified by the oath or af-
firmation of the president and cashier, and shall be published for three consecutive insertions in not less than two of the Galveston newspapers. And it shall be the duty of the president and directors of said corpora-
tion, either annually or semi-annually, to make such dividends of the net profits of said corporation as shall be deemed advisable under the fol-
lowing rules and regulations: One-fourth of the net profits shall be divided pro rata among the depositors, the remaining three-fourths among the stockholders; but if at any time the amount of deposits should bear the proportion to capital stock of three to one, then one-third of the net profits shall be divided among the depositors, and two-thirds among the stockholders: and if the average deposits should reach the proportion to the capital stock of four to one, then one-half of the net profits shall be divided among the depositors, and one-half among the stockholders.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, That at any time after the pass-
age of this act, and within twelve months from the date thereof, it shall be the duty of the commissioners named in the first section of this act, or a majority of them, to assemble the subscribers to the capital stock, by giving due notice of time and place, by publication in two papers in the city of Galveston, or by written notice served on every stockholder, at least ten days previous; and then one of the said commissioners, to be selected by the ‘ others, shall, ex-officio, preside at the meeting thus assembled, and he shall proceed to effect the organization of the company by the election of directors as here-
inbefore provided, first exacting that five per cent. of the stock
Laws of the State of Texas.represented shall be paid down before any vote is cast; and the meeting shall then proceed to elect a directory, which directory shall immediately select a temporary treasurer, who shall take charge of the five per cent. paid in; then the directory, at their discretion shall, within thirty days, perfect their organization by the election of president and vice-presi-
dent, as hereinbefore provided. And when the president and directors as herein elected, shall have established to the satisfaction of any notary public of Galveston county, by the oath or affirmation of the president, that the amount of subscription on stock has been paid up in full, on not less than fifteen hundred shares, and that the terms of this charter have been complied with, then said notary public shall give his certifi-
cate thereof, which shall be their warrant to commence business opera-
tions under the authority vested by this act. And it is herein provided that the duties of the commissioners named shall cease to exist from the date of election of this directory.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted, That when the directory shall have per-
fected their organization as provided for in section eight, and when they shall have made a demand through their president for the remaining ninety-five per cent. due on the capital stock, any stock-holder failing to pay up the amount due on his stock, shall forfeit the five per cent. al-
ready paid in; provided, that thirty days’ notice of the call for ninety-
five per cent. be given by publication in two newspapers published in the city of Galveston.

Sec. 10. Be it farther enacted. That the general office of this company shall be located in the city of Galveston, and that there its books of rec-
ords and transfer shall be kept. And that the privileges of this charter shall continne for fifty years.

div3.head: CHAPTER VI.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of the “East Texas Agricultural and Mechanical Association.”

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the declaration of the late Constitutional Convention, incorporating the “East Texas Agricultural and Mechanical Associa-
tion” is hereby confirmed and amended as follows: That there is hereby created a body corporate and politic, to be styled the “East
Laws of the State of Texas.Texas Agricultural and Mechanical Association.” That said corpora-
tion shall be capable of suing and being sued in any and all courts what-
ever, and shall use a common seal, and may enter into contracts, and make and enforce such necessary by-laws, miles and regulations for car-
rying into effect the objects of this charter, as shall not be inconsistent with the laws of the United States, or of the State of Texas.

Sec. 2. That said corporation shall be enabled to purchase and hold such real and personal property as may be necessary to effectuate and sustain the object of its creation, which is hereby declared to be, to en-
courage and promote the development of the agricultural and mechanical interests of the State.

Sec. 3. That the officers of the Rusk County Agricultural Society, to wit: W. W. Morris, President, James R. Armstrong and Robert Dansby. Vice Presidents, Thomas Loyd and J. N Still, Secretaries, and A. B. Collins, Treasurer, and W. PI. Marshall, Corresponding Secretary, are hereby authorized to open books at the town of Henderson, for subscrip-
tion to the capital stock of said corporation, in such amount only as may be necessary for the legitimate objects of said association, to be deter-
mined by them. The said capital stock shall be divided into shares of ten dollars each, in specie, and shall not exceed in the aggregate the sum of fifty thousand dollars. In the election by stockholders, each share shall be entitled to one vote, but no stockholder shall be entitled to more than ten votes.

Sec. 4. That said corporators shall give notice in the “Henderson Times” of the opening of said books, which shall be kept open for thirty days, or longer, if they may deem it necessary, to obtain the requisite amount of stock.

Sec. 5. That at the time of subscribing, the whole amount of said share or shares shall be paid in, and said stock shall be deemed personal assets, and shall be transferred only on the books of said corporation by the person owning the same, or his legally constituted agent, attorney, legal representative, trustee, or guardian, and said stock shall ever be held subject to any demand due from the stockholder to the said cor-
poration, before or at the date of the transfer.

Sec. 6. No dividends shall be declared or paid on said stock for more than the rate of twelve per cent. per annum on the sum paid in; but the fund accruing above this shall be faithfully devoted to the objects of the corporation.

Sec. 7. On the subscription and payment of the stock advertised for by said corporation, they shall proceed to an organization. The affairs and business of the company shall be managed by a board of
Laws of the State of Texas.directors, not less than five nor more than seven in number, who shall be elected annually by the stockholders; the day of election to be fixed by said corporators. The directors shall hold their offices for the term of twelve months, and until their successors are elected, and enter upon the discharge of their duties. Should the stockholders fail to meet, at any time, and elect directors, the directors in office shall appoint a day for a special election. Thirty days’ notice shall be given of all elections for directors. No person shall be eligible as a director, secretary or treasurer, unless he owns at least two shares of the capital stock of said company. The said board shall elect a president and vice-president from their num-
ber, fill vacancies, appoint a treasurer and secretary, and such other offi-
cers as they may deem necessary, and require bond and security for the faithful performance of their official duties, if they see fit, and do all other acts and things that they may deem necessary in conducting the business of said company, not in contravention of the constitution and laws of the United States, or of the State of Texas. A majority of said board of directors shall constitute a quorum to do business.

Sec. 8. Instruments or contracts in writing, authorized by the com-
pany, shall be signed by the president, and countersigned by the secretary, with the seal of the company affixed; and said company shall be bound by the parol contracts made by their authorized agents, within the scope of the authority to be conferred on them by resolutions of the board of directors.

Sec. 9. That the stockholders in said corporation shall be liable in a just ratio or proportion to the amount of the stock held or subscribed by them, for all debts incurred or created during their said ownership of said stock, to the extent of the amount of their stock subscribed.

Sec. 10. That said corporation may receive and hold by gift, grant or bequest, for the benefit of the same, any lands, money, or labor (in lien of money), material or other property; but the whole amount of property to be held by said company shall not exceed fifty thousand dollars.

Sec. 11. That said president and board of directors shall have power to make all necessary rules and regulations for the holding of their fairs, and for the preservation of order, and the protection of the fair grounds from disturbance or breaches of the peace, during the time of holding fairs. At the commencement of said fairs said rules shall be conspicuously posted up at the entrance gate thereof, and any person who shall wilfully violate any of said rules or regu-
lations, shall be subject to a fine not exceeding fifty dollars, to be
Laws of the State of Texas.recovered by complaint or indictment, in any court having jurisdiction of such offenses.

Sec. 12. That nothing in this act shall impair the rights of any creditor of the late Rusk County Agricultural Society, to any lien on the property of said society, for the payment of advances to the same, in money, material or labor; hut said debts shall be assumed and paid by the corporation hereby created. And the said corporation shall settle with the members of the Rusk County Agricultural Society, for the amount they have each paid in to become members thereof, by refunding the money they have so paid in, or by giving them free tickets to the fairs for such time as may be agreed upon, or by such other mode of adjust-
ment as may be satisfactory to both parties.
Sec. 13. That this act take effect and be in force for ninety-nine years from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER VII.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the Bellville, Hempstead and Brazos Bridge Com-
pany.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That John G. Bell, and such others as he may associate with himself, are hereby incorporated under the name and title of the “Bellville, Hempstead and Brazos Bridge Company,” and under such name shall sue and be sued, and have succession for thirty years.

Sec. 2. Said company shall have the right to construct a bridge, of iron or wood, across the Brazos river, on the banks they deem most suit-
able, at or near a point where a good road, at all seasons, can be had, from the town of Bellville to the town of Hempstead, in Austin county, Texas.

Sec. 3. Said company shall construct said bridge in a good and substantial manner, within (5) five years from the first day of Janu-
ary, A. D. 1871, and shall keep the same in good repair for the term of thirty years from the completion thereof, and to be ready at all times, night and day, to pass all passengers, carriages, wagons, teams and stock that may wish to cross on said bridge, and be re-
Laws of the State of Texas.sponsible, as common carriers, under the law, for any loss of property in transit over said bridge.

Sec. 4. That it shall be the duty of the County Court of Austin county, from time to time, to cause said bridge to be examined; and whenever they shall consider the same to be not in a good and safe condition for the crossing of persons and property, they may cause the gates thereof to be opened for the free crossing of the public, and so remain open until said bridge company shall place said bridge in good repair.

Sec. 5. That no person or persons shall-he authorized or allowed to erect any bridge or keep any ferry across said Brazos river, at or within (5) five miles, on a straight line, above or below the said bridge herein authorized, when completed; provided, that in case said bridge shall get-
out of repair, said company may keep a ferry boat to cross persons and property until the said bridge is put in order.

Sec. 6. That the said company shall have the right to establish said bridge at any point (as in section second,) and have the right of way over any land on either side of the Brazos river where the said company conclude to place the said bridge (as in section second,) which may inter-
pose or lie between the termination of any road so selected by said com-
pany (as in section second,) and said bridge, if any there be, and may enter upon and take possession of said land; provided, the same shall not exceed the width of (50) fifty feet, by paying the owner or owners thereof whatever price may be agreed upon; and should the said owner or owners of the land not be able to agree as to the price, the said company may petition the presiding justice of the County Court of said county, giving a description of the land which they require, with the names of the owner or owners thereof; and the presiding justice shall summons a jury of six freeholders, not in any way or manner interested, who shall, on oath, make a report of the value of the land so required, and upon pay-
ment thereof by the company to the owner or owners, or his or their agents, a good bona fide title shall be granted by said presiding justice to said company, a copy of which shall be recorded in the office of the county clerk of the county aforesaid.

Sec. 7. That when said bridge shall be completed, said company are authorized to demand and receive from each and every person crossing this bridge, or crossing their property over the same, a toll not to ex-
ceed the following rates, to-wit: For each wagon, cart, carriage or other vehicle drawn by more than two horses or other animals, (2O) twenty cents per wheel, and (5) five cents for each animal by which the same is drawn; and where the same is drawn by (2) two animals, or less, (10) ten cents per wheel, and (5) five
Laws of the State of Texas.cents for each animal by which the same is drawn; for each animal and rider (10) ten cents; for each loose horse, mule, jack or jennet (5) five cents; for each loose animal of the cattle kind (5) five cents; for each foot passenger (5) five cents; for each sheep, hog or goat, (3) three cents.

Sec. 8. That this charter of incorporation continue and remain in force for thirty years from and after the completion of said bridge, and that this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER VIII.

opener.salute: An Act appropriating money to pay a claim upon vouchers against the State.

div3.p:
Be it resolved by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the sum of two hundred and thirty-seven dollars, and sixty-nine cents, ($237 69) he and the same is hereby appropriated out of any money in the Treas-
ury, not otherwise appropriated, to pay two vouchers against the State, in favor of John Gerraty, for services rendered the State at the State Penitentiary; and that A. Faulkner is hereby authorized to receive and receipt for the same.

div3.head: CHAPTER IX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the “Agricultural, Stock Raising and Industrial Association of Western Texas.”

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Agricultural, Stock Raising and Industrial Association of Western Texas is hereby declared a body corporate and politic, with power to sue and be sued, to plead and be impleaded, and with the right and power to buy, hold and sell property, real and personal, to the amount of one hundred thousand dollars.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 2. That said association shall have a common seal, and shall, in general, have and exercise all the rights, privileges and immunities that are, by law, incident to and necessary for corporations of a similar char-
acter.

Sec. 3. That W. H. Jackson, E. Braden, W. G. Kingsbury, Erastus Keed, F. Kalteyer, T. H. Stribling, E. Pentenrieder, W. J. Locke, Joseph Deutz, Th. Hertzberg, Jas. P. Newcomb, W. W. Gamble, F. Schenck, and their successors in office, are hereby constituted trustees for said asso-
ciation.
Sec. 4. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER X.

opener.salute:
“An Act to incorporate the Jewish Congregation B’nai Israel of Gal-
veston, Texas.”

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. W. Frank, D. Wenar, I. Dyer, M. Kopperl, S. K. Labatt, S. E. Loeb, Henry J. Labatt, Leon Blum, A. Ivory, C. Kahn, I. Decider, S. H. Heidenheimer, J. Blum, jr., and those whom they may associate with them are hereby incorporated into a body politic, to be known as the Jewish Congregation B’nai Israel of Galveston, Texas.

Sec. 2. The said Jewish Congregation B’nai Israel of Galveston, Texas, shall have the right to sue and be sued in its corporate name; to hold real and personal estate, receive bequests, gifts and devises, regulate the mode of worship and religious observances of its members, and to exclude those who do not confirm thereto; have a common seal and enjoy all the civil rights of bodies corporate.
Sec. 3. Its affairs shall be managed by a board or officers, not less than five in number, whose duties shall be prescribed by the laws and regulations of the congregation.
Sec. 4. The members of said congregation may enact all necessary by-laws, rules and regulations for their self-government which shall be necessary to give the said corporation force and effect.
Sec. 5. This act shall take effect from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate “The Galveston Bay Dredging Company."

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Thomas Peacock, Blair Gallaher, Bernard Tiernan, Fitzhugh Ward, James Wrigley, T. S. Prindle, and their associates and successors, be and they are hereby created and established a body corporate and politic, under the name of the “Galveston Bay Dredging Company,” with ca-
pacity as such and in said corporate name to have succession and a com-
mon seal; to make by-laws for the regulation and government of its affairs; to make contracts, and to acquire, by purchase or otherwise, property, real and personal, and to hold the same; to sue and be sued, to plead and be impleaded, and generally to do and perform all such acts and things as may be necessary and proper for, or incident to, the full enjoyment of all the rights and privileges granted by this act.

Sec. 2. That the said company shall have a capital stock of fifty thousand dollars, with the privilege of increasing the same to an amount not to exceed one hundred thousand dollars, and shall have its domicile and principal office in the city and county of Galveston, in said State.

Sec. 3. That the said company be and is hereby authorized and em-
powered to deepen, and render suitable and convenient for navigation, by dredging or otherwise, the bar obstructing that mouth of, or entrance to the Trinity river, which is immediately next to and west of the mouth or entrance of said river, now generally used by steamboats, and com-
monly known as “The Canal.”

Sec. 4. That the said company shall have the right to demand, and collect from the master and owner or owners of each and every steamboat and water craft of whatever kind that shall pass through the channel made or improved as aforesaid, such tolls upon said steamboats and water crafts, and upon the freight carried thereon, through said channel, as the said company may determine upon, not to exceed, however, twenty-five cents per ton on the tonnage of said steamboats and water craft; twenty-five cents per hale on cotton and wool, and in like proportion on other freight brought out of said river; two and one-half cents per foot on measurement freight, and one-twentieth of one cent per pound on other freight; and the said tolls, so charged, shall constitute a lien on said steamboats and water
Laws of the State of Texas.craft; and if any master or owner or owners of such steamboats or water craft shall, when called on by said company, fail or refuse to report, or report falsely, the amount and character of freight on board, then said master, owner or owners shall be chargeable with the tolls to the full capacity of said steamboat or other water craft, which shall be a lien thereon as aforesaid

Sec. 5. That the persons named in the first section hereof, or a ma-
jority of them, are hereby appointed commissioners, and invested with the rights of forming and organizing said company, and to that end shall open books for the subscription of stock; and when twenty-five thousand dollars thereof shall have been subscribed, shall immediately, by publi-
cation for ten days, in some newspaper published in said city, call a meeting of the stockholders, to be held in said city at such place as they may designate in said public notice; and the said stockholders shall thereupon proceed to form a permanent organization of said company, by the establishment of its by-laws as aforesaid, which shall be adopted by the consent of holders of two-thirds of the stock subscribed, given in person or by proxy. And upon the said organization as aforesaid, the power of the said commisssioners shall cease and determine, and the stockholders so organized as aforesaid shall thereupon become the suc-
cessors of the persons herein named, and as such the body politic and corporate herein created.

Sec. 6. That there shall be held by said stockholders one regular meeting in said city in each year, at such time as said by-laws may pre scribe, and also such other meetings as may be provided for therein; and in all meetings each stockholder shall be entitled to one vote, in person or by proxy, for each share of stock held or represented by him, unless otherwise provided by the by-laws first established; and all questions shall be determined by a majority of the votes cast, except in cases of altering or amending the by-laws, when a majority of two-thirds of the votes cast shall be required. The capital stock of said company shall be divided into such number of equal shares as said stockholders may de-
termine by their by-laws at their first meeting.

Sec. 7. That the affairs of said company shall be managed by such number of directors as shall be determined by said by-laws, whose term of office and powers and duties shall be therein prescribed; and by such subordinate officers as may be therein provided for.
Sec. 8. That this act shall take effect from and after its passage, and continue in force for the period of twenty-five years.

closer.dateline: Passed June 30, 1870; Vetoed July 11, 1870; Veto withdrawn July 19, 1870.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the “Washington Fire Engine Company No. 1,” of the city of Austin.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That John Bremond, Joseph A. Nagle, L. N. Edwards, E. T. Eggleston, and Joseph A. Costa, of the county of Travis, and State of Texas, and their associates and successors, are hereby constituted a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of the “Washington Eire Engine Company, Number 1,” and by that name shall have succession, and may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, have and use a corporate seal, buy, sell, and hold property, real, personal and mixed, not to exceed in value ten thousand dollars; may contract and be contracted with, and make all rules and by-laws that may be necessary for the government of the company, and have and exercise all the powers and rights generally incident to such companies.

Sec. 2. That said company shall have the right in its constitution or by-laws to impose upon its members for neglect of duty, not to exceed in any one instance the sum of fixe dollars, which may be collected in the name of said company by suit before any justice of the peace, in and for the county of Travis.
Sec. 3. That the members of said company shall never be less than twenty, nor more than seventy-five in number.
Sec. 4. That the actual active members of the company, who shall hereafter have served therein, for one year, shall be exempt from militia duty and service as jurymen, except in capital cases.
Sec. 5. That neither the company, nor its members, shall be liable in damages or otherwise, for property destroyed or injured by the company while in the discharge of their duties as firemen.

Sec. 6. That all property of the company shall be exempt from taxa-
tion for State and county purposes.
Sec. 7. That this act take effect from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XIII.

opener.salute: An Act granting certain real estate to the city of Austin.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the State of Texas hereby authorizes and empowers the corpora-
tion of the city of Austin, to take possession, and have and exercise ab-
solute control over the following property and real estate, to-wit: Lots numbers nine, ten, eleven and twelve, in block ninety-eight, as the same is laid out on the original plot of the city of Austin, at present known and described as the old capitol property, with appurtenances; to have and to hold the same free of charge for the full term and period of three years from the date of the passage of this act, and at the expiration of the said period of time, the Commissioner of the General Land Office is hereby authorized to relinquish and patent unto the said corporation all her rights, title and interest of, in and to the same; provided, the said corporation within said time shall erect thereon a good and sufficient market house and city hall, for the use of the said city; provided, that whenever the city of Austin shall convert the same for any other use than that mentioned in this act, the said property shall revert to the State.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XIV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Firemen’s Insurance Company of Galveston.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. L. Briggs, Franklin Hitchcock, J. S. Vedder, F. B. Yard, M. A. Davey, M. F. Mott, F. Lindenthal, J. H. Westerlage, John Foth, Hugo Brosig, H. Reybaud, P. H. Hennessy and J. F. W. Ahrens, and their associates, successors and assigns be, and are hereby constituted a body politic and corporate, by the name of the “Firemen’s Insurance Company of Galveston,” and by the
Laws of the State of Texas.same name and style they and their successors shall be capable of suing and being sued, and maintaining any action to final judgment and ex-
ecution, and shall be in law capable of purchasing, holding, improving and conveying any estate, real, personal or mixed, for the use and benefit of said corporation; and may have and use a corporate seal, and change and renew the same at pleasure, and shall have the power to ordain, es-
tablish and put in execution such by-laws, ordinances and regulations as shall be necessary for the government thereof; and it shall be lawful for the said corporation, after the expiration thereof, to use the corporate name, style, seal and capacity for the purpose of suits for the final settle-
ment and liquidation of the affairs and accounts of the corporation, and for the sale and disposition of their estate, real, personal or mixed, but not for any other purpose, nor for a period exceeding three years after the expiration of the term of the incorporation.

Sec. 2. That the capital stock of said corporation shall not be less than one hundred and fifty thousand dollars, nor more than five hundred thousand dollars, divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, and the same shall be created and paid in such manner, and at such time and place as the president and directors of said corporation shall require; of which requisition at least one month’s notice shall be given by publica-
tion in two newspapers printed in the city of Galveston; and if any stock-
holder or stockholders shall fail to pay any installment to be paid, he or she shall cease to be a member of said corporation, and shall forfeit his or her stock, and the share or shares so forfeited may be sold by said cor-
poration in such manner as they may think proper; but such forfeiture and sale of such stock shall not release the holder thereof, nor his or her sureties on the notes contemplated to be given in sections six and eight of this act, from his or her liability on account of said notes, to any per-
son or persons having just claim against said corporation; provided, said claim shall have accrued before such sale.

Sec. 3. That for the well ordering of the affairs of said corporation, there shall be thirteen directors, who shall be stockholders of the corporation. They shall be elected by the stockholders at their annual meeting to be held on the first Tuesday in March of each year for that purpose, and the directors, at the first meeting, shall choose one of their own number as president, and another as vice-
president; provided, nevertheless, that until the first annual election the persons named in the first section of this act shall have and may exercise all the powers given to the president and directors by this act; and in all elections for directors the vote shall be by bal-
lot, and each stockholder shall have one vote for each share he or she may hold; but no stockholder shall vote at any election unless
Laws of the State of Texas.the share or shares upon which he or she claims to vote, shall have been standing in his or her name on the books of said corporation for at least three months previous to such election. In case of absence of a stock-
holder from any annual or general meeting, such stockholder may be en-
titled to vote by written proxy.

Sec. 4. That the directors of said corporation for the time being, seven of whom, including the president or vice president shall form a quorum, shall have power to appoint such clerk, agents and other per-
sons as shall be necessary for conducting the business of said corporation, and to allow said persons so appointed such compensation for their ser-
vices as they shall deem proper, and generally to exercise all other powers and privileges that are given by law to corporations.

Sec. 5. That it shall be lawful for the said corporation to employ the funds thereof in establishing and sustaining the business of marine and fire insurance; to insure vessels in port, buildings, merchandise and all other property on land against loss or damage by fire; to make all and every insurance appertaining to or connected with marine, inland and transportation risks, and to charge, collect and receive for the same such premiums of insurance as the president and directors of said corporation may deem just and reasonable. It shall be lawful for said corporation to receive moneys on deposit, and pay out the same; to buy and sell ex-
changes and to lend any surplus capital they may at any time possess, at a rate of interest not exceeding twelve per centum per annum, or to lend the same on bottomry and respondentia security at marine interest; but it shall not be lawful for said corporation to issue any promissory notes of the character of bank bills.

Sec. 6. That the shares of said corporation shall be assignable and transferable upon the books of said company, according to such rules and regulations as the president and directors thereof shall, for that pur-
pose, ordain and establish; and in case the assignee of any share or shares of stock shall deposit his or her note with securities, as contemplated and provided for in section eight of this act, then the assignor of such share or shares shall have the right to withdraw and cancel his or her note or notes, and securities given for such share or shares of stock; other-
wise the notes and securities of said assignor shall be and remain sub-
ject and liable to all the conditions and provisions contained in section nine of this act.

Sec. 7. That the president and directors of said corporation shall annually or semi-annually make such dividends of the net profits of the company as shall appear advisable; hut this rule of distri-
bution shall, in all cases be observed, to-wit: One half of said profits, after deducting twenty-five per cent. thereof for a reserved
Laws of the State of Texas.fund, shall be credited to the stockholders in proportion to the stock owned by them and indorsed upon their notes; and for the residue a cash dividend may be declared or endorsed upon the stockholders’ notes at the discretion of the directory; and when such notes are paid in full, it shall be the duty of the president and directors to issue certificates to stockholders for full paid shares.

Sec. 8. That the office of the company incorporated by this act shall be established and located in the city of Galveston, and as soon as the president and directors thereof shall establish by evidence, to the satis-
faction of the judge of the District Court of Galveston county, that ten per cent. of the minimum capital stock of said corporation has been paid by the stockholders thereof, and that the balance or residue of said capital stock of two hundred and fifty thousand dollars has been secured, to be paid when called for, as contemplated in section second of this act, by the notes of the holders of said capital stock, secured by good and sol-
vent security or securities, and shall also establish, to the satisfaction of said judge of the District Court, that the directors of said corporation have been organized in conformity to the provisions of section third of this act, then the said judge of the District Court shall give them a cer-
tificate thereof, which shall be their warrant to commence business opera-
tions under the authority vested by this act.
Sec. 9. That in all suits against said corporation, service upon the president or secretary of the company will be sufficient.
Sec. 10. That the charter, granted by this act shall continue in full force and effect for the term of fifty years, from and after the passage of this act.

div3.head: CHAPTER XV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Jefferson, Marshall and Big Cypress Bayou Bridge Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That William H. Johnson, Donald Campbell and J. H. Roberts, and such other persons as they may associate with themselves, and their successors, are hereby created and constituted a body corporate under the name and style of the Jefferson, Marshall and Big Cypress Bayou Bridge Company, and under such name shall
Laws of the State of Texas.sue and be sued, to have, hold and own property, and have succession for thirty years. Said company shall have the right to construct a bridge or bridges, of iron or wood, across the Big Cypress Bayou, at a suitable point opposite the city of Jefferson, between said city of Jefferson and Marshall. Said company shall construct said bridge in a good and sub-
stantial manner, within five years from the first day of January, A. D. 1870, and shall keep the same in good repair for the term of thirty years from the completion thereof, and to be ready at all times to pass all pas-
sengers, carriages, wagons, teams and stock that may wish to cross on said bridge, and be responsible as common carriers, under the law, for any loss of property in transit over said bridge.

Sec. 2. That said company shall be entitled to charge and receive, from the completion of said bridge, for the term of thirty years, the following tolls from all persons who may cross themselves or their prop-
erty, viz: Four horse, or ox stage or wagon, fifty cents; for six horse or ox stage or wagon, sixty cents; and for each additional pair of horses, mules or oxen attached to said wagon, ten cents; for man and horse, ten cents; single horse and buggy, twenty-five cents; two horse buggies, two horse or ox wagons, forty cents; other vehicles in proportion. Footmen, five cents; cattle, five cents per head; hogs, sheep and goats, two cents per head; and other property in proportion to the above rates.

Sec. 3. That no other bridge or ferry shall be constructed or kept across the said Big Cypress Bayou or river, for the space of thirty years, after the completion of the bridge, within a space of two and a half miles in a straight line above, and two and a half miles in a straight line below said bridge, except railroad bridges: which said Jefferson, Marshall and Big Cypress Bayou Bridge Company may construct: provided, that in case the said bridge shall get out of repair, the said company shall be authorized to keep a ferry boat for the crossing of passengers over said bayou or river, until the said bridge is repaired or put in order.

Sec. 4. That any person crossing said bridge, and refusing or other-
wise attempting to evade the payment of the tolls herein allowed, when said company is authorized to demand and receive the same, shall forfeit and pay to said company for every such attempt the sum of five dollars for each item attempted to be evaded, which may be recovered before any justice of the peace in whose jurisdiction such person may be found; pro-
vided, that nothing herein contained shall be construed to prevent any person from crossing at any ford on said bayou or river.
Sec. 5. That this act shall take effect from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XVI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Red River county, Texas, Agricultural and Mechanical Association.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That L. D. Van Dyke, James N. B. Donoho, W. P. Clutterbuck, John A. Chambers, W. W. Giddons, J. T. Fleming, J. L. Bryarly, Jos. J. Strygley, — Dinwiddie, W. W. Clark, Charles De Morse, John C. West, A. S. Baker, Miles Reed, R. W. Townes, L. W. Ward, and others, their asso-
ciates and successors, be and they are hereby declared a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “Red River County, Texas, Agricultural and Mechanical Association,” and by said corporate name shall be capable of suing and being sued, pleading and being impleaded, contracting and being contracted with, and of doing and performing all things necessary to carry into effect the objects of this act. They shall also have and use a common seal.

Sec. 2. That the persons named in the first section of this act shall act as commissioners, to obtain by subscription the capital stock of said association, and that the stockholders shall organize the same in the man-
ner hereinafter provided.

Sec. 3. That the objects of said association are declared to be the im-
provement of the breed of domestic animals, and the encouragement of agricultural and mechanical improvements, and for these purposes said association is authorized to purchase, import, breed, exhibit, and sell, any kind of domestic animals; to purchase, import, manufacture, exhibit, and sell such improved machinery and implements as will promote the me-
chanical, agricultural, and manufacturing interests of the people of this State; provided, nothing herein contained shall infringe upon the rights of patentees. For the further purpose of carrying out the objects and purposes above declared, said association is hereby authorized to own the necessary real estate for fair grounds, pastures, and farming grounds, not to exceed five hundred acres, and to erect upon the same such improve-
ments as may be necessary to carry out the objects of this association. That the fair grounds and other improvements of said association shall be located in the county of Red River, in this State.

Sec. 4. That the capital stock of said association shall not exceed fifty thousand dollars, to be divided into shares of twenty dollars each, and that the affairs of said association shall be con-
Laws of the State of Texas.ducted by a board of directors, to be elected by and from the stockhold-
ers of said association, and than said board shall consist of not more than twelve, and a president and vice-president, secretary and treasurer, who shall be elected from and by the stockholders of this association. These officers, and the board of directors, shall make such by-laws, rules and regulations, and appoint such other officers and agents, as may be neces-
sary for the government and conduct of said association.
Sec. 5. That this act shall take effect and be in force for twenty-five years from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XVII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate “The City Bank of Houston.”

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That there may be established in the city of Houston an association for the purpose of transacting a general banking and exchange business, which association shall be called and known by the name of “The City Bank of Houston,” and the stockholders and their successors shall have continuous succession, and by that name shall be capable of suing and being sued in all the courts of this State; of purchasing, holding and con-
veying property of all descriptions; to make, have and use a common seal, and the same to alter and renew at pleasure; and generally to do any act necessary to carry into effect the objects of the corporation not inconsistent with the laws of this State or of the United States.

Sec. 2. That the capital stock of this association shall be not less than two hundred and fifty thousand dollars, to be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, to be paid for at the time of subscription, which capital stock may be increased to one million dollars at the discretion of the president and directors of this corporation. The said stock shall be deemed and held as personal property, and be represented by certifi-
cates under the seal of the association, signed by the president and coun-
tersigned by the treasurer or cashier.

Sec. 3. That the books of subscription to said capital stock shall be opened in the city of Houston under the supervision of W. J. Hutchins, W. M. Rice, P. J. Willis, P. W. Gray, Robert Brewster,
Laws of the State of Texas.C. S. Longcope, Benj. A. Botts, E. H. Cushing, A. J. Burke, or any three of them, and at such place in said city as they or any three of them may direct, advertisement of the time and place of opening such books to be made for one week in some newspaper published in the said city of Hous-
ton, and they shall be kept open until the sum of two hundred and fifty thousand dollars shall be subscribed for; and the said commissioners, or any three of them, shall, as soon as may be after the books of subscrip-
tion are closed, call a meeting of the subscribers, and shall proceed to the election of not less than seven or more than nine directors, as may be determined by them; and the said directors shall elect one of their own number president, and the said president and directors elected in pur-
suance of this act, and their successors, shall have full power and author-
ity to make, appoint, and remove at pleasure all officers and agents of said association; to fix their compensation, prescribe their duties, and provide for the taking of bonds for faithful discharge of their duties, as well as generally to manage the affairs of the association. They shall also have power to fill any vacancy that may occur in their own body, and also appoint a president pro tem. when the president may be absent from their meetings; and if the president or any director be absent without leave for five successive regular meetings of the board, a majority of the same may declare his place vacant, and proceed to fill it without notice to such absent president or director.

SeC. 4. That the directors of this corporation shall call an annual meeting of the stockholders, to make such election for director, who, when so elected, shall hold their offices for the term of one year, or until their successors are elected; and no person shall be eligible to the office of director unless he owns at least five shares of stock.

Sec. 5. That in all meetings of the stockholders those representing a majority of the stock shall constitute a quorum; and each stockholder shall be allowed one vote for each and every share he may hold; and the power to cast the vote of any absent stockholder may be constituted by written power in such form as the directors may prescribe by the by-laws.

Sec. 6. That said corporation shall have full power to receive money and other valuables to keep for depositors; to issue certificates or bills payable on demand, or at specified times; to buy and sell coin and un-
current money, and to buy, sell, draw or negotiate bills of exchange or other securities. It may loan its money, and discount any promissory note or negotiable paper, or other security assignable by law, receiving the interest or discount thereon in advance.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 7. That the president and directors of said corporation shall have full power to pass such by-laws as may be necessary to carry this act into effect; to delegate authority to such officer or agent as they may think proper; and to execute or authorize the execution of all such bargains and contracts as may seem to them for the best interest of this corpora-
tion; and it is provided that a majority of the board of directors shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of all business.

Sec. 8. That the president and directors of said corporation shall have full power to fix the places and modes of transfer of stock, as well as the payment of interest and dividends; and any person in whose name shares of stock stand on the books of this corporation, shall, so far as affects the rights and acts of the association, be deemed at law and in equity the owner.

Sec. 9. That it any stockholder shall, for valuable consideration, sell, pledge, or otherwise dispose of any of his shares of stock to another, and deliver to him the certificate of such shares with a power of attorney au-
thorizing the transfer of the same on the books of the association, the title of such stockholder, both at law and in equity, shall vest in the pur-
chaser so far as may be necessary to effect the purpose of the sale, pledge, or other disposition, not only as between the parties themselves, but also as against the creditors of and subsequent purchasers from such stock-
holder, subject to the provision of the eighth section.

Sec. 10. That when any person to whom a certificate of stock shall have been issued, alleges it to have been lost, he shall file in the office of this corporation, first, an affidavit setting forth the time, place and cir-
cumstances of the loss; second, proof of his having advertised the same in some newspaper once a week for two months; and third, a bond to the association, with one or more sureties, conditioned to indemnify all per-
sons, as against any loss in consequence of issuing a new certificate in place of the former, and thereupon the board of directors, if satisfied of such loss and with such security, may direct such new certificate to be issued.

Sec. 11. That this charter, and all the privileges and powers herein granted shall continue in force and effect for the full term of twenty-five years from the passage of this act; and that this corpora-
tion shall be responsible to the extent of its property, both real and personal; and that the funds, property and business transac-
tions of the association shall be subject to the same rate of taxation by law imposed on the funds, property and similar transactions of
Laws of the State of Texas.individuals, and the stockholders shall not again be subject to tax on their shares or dividend.
Sec. 12. This act shall be in force from its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Bayou City Bank.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That E. Peliot, A. B. Hall, H. E. Perkins, R. O. Love, R. Greene, junior, J. G. Tracey, T. H. Seanlan, and such other persons as they may associate with them, and their successors, be and they are hereby created a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of the “Bayou City Bank,” and by said corporate name shall have succession, and may sue and be sued; may have and use a corporate seal; may own property real, personal and mixed, and may mortgage and alienate the same. They may also issue bank bills, and borrow and loan money.
Sec. 2. The legal domicile of the company shall be in the city of Houston.

Sec. 3. That the said company, under their corporate name, shall be empowered to deal in foreign and domestic exchange, bank notes, coin, bullion, cotton, wool, hides, or any other things of value, and to buy and sell the stock of any other incorporated company, or the bonds of any other company, or of any county, city or State; to issue, emit and circu-
late their own notes; provided, such circulation shall not exceed at any one time the amount of their capital stock already subscribed; and to do and perform all acts necessary for or incidental to the carrying out of the objects of the company, or appertaining to a banking and exchange com-
pany.

Sec. 4. That the capital stock of said company shall be one hundred thousand dollars, including all its property, real and personal, franchises and rights to property. The stock of the company shall be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, which shall be considered personal property, and shall be transferable as may be provided in the by-laws, and payable at such times and in such sums as the directors may determine in their by-laws. The said company shall organize within two years after the passage of this act.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 5. That said, company shall make by-laws for the government of its affairs and officers; which by-laws may be altered or amended, from time to time, as may be deemed advisable by a majority of the board of directors

Sec. 6. The management of said company shall consist of a board of directors, not less than five nor more than seven, to be elected annually by the stockholders. They shall elect from the board of directors one president and one vice-president, and such other officers as may be pre-
