scribed by the by-laws, and their term of office shall be for one year, or until their successors qualify.

Sec. 7. All obligations of the company shall be signed by the presi-
dent and cashier.

Sec. 8. The capital stock of the company may be increased to five hun-
dred thousand dollars by the board of directors, as may be prescribed by the by-laws.
Sec. 9. That this act of incorporation shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage, and shall remain in force for the period of fifty years.

div3.head: CHAPTER XIX.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of the heirs of General Sam. Houston, deceased.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the land certificate heretofore issued by the lawful authorities of the late Republic of Texas, to General Sam Houston for military services from November 1835, to October 1836, for twelve hundred and eighty acres be, and the same is hereby approved, and declared to be a just claim from its original date against the State of Texas; and that the Commis-
sioner of the General Land Office be and is hereby authorized to issue a patent on the same, in the name of the heirs of General Sam Houston, deceased.

Sec. 2. That the owners of any land certificate, located on land in conflict with a previous location made by virtue of the foregoing war-
rant, and not patented, are hereby authorized to lift and locate the same on other lands; and that this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XX.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of J. H. Hallanuqist.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Treasurer of the State be, and he is hereby authorized to pay to J. H. Hallanquist the sum of ($1328.20) thirteen hundred and twenty-
eight dollars and twenty cents, currency, being the amount justly due him for services rendered as State Engineer.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect from, and be in force after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Gulf Land Company of Galveston, Texas.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That E. Randall, R. P. Boyce, J. P. Garland, Thomas Compton and Selim Rinker, and their associates and successors, be and they are hereby created and established a body corporate and politic, under the name of “The Gulf Land Company of Galveston, Texas,” the objects of said company being to build a hotel and other buildings on their lands on the sea side of the city of Galveston, and to improve said lands, and sell or lease the same.

Sec. 2. That said company as such shall have capacity in said corpo-
rate name to have succession and a common seal; to make by-laws for the regulation and government of its affairs; to make contracts; to sue and be sued; to plead and be impleaded, and generally to do and perform all such acts and things as may be necessary and proper for, or incident to, the full enjoyment of all the rights and privileges granted by this act.

Sec. 3. That said company may acquire by purchase or other-
wise, property, real and personal, and hold, occupy, improve, lease, sell or dispose of said property, or any part thereof, by the action
Laws of the State of Texas.of three-fourths of the stock of said company, expressed in writing, or at any meeting of the company.

Sec. 4. That said company shall have a capital stock of one hundred, thousand dollars, to be divided into shares of twenty dollars each, with the privilege of increasing the same to any sum not to exceed two hun-
dred thousand dollars.

Sec. 5. That the affairs of said company shall be managed by a board of directors, to consist of not less than three nor more than five stock-
holders of the company; said directors shall be chosen or elected under the rules or by-laws of the company. Each share of stock shall entitle the holder thereof to one vote at any meeting of the company; but any vote of three-fourths of the issued stock upon any question shall be bind-
ing on all the stock of the company.
Sec. 6. That the corporators herein named, or a majority of them, shall have authority to organize this company after the passage of this act.
Sec. 7. That this act shall take effect from and after its passage, and shall continue in force for the period of twenty-five years.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXII.

opener.salute: An Act to Incorporate the Society Los Indisolubles of the City of San Antonio.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Joe Firmin, Cassiano Narcisco Leal, Juan Cardenas, Antonio P. Rivas Alejo Perez, E. Buchetti, Juan M. C. Naves, Y. Martinez, R. M. Pereida, V. Beze, J. M. Valdez, M. E. Flores, E. Navarro, and J. E. Bar-
rera, and their associates and successors, be and they are hereby consti-
tuted a body corporate and politic for the promotion of education, mor-
als, benevolence, and the encouragement of scientific and literary pur-
suits, under the name and style of “The Society Los Indisolubles of the city of San Antonio;" and by that name may receive, hold, enjoy, sell, convey, and alienate property real, personal and mixed, and by the aforesaid name may sue and be sued,defend and be defended, plead and be impleaded, in any court of law or equity within this State; provided, that the value of real estate held by said society at any one time shall not exceed in value the sum of fifty thousand dollars.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 2. That the said society shall have power to make such a con-
stitution and by-laws, and to change or alter the same, as they may deem necessary for their own government, not contrary to the Constitution and laws of this State, and may elect from their own body the officers necessary for conducting the business of said society.

Sec. 3. That this corporation shall have a common seal, and shall in general have and exercise all such rights, privileges, and immunities as by law are incident to, and necessary for, corporations of a similar character.

Sec. 4. That the privileges, immunities and franchises of this corpo-
ration shall expire unless renewed within thirty years.

Sec. 5. That in any suit or other proceedings against the said corpo-
ration, service of process or of notice, or of any other papers, may be made by delivering to any officer of the corporation a copy thereof duiy certified, and the officer, or other person serving the same, shall state in his return the officer of the corporation upon whom it was served, naming him.

Sec. 6. That any deed of conveyance duly signed and executed by the officer of said corporation, in pursuance of a resolution authorizing the same, shall be deemed valid in law, and shall in law have the same force and effect as any other like deed of conveyance.
Sec. 7. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXIII.

opener.salute:
An Act to Incorporate the Odd Fellows’ Building and Exchange Com-
pany of Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That R. O. Love, D. U. Barziza, I. R. Newrath, S. Preis-
ter, J. Haske, G. W. Lemuel, J. Jophet, F. L. Delesdernier, A. C. Rogers. M. E. Davis, H. R. Allen, P. W. Gray, H. E. Perkins, J. W. Oliver, and their present and future associates, successors and assigns be, and are hereby incorporated and created a body politic and corporate, by the name and style of “The Odd Fellows’ Build-
ing and Exchange Company of Texas,” and by said corporate name shall have perpetual succession, with full power and capacity to sue
Laws of the State of Texas.and be sued, and maintain any action to final judgment and execution in any of the courts of this State; and shall be capable of purchasing, taking by grant, gift or donation, and of holding, improving and convey-
ing any estate or property, real, personal or mixed, for the use of said corporation; and shall have power to make contracts, execute promissory notes, draw bills of exchange, execute deeds of trust and mortgages; make dividends and divisions of property, issue bonds, have a common seal, with such device as they may adopt, establish such by-laws as shall be necessary for the government of said company, and do and perform all other acts incident and appertaining to the powers granted by this act.

Sec. 2. That for the well ordering of the affairs of said corporation, there shall be seven directors, five of whom shall be active members of the Independent Order of Odd Fellows. Said directors shall be stock-
holders, entitled to vote upon their stock under this charter, and shall be elected by the stockholders entitled to vote upon their stock, and who are not in arrears (each share being counted one vote,) in such manner as the by-laws may direct, and shall be chosen for one year from the date of their election, or until successors shall be elected.

Sec. 3. The officers of this company shall be a president, vice-presi-
dent, treasurer and secretary, all of whom shall be chosen by the directors, and the positions of secretary and treasurer may both be filled by the same person, or by two persons, at the option of the directors; such offi-
cers shall hold their offices for one year from the date of their election, or until their successors are chosen and qualified; provided, however, that the said directors and officers may be removed before the expiration of their terms of office, in such manner and for such causes as the by-laws may determine, and such by-laws may define the rights and duties of said directors and officers, and may provide for the compensation of any of them, and may require bonds from any of them.

Sec. 4. The principal object of this corporation is for the purpose of erecting suitable halls and temples in the State of Texas, for the benefit and advancement of the Independent Order of Odd Fellows; but this shall not be construed to affect or diminish, in any way, any other rights, powers and privileges granted by this act.

Sec. 5. The capital stock of this company shall be one hundred thousand dollars, which may be increased at any time by a two-thirds vote of the directors, to an amount not to exceed a mil-
lion of dollars, and the said directors may thereupon issue such paid up shares in excess of said capital stock of one hundred thousand dollars, at such price or premium as they may adopt, but shall not issue them at less price than at par; but such excess may be taken and
Laws of the State of Texas.subscribed for under the same berms that are herein provided for the taking and subscribing to the capital stock of one hundred thousand dol-
lars.

Sec. 6. The capital stock shall be divided into shares of twenty-five dollars each, payable in installments, monthly, of one dollar per share, on or before the first day of each month in advance; and if said installments be not so paid, promptly on or before the first day of each month, in ad-
vance, the share or shares so in arrears shall be declared forfeited to the company by the directors at their next meeting after such failure to pay, and the share or shares so forfeited may be disposed of for the use of the company as the by-laws may prescribe; and said delinquent shareholder or shareholders shall then and there cease to be a member or members of this company, and such forfeiture is hereby declared to be complete and beyond redemption; provided, however, that such forfeiture shall work a discharge of the owner or owners of the share or shares by whom it or they have been forfeited, from further liability as subscriber or sub-
scribers to such forfeited stock.

Sec. 7. That the shares of said company shall be transferred on the books of the same, under such rules and regulations as the by-laws may direct; and no shareholder shall vote at any general election unless the share or shares upon which he or she offers to vote in his or her name, or by proxy, shall have been standing on the books of the company in his or her name for at least one month previous to such election; but any share-
holder entitled to vote, may vote by proxy under such rules as the by-
laws may prescribe; provided, no share shall be entitled to a vote unless it has been paid up to an amount equal to those paid up from the organiza-
tion of this company under this act.

Sec. 8. That as soon as two hundred shares shall have been subscribed, and the first installment of one dollar per share shall have been paid thereon, this company may organize under this act, and for this purpose the said corporators, or a majority of them, may, upon the passage of this act, open the books of said company, after ten days’ public notice, for subscription to stock, and when the requisite number of shares shall have been subscribed, and the first installments paid, shall call a meeting of the shareholders, at which meeting the shareholders may elect the directors and adopt by-laws, and fully organize under this act, and there-
after the directors shall hold a meeting for the transaction of business once during each month, upon such day as the by-laws may prescribe; provided, that such day be not earlier than the tenth day of each month, and at such meetings four of said directors shall constitute a quorum.

Sec. 9. That said company may loan its moneys, receive de-
Laws of the State of Texas.posits, buy and sell exchange, drafts or other obligations, bullion, coin, and all sorts of currency, bonds and securities, and shares or stock in companies, incorporated or not incorporated, and may loan money upon any terms or plan they may adopt, and have full power to do and perform all acts which may be appropriate and incident to the company, out of the powers and privileges granted by this act.
Sec. 10. That this act take effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXIV.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of Harvin W. Moore.

div3.p: Whereas, Harvin W. Moore was appointed district attorney of the Ninth Judicial District of the State of Texas, on the thirtieth day of November, one thousand eight hundred and sixty-seven, by Brevet Major General J. J. Reynolds, commanding the Fifth Military District; and

Whereas, The said Harvin W. Moore entered upon the duties of said office at once, having prepared his affidavit and bond as required by law, and the bond not being filed until the tenth day of January, one thou-
sand eight hundred and sixty-eight, therefore,

Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Comptroller of said State be and is hereby authorized and required to issue his warrant in favor of Harvin W. Moore for the sum of one hun-
dred and eleven dollars.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the State Treasurer is hereby authorized to pay the said draft out of any moneys in the treasury not otherwise appropriated, the said Harvin W. Moore receipting for the same.
Sec. 3. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXV.

opener.salute:
An Act to prohibit the sale or otherwise disposing of spirituous or other intoxicating liquors within two miles of the village of Ladonia, Fan-
nin County, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That it shall not be lawful for any person, either with or without license, to sell, or in any manner dispose of any spirituous, vinous, or other intoxi-
cating liquors within two miles of the village of Ladonia, except for medical or sacramental purposes; and any person violating the provisions of this act shall, upon conviction before a justice of the peace or other court of competent jurisdiction, be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and fined in any sum not less than ten, nor more than one hundred dollars for each and every offense.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXVI.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the Southern Trans-Continental Railway Com-
pany.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That John C. Fremont, George P. Buell, Henry D. Cook, Marshall O. Roberts, John W. Forney, Morton C. Hunter, Thomas A. Morris, R. M. Bishop, William Schmoele, S. W. Moreton, W. Vermillia, D. R. Marten, Samuel D. Hoffman, Daniel Drew, jr., John D. Defrees, J. W.Tibbene, J. P. Bow-
man, George Maney, Maxwell Woodhull, E. L. Fanchier, G. H. Giddings, A. W. Rice, J. R. Russell, S. D. Rainey, J. G. Tracy, J. G. Dumas, and their associates, successors and assigns, be and they are hereby constituted a body corporate and politic, by the name and style of “The Southern Trans-Continental Railway Company,” with power to sue and
Laws of the State of Texas.be sued; plead and be impleaded, contract and to be contracted with; to have perpetual succession, and to adopt and have a corporate seal, and to alter the same at discretion.

Sec. 2. And be it further enacted, That the object of the railway oompany hereby incorporated is to construct and establish a complete first class railway line and telegraphic communication, beginning at a point on the eastern boundary of the State of Texas, bordering on the State of Arkansas, at or near Texarkana, between the Sulphur Fork and Red River, and thence, as near as is practicable, to the route of the Mem-
phis, El Paso and Pacific Railroad survey, to or near the town of El Paso, and the main line of said road shall follow, as nearly as may be prac-
ticable, the old survey of the Memphis and El Paso road; also to con-
struct a branch road from Jefferson, in Marion county, in a northerly direction, to the main line designated as aforesaid, on the most prac-
ticable route.

Sec. 3. And be it further enacted, That the said corporation shall have the power, and it is hereby authorized to construct, use and main-
tain a railway and telegraph line from said point and branch road there-
of, as designated in the second section of this act; and to effect that ob-
ject the said company shall have power to purchase lands, or may accept any donations or grants of land, and any other property whatsoever; the said company shall also have the right to purchase and enter upon any lands or other property, and may issue in payment thereof the paid stock of the company; provided, the landholder or owner is willing to receive the same. The said company shall also have the right to connect their road with any other road chartered by the State of Texas, running to or in the direction of El Paso; provided, that said junction shall not be with the Southern Pacific Railroad, at a point east of the twenty-third degree of west longitude from Washington, and after such junction, the compa-
nies mutually agreeing, one common trunk road may be constructed to the western boundary of the State, when the stock of said company may become united. And the said company hereby incorporated may pur-
chase the rights, franchises and property of the Memphis, El Paso and Pacific Railroad Company, heretofore incorporated by this State, and also the rights, franchises and property of any other company incorporated by this or any other State, or by the United States or any territory, so that it may have its connections complete and continuous to the Atlantic on the east and the Pacific Ocean on the West.

Sec. 4. That the capital stock of said company shall be fixed by the board of directors at any sum not to exceed thirty millions of dollars, and shall consist of shares of one hundred dollars each, which shall be transferable in such manner as the by-laws of said
Laws of the State of Texas.company may provide. In all elections of officers of said company, each share of stock shall entitle the holder thereof to one vote, No right shall vest until one million of dollars of stock shall have been subscribed in good faith, and five per cent. thereof paid; and no sub-
scription of stock shall be valid and legal unless two per cent. there-
of is paid at the time of subscribing. The board of directors shall have the power to require full payment of all of said stock in such installments and at such times and in such manner as may be prescribed by the by-laws of said company.

Sec. 5. The persons named in the first section of this act, or any nine of them, shall meet in the city of Yew York within ninety days after the passage of this act, and temporarily organize said company by electing a president, vice-president, secretary and treasurer; the said persons shall, at the same time, provide for the opening of the books of subscription to the capital stock of said company, and when one million of dollars of stock shall have been subscribed, and five per cent. thereof paid, the president of said company shall notify the stockholders to meet at a time and place to be designated by him, when a permanent organization shall be had by electing a board of directors, to consist of not less than nine, a majority of whom shall constitute a quorum, who shall hold their offices for two years, and until their successors are duly elected and qualified; and the said directors shall elect a president and vice-president from their number; also a secretary, treasurer and such other officers as may be necessary. The said directors, at their first or any subsequent meeting, may make by-laws, rules and regulations for the management of the business and affairs of said company, not in-
consistent with the laws of this State or of the United States; provided, that the president of the road shall appoint the chief engineer; and provided, further, that due notice of the time and place of meeting for the temporary organization herein provided for, shall be given by publication for at least thirty days in one newspaper published in the city of New York, and in two newspapers published in Texas, one of which shall be at the city of Austin.

Sec. 6. And be it further enacted, That the right of way through the public lands of this State, along the line of said road, or the branch road aforesaid, be and the same is hereby granted to said company; and the right, power and authority are hereby con-
ferred upon said company to take from the public lands adjacent to the line of said railway, earth, timber, rock and other materials for the construction thereof; the said right of way is granted to said railway company to the extent of two hundred feet, in width where it passes over public lands, including all necessary grounds or sta-
tions, buildings, workshops, switches, side-tracks, turn-tables, and
Laws of the State of Texas.water stations, not to exceed forty acres at any one point. When the line of said road, or the Jefferson branch thereof, shall pass through the lands of private persons, the right of way is hereby secured to said company in accordance with the laws of this State; and the said com-
pany is also empowered, and the right and franchise are hereby granted to said company to cross other roads and to bridge all streams on said route, so as not to interrupt the navigation thereof.

Sec. 7. And be it further enacted, That the said company hereby incorporated shall construct and have in complete running order at least one hundred miles of said road, or the branch thereof, beginning at Jefferson, within two years after the passage of this act, and fifty miles each year thereafter, and in default thereof shall forfeit all rights under the provisions of this act.

Sec. 8. And be it further enacted, That the said company shall have the right to construct the branch road herein provided for to the main line, and thence on said main line in the direction of El Paso, or the said company may begin the work at a point on the eastern boundary of the State, and thence proceed to construct a road in the direction of the town of El Paso, at its option, as well as a telegraph upon said road so constructed; provided, however, that any portion of said road which has not been constructed within ten years after the passage hereof, as well as the franchises thereto, shall be forfeited to the State; provided, further, that no portion of said road constructed and in complete run-
ning order shall be forfeited, except what is provided for in this act; provided, further, that the branch road herein authorized shall not in-
tersect with the Southern Pacific Railroad east of the twenty-third de-
gree of longitude west from Washington.
Sec. 9. And be it further enacted, That this act shall be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXVII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Dallas Wire Suspension Bridge Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. K. P. Record, T. C. Jordan, W. H. Gaston, Sarah
Laws of the State of Texas.H. Cochrell, J. W. Haynes, J. W. Crowdus, and such other persons as they may associate with them, be and they are hereby created a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “Dallas Wire Suspension Bridge Company,” and as such may make contracts, sue and be sued, have a corporate seal, and may own such property, real and per-
sonal, as may be necessary to carry out the objects of this charter, not to exceed in value one hundred thousand dollars.

Sec. 2. That it shall be the duty of said company to build a good and safe wire suspension bridge across the Trinity river, at or within two hundred and fifty yards of a line drawn due west from the centre of the public square in the town of Dallas, Dallas county, Texas, and to construct a good and substantial causeway through the bottom on the west side of the said river; said bridge and causeway to be completed and open for public travel within two years from the passage of this act.

Sec. 3. That the immediate control and direction of the affairs of said company shall be vested in a board of not less than five directors; said board of directors shall elect from their own number a president, treasurer, and secretary, who shall perform such duties as shall be re-
quired by the company.

Sec. 4. That for the purpose of raising the necessary funds with which to build said bridge and causeway, the said company may issue and sell their bonds, which, when issued and sold, shall constitute a lien upon said bridge and causeway for the payment of the principal and interest thereof.

Sec. 5. That when said bridge and causeway shall be completed, said company are authorized to demand and receive from every person, non-
resident of Dallas county, crossing said bridge, or crossing their prop-
erty over the same, a toll not to exceed the following rates:
For every buggy and horse..................... $0 40
For every buggy or carriage and two horses................... 50
For every wagon and pair of horses or yoke of oxen........... 50
For each additional pair of horses or oxen...............20
For man and horse..................10
For each, head of loose horses, mules, jennets, jacks, or cattle.... 05

and from citizens of Dallas county, one-half of the above rates, except parties going to mill, public elections, or to church, who shall pass free; provided, that the said company shall have the right to regulate the crossing of persons and property over said bridge.

Sec. 6. That it shall be the duty of the County Court of Dallas county from time to time to examine said bridge, and whenever
Laws of the State of Texas.they shall consider the same unsafe for crossing, they may cause the gates thereof to be closed, and to remain closed until said company shall put said bridge in sufficient repair.

Sec. 7. That the gates of said bridge shall at all times, day and night, be open for passing of persons and property; and said company shall be responsible in damages for unreasonable delays, and for injuries to persons or property resulting from the bad condition of said bridge.

Sec. 8. That nothing herein contained shall divest any vested rights subsisting, by virtue of any charter or license, to keep a ferry; and that any private property used in carrying out the provisions of this bill shall be compensated for.

Sec. 9. That this charter of incorporation continue and remain in force for thirty years from and after the completion of said bridge, and that this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXVIII.

opener.salute: An Act supplemental to the Act to incorporate the Buffalo Bayou, Brazos and Colorado Railway Company, and to the other special Acts relating to said company.

div3.p:
Whereas, On the seventh July, 1868, “the road-bed, track, franchise, and chartered rights and privileges” of the Buffalo Bayou, Brazos and Colorado Railway Company were sold on executions issued on judg-
ments against said company; and on the twenty-fourth January, 1870, the railroad of said company from Harrisburg to Alleyton, and its franchise, rights, and other property appertaining thereto, were sold under the provisions of a mortgage or deed of trust made by said com-
pany on the first November, 1860, all of which appears of record; and

Whereas, the act of December 19, 1857, supplementary to and amendatory of an act to regulate railroad companies” provides that the purchasers at such sales, and their associates “shall be entitled to have and exercise all the powers, privileges, and franchises granted to” the company sold out “by its charter, or by virtue of the general laws of this State,” and “shall be deemed and taken
Laws of the State of Texas.to be the true owners of said charter and corporators under the same, and vested with all the powers, rights, privileges and benefits thereof;” and

Whereas, the purchasers at said sales, and their associates, have formed a new company under said old name, and have expended large sums of money in the reconstruction of said railroad, in the purchase and com-
pletion of the Columbus Tap Railroad, and the bridge of the Brazos Iron Bridge Company over the Brazos river at Richmond; and
Whereas, said new company desires to be distinguished by name from said “sold out” company, to consolidate its property, and to extend said line of railroad; therefore,

section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the new company heretofore known as the Buffalo Bayou, Brazos and Colorado Railway Company, referred to in the preamble of this act, shall be hereafter known by the corporate name of “The Galveston, Har-
risburg and San Antonio Railway Company,’ and may alter its seal to conform to its name; provided, that said new company shall be liable to the State of Texas for the debt of said “sold out” company, for loans made to the latter company from the special school fund, in the same manner and to the same extent as said “sold out” company was liable; and that said change of name shall in no respect impair or affect said liability, or the existing lien or mortgage of the State upon the railroad of said company as security for said loans. Also, provided, that said change of name shall in no respect impair or affect any of the obliga-
tions of said new company to other parties, or the obligations of other parties to said new company; all of which may be enforced by or against said new company under said new name.

Sec. 2. That said railroad company may avoid the sale of its railroad for its indebtedness to the State for loans from the special school fund, and for the non-payment of principal and interest, by the payment into the treasury of the State, on the first day of No-
vember, A. D. 1870, of six months’ interest on the aggregate amount due on account of said loans, principal and interest as said aggregate amount stood on the first day of May, A. D. 1870, and by the payment in addition, on said first day of November, of one per cent. upon said aggregate amount, to be applied towards the sinking fund provided for by existing laws in respect to said loans, and by continuing to pay into the treasury of the State six months’ interest and one per cent. on account of said sinking fund semi-
annually thereafter, to wit: on the first day of May and November, in each year; provided, that in case of failure to comply with any
Laws of the State of Texas.payment required under this section, the Governor shall sell the said road under the regulations provided in the law of August 13, 1856.

Sec. 3. That said new company is hereby authorized to extend the existing line of railroad owned and operated by said company from Columbus, in Colorado county, to San Antonio, in the county of Bexar, within four years from the passage of this act, and thence to a ter-
minus on the Bio Grande, by such route as the directors shall deem most feasible, with a branch from the most suitable point to New Braunfels, in Comal county, within four years from the passage of this act; or said new company may connect with any line of railroad that may be constructed or under construction to San Antonio or the Rio Grande, south of the latitude of the city of Austin and the Colorado river, in-
stead of building its own line beyond the point of such connection; and may build to and connect with any line of railroad that, may be constructed, or under construction, and designed to form part of any railroad line to the Pacific, south of the thirty-fifth parallel of latitude; nothing herein being so construed as to exclude said new company from the right to construct also, any part of the line up the Colorado valley, formerly designated by said “sold out” company as its route under the provisions of the eleventh section of the act of December 19, 1857; pro-
vided, that if the said road shall not be completed within the time speci-
fied in this section, then this charter shall be forfeited.

Sec. 4. That said new company may consolidate with its existing railroad the bridge built by the Brazos Iron Bridge Company over the Brazos river at Richmond, and the five miles of railroad, more or less, including side tracks, from the town of Alleyton to the town of Colum-
bus, built under the charter granted in the year 1860 to the Columbus Tap Railroad Company, including the bridge over the Colorado river at Columbus, together with all franchises, rights, fixtures and appurtenances of, or upon any of the same, and may construct and maintain telegraphs along its lines.

Sec. 5. That said new company may issue its bonds, under seal or otherwise, and secure the same by a mortgage or mortgages upon its said consolidated line of railroad, or any part of the same, and any such mortgage may be so expressed as to include and cover, as said company shall construct the same, the lines of railroad it may construct in extension of its existing line, together with all the franchises and rights, bridges, depots, fixtures, equipments, machin-
ery, and the appurtenances and property of said railroad, and of said company, of every kind, or any part thereof, whether con-
structed or acquired before or after the execution of said mortgage, and with provision for a sinking fund sufficient for the extinguish-
Laws of the State of Texas.ment at their maturity of the principal of the bonds secured thereby. That the amount of bonds that may, at any time, be outstanding under any such mortgage, shall not exceed twenty thousand dollars for each mile of single main track, with the necessary turn-outs, included in such mortgage, and completed and in running order. That all the bonds secured by any such mortgage shall be on an equality in respect to the benefits of the same, shall be of the same form and tenor, except that they may be of different dates, and for different amounts, and shall mature at the same time, in not more than fifty years from the date of those of said bonds which shall be first issued. That said bonds shall bear interest at such rates, not exceeding eight per cent. per annum, payable semi-annually; both principal and interest shall be payable in gold, or other lawful currency of the United States, at the places named in the bonds and coupons, and, with said mortgage or mortgages, may be otherwise in such form, and contain such stipulations not inconsistent with the provisions of this act, as the directors shall think proper to embody therein.

Sec. 6. That said new company may issue such other bonds, and secure them by other mortgage or mortgages, on its railroad, franchises and property, or any part of the same, subsequent and subject to the mortgages hereinbefore provided for, as the interests of said company may require. And any bonds lawfully issued by said new company may be disposed of by the directors on such terms as they shall think proper.

Sec. 7. That the issue of any of the bonds, and the execution of any mortgage provided for in the two preceding sections shall not impair, or in any way affect, the lien or mortgage held by the State upon the railroad, franchises, rights or property of said new company as security for loans made to said “sold out” company as aforesaid, or any of the rights of the State in respect to the same. And if any such mortgage is made whilst said lien or mortgage of the State exists, it shall be made expressly subject thereto.

Sec. 8. That in case it shall be made to appear to the Governor that there has not been issued upon said railroad the full quantity of six-
teen sections of land scrip for every mile of the same that was con-
structed and put in running order prior to the war of the late rebellion, in acordance with the provisions of the charter and of the general laws of the State, in force at the time, regulating railroads, there shall be issued to said new company said scrip to the amount of any such de-
ficiency, notwithstanding said railroad may not have been constructed and completed at the rate of twenty-five miles each year after the con-
struction of the first twenty-five miles, as provided in the act of Janu-
ary 30, 1854.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 9. That meetings of said new company and of the directors may, when desirable, be held at an office of said company in Boston, Massachusetts, as well as at the “principal office” of the company in Texas; provided, that the votes passed at meetings in Boston shall be, within thirty days therefrom, spread upon the records, which shall be kept at the “principal office” in Texas. That a majority of the directors and the president and treasurer shall not be required to reside in this State so long as the vice-president and assistant treasurer reside therein; and directors may vote by proxy under such regulations as the by-laws shall prescribe.

Sec. 10. That said new company may make a terminus of said rail-
road at the city of Houston, or change the present terminus from Har-
risburg to Houston, and for that purpose may acquire, by agreement with the owners, any part of the Houston Tap and Brazoria Railroad; and said company may make a terminus at the city of Galveston, arranging with any railroad running to Galveston for a third rail thereon, or other connection therewith, or to extend its own line thereto, if preferable.

Sec. 11. That said new company shall be entitled to the same or similar rights and relief, except State aid in bonds, or indorsement of, or guaranty of interest on bonds, granted to or provided for any other rail-
road company by the Legislature, and upon the same or similar terms and conditions, so far as such rights or relief are, in their character, applicable to said new company or its line, or lines of railroad.

Sec. 12. That nothing in this act shall be so construed as to deprive any party interested, of the right to disprove any assumed fact stated in the preamble; provided, that nothing in this act contained shall be construed as reviving or renewing any land grant to said company for road hereafter to be completed, which it does not possess by existing law.
Sec. 13. That this act shall take effect from its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXIX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate tire Texas Odd Fellows’ University and Orphans’ Home.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That T. T. Smothers, George Johnson, R. N. Blanford, William Mc-
Intosh, A. H. Wilson, C. A. Sterne, H. W. Hall, I. M. Zimmerman, Wm. Lambden, T. McCarty, G. I. Goodwin, H. Hardin, J. P. Mitchell, T. J. Beall, G. W. Castles, E. Littlefield, II. S. Newland, I. I. Kumbrough, T. D. Wilson, and Alexander McKee, and their successors, are hereby declared an aggregate corporation, under the corporate name and style of the “Texas Odd Fellows’ University and Orphans’ Home.”

Sec. 2. That said corporators or successors shall have the right of perpetual succession, for the purpose of governing, directing and con-
trolling the “Texas Odd Fellows’ University and Orphans’ Home,” un-
der the authority conferred by this act, or by any by-law, rule or reg-
ulation made by them that is not in conflict with any law of this State or the United States.

Sec. 3. That said corporation shall have the right to purchase and hold property, to alien and convey the same, to sue and be sued, and have a corporate seal with the following letters, T. O. F. U. & O. H., by which all their official acts shall be verified.
Sec. 4. That said institution shall be located at Bryan, in Brazos county; and that this act be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXX.

opener.salute: An. Act to authorize John J. Blankenship to erect a toll bridge over Tehuacana creek, in the county of McLennan, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That John J. Blankenship be, and he is hereby authorized and empowered to erect a toll bridge over Tehuacana Creek in the
Laws of the State of Texas.county of McLennan, where the public road from Waco to Springfield crosses the same, and that he be authorized and empowered to charge, receive and collect toll for crossing on said bridge, at the following rates, to-wit:
For every man and horse......................10
For every one horse vehicle...................20
For every two horse vehicle...................25
For every ox wagon and two yoke of oxen..............30
For every ox wagon and four to six yoke of oxen................ 50
For every two horse wagon............... 25
For every four to six horse wagon.............. 50
For every loose horse............ 05
For cattle, sheep, goats and hogs, per head............ 01

Sec. 2. That the right and privilege herein granted shall inure to the benefit of the said John J. Blankenship, his heirs and assigns for twenty years; provided, however, that in order to secure the privileges conferred by this bill, he shall, within twelve months from the passage of this act, erect and construct a good, safe and substantial bridge over the said Tehuacana Creek, at the crossing aforesaid, and shall keep the same in good repair; and in the event of any accident or casualty destroying said bridge, the said Blankenship shall reconstruct the same within twelve months from the date of such accident or casualty, otherwise the fran-
chise herein granted shall abate.
Sec. 3. That no bridge shall be permitted or allowed to collect toll, or he erected with the right so to do, for three miles above and below said Springfield crossing on said Tehuacana Creek.
Sec. 4. This act shall take effect and be in force from its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXXI.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the Harrison County Agricultural and Mechan-
ical Association.

div3.p:
Section. 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That N. V. Board, M. J. Hall, John T. Mills, Alexander Pope, E. P. Gregg, B. H. Martin, Thomas J. Whaley, B. M.
Laws of the State of Texas.Baldwin, B. F. Perry, J. H. Callaway, George Lane, E. Greer, W. W. Heartsill, W. G. Barrett, B. PI. Motley, A. P. Hinton, T. J. Coleman, T. W. Winston, O. Knox, A. M. Burnham, PI. J. Nichols, J. B. William-
son, E. Iv. Taylor, Thomas F. Purnell, Dushee McKay and James Tur-
ner, and their associates and successors, be and they are hereby created a body corporate and politic, under the name and title of the Harrison county Agricultural and Mechanical Association, with the capacity in said corporate name to make contracts; to have succession and a common seal; to make by-laws for their government and regulation; to sue and be sued; to plead and be impleaded; to grant and receive, and generally to do and perform all such acts and things as may be necessary and proper for the fulfillment of its obligations, or maintenance of its rights, consistent with the Constitution of the State.
Sec. 2. Said association is hereby empowered to purchase and hold such real estate as may be necessary (not to exceed six hundred and forty acres) to carry out the purposes of said association.

Sec. 3. The capital stock of said association shall consist of all its property, real and personal, and shall be divided off into shares of twenty-five dollars each: each share entitling the owner thereof to one vote, by himself or proxy, at all meetings of said association; said shares to be deemed personal estate, and as such subject to levy and sale for the individual debt of the owner, and shall be transferable by any con-
veyance in writing, recorded by the secretary in the books of the society, in such manner as the by-laws may provide; and no sale of said stock shall be deemed valid, so as to entitle the purchaser to the title as against any subsequent purchasers, unless the same is recorded or presented for record with the secretary within thirty days from the purchase.

Sec. 4. The immediate government and direction of the affairs of said association shall be vested in a board of not less than nine directors, a president and vice president, who shall be ex-officio memcers of the board of directors, a secretary, treasurer, and such other officers as shall be necessary to the transaction of its business; the president, vice presi-
dent and directors to be chosen annually, at the regular meeting of the stockholders and the other officers chosen by the board of directors.

Sec. 5. Said association shall hold at least one fair in each year, at such time as they may select; and shall publish, in at least one news-
paper in the State, a list of premiums to be offered, at least one month before the holding of said meeting or fair.

Sec. 6. All medals or tokens awarded at such fair shall be engraved as follows: “First Premium for —, H. C. A. & M.
Laws of the State of Texas.Association;” provided, however, if they prefer, said society may pay its premiums in money.

Sec. 7. Not exceeding twenty-five per cent. of the value of the prem-
iums offered shall be exacted by said association from owners for the privilege of competing.

Sec. 8. Said association shall have power, at any regular meeting of the stockholders, to adopt such by-laws, rules and regulations, for its government, as they may deem, advisable; and until such are adopted, the printed by-laws and regulations of the Harrison county Agricultural and Mechanical Association, as it existed at the passage of this act, shall govern; provided, however, that nothing therein conflict with the pro-
visions of this act or the laws of the State.
Sec. 9. Said association shall have and keep a seal, engraved thus: “H. C. A. & M. Association.”
Sec. 10. The domicile of said association shall be at the town of Marshall.
Sec. 11. This act to take effect and be in force from and after is passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXXII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate Pennington College.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That a school of learning, consisting of male and female departments, be and the same is hereby established in the county of Trinity, to be known as Pennington College.

Sec. 2. That William H. Denney, Daniel Dailey, Thomas Nel-
son, William Cox, J. T. Wortham, Washington Holley and John Scharhorongh, and their associates, are hereby created and declared to be a body corporate and politic, by the name and style of the Trustees of Pennington College; and by said name and style they shall have succession, sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded in all courts whatever in like manner and as fully as natural persons; and by said corporate name and style shall be capable of contracting and being contracted with, and shall have the power of acquiring, by purchase, donation, of otherwise, property, both real, personal and mixed, and dispose of the same in any manner whatever for the
Laws of the State of Texas.benefit of said college: to construct all necessary buildings for said insti-
tution; to establish a preparatory department; to organize, establish and control a separate department and school for females, and such depend-
ent institutions as they shall deem necessary in furtherance of the ob-
ject of this act; to hare the management of the finances; the privilege of electing their own officers; of appointing all necessary committees, and to act and do all things whatsoever for the benefit of the said college, in as ample a manner as any person or body politic or corporate may or can do by law.

Sec. 3 That said trustees shall have power of prescribing the course of studies to be pursued by the students, and of framing and enacting all such ordinances and by-laws as shall appear to them necessary for the good government of said college and for their own proceedings; provided, that the same be in acordance with the Constitution of the United States and the State of Texas.

Sec. 4. The trustees shall appoint a president and the professors, who shall be styled the faculty of Pennington College, which faculty shall have power of enforcing the ordinances and by-laws adopted by the trustees for the government of the students, by rewarding or censuring them and finally by suspending such of them as, after repeated admoni-
tions, shall continue disobedient or refractory, until a determination of a quorum of trustees can be had; but it shall only be in the power of a quorum of the trustees to expel a student from college.

Sec. 5. That the trustees shall be empowered by the faculty of said college to grant or confer such degree or degrees in the arts and sciences, to the students of said college and other persons worthy thereof, as are usually granted and conferred in other colleges, and to give certificates thereof or diplomas, signed by them and sealed with the common seal of the trustees of said college, (which seal they are hereby authorized and empowered to have and use,) to authenticate and perpetuate the memory of such graduations.
Sec. 6. That whenever any vacancy may occur in the board of trustees, either by death, resignation, or otherwise, such vacancy or vacancies shall be filled by the selection of the remaining trustees.

Sec. 7. That all necessary officers of said college shall be appointed by a majority of the board of trustees, viz: the faculty or minor officers; and that officers shall always be subject to be removed by the appointing power, for cause.
Sec. 8. That the salaries of all officers connected with the college shall be fixed by a majority of the board of trustees.

Sec. 9. That Pennington College shall be purely literary and scien-
tific, and that the students of all religions shall enjoy equal advantages.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 10. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXXIII.

opener.salute: To prohibit the sale or otherwise disposing of spirituous or vinous liquors within two miles of Pennington College, in Trinity county, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the sale of all intoxicating liquors, including all vinous, fermented or medicated liquors, (except for medical or sacramental purposes) within two miles of Pennington College, in Trinity county, Texas, is hereby prohibited; and that the furnishing or giving away of any intoxicating liquors or drinks to any student or students of said college is hereby pro-
hibited.

Sec. 2. That any person or persons violating the provisions of the foregoing section, shall be fined in any sum not less than ten nor more than one hundred dollars for each violation of the same, before any court of competent jurisdiction.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXXIV.

opener.salute: An Act authorizing the construction of a ship channel from Bolivar Point to the City of Houston.

div3.p:
Whereas, The late Constitutional Convention of this State, on the twenty-third day of January, A. D. 1869, passed a declaration entitled “A declaration incorporating the Ship Channel Company, from Bolivar Point to Houston,” which said declaration purported to create A. S. Richardson, W. J. Hutchins, T. H. Mundine, John Shearne, T. W. House, R. O. Love, W. M. Rice, A. Groesbeck, J. R. Morris, H. R. Allen, S. Harper, and their associates, a body
Laws of the State of Texas.corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “Buffalo Bayou Ship Channel Company;” and

Whereas, the, parties named in said declaration and their associates have organized as a company, in accordance with the terms of the said declaration, and have done numerous acts towards the construction of the ship channel contemplated by the said declaration; and
Whereas, doubts exist concerning the force and effect in law of the said act of the said Constitutional Convention; and

Whereas, the construction of a ship channel as contemplated by the said declaration will greatly promote the commercial, agricultural, manu-
facturing, and other interests of the State of Texas; therefore,

Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That A. S. Richardson, John Shearne, T. W. House, R. O. Love, A. Groesbeck, J. R. Morris, H. R. Allen, and their associates, be and the same are hereby created a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “Buffalo Bayou Ship Channel Company,” with authority in said corporate name and capacity, to contract, sue and be sued; to plead and be impleaded; to acquire real and personal property, by gift or purchase, and to sell, grant, mortgage, or alienate the same; to borrow money, and to issue its bonds with interest warrants attached thereto; to make by-laws for its own government; to have succession, and a common seal; and generally to do and perform all such acts and things as may be necessary to, proper for, or incidental to, the carrying out of its obliga-
tions, the maintenance of its rights and privileges, and the accomplish-
ment of the objects of the company, in accordance with this act, and not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of the State of Texas.

Sec. 2. That said company are hereby authorized to form, construct, own and maintain a ship channel from any point at or within the corpor-
ate limits of the city of Houston, through Buffalo Bayou, deepening, straightening and widening the same, and through the waters connecting said Buffalo Bayou with the Gulf of Mexico at Bolivar Channel, deepen-
ing and removing the obstructions thereof, to the Gulf of Mexico at Boli-
var Channel, (including the construction of all locks, gates or dams, that may be requisite,) so as to make said ship channel of such continuous depth, width and extent, as may be essential for the purposes of foreign and domestic trade and commerce, and to build, own and possess such ship basins within or near the corporate limits of the city of Houston, in such numbers, depth and capacity, as may be requisite for the purposes of the company, with all slips, wharves, docks, buildings and machinery,
Laws of the State of Texas.necessary or in any wise pertaining thereto; and the said company are furthermore authorized to build, construct and possess, such steamboats, tug-boats, dredge-boats, barges, tools, machinery, and buildings, or any other property, of any and every kind whatever, as may be necessary to, convenient for, or adapted to the prosecution, management and accom-
plishment of this act and the purposes of foreign and domestic commerce.

Sec. 3. That said company, in order to accomplish the purposes above specified, are hereby empowered to perform such dredging, and make such excavations, enlarge such streams, and deepen such channels, cut off such bends, and remove such obstructions in Buffalo Bayou, and the bays and waters connecting Buffalo Bayou with the Gulf of Mexico at Bolivar Channel, as may seem desirable and necessary to build said ship basins and construct said ship channel; and it shall be lawful for said company to appropriate and use such lands in the several bayous, streams, gulfs, and waters, or on the banks thereof, or lying contiguous thereto, ass-
may be requisite for the specific purposes of this act, making compensa-
tion to the several owners thereof as may be agreed upon by the parties and the company, and if unable to agree, then in accordance with the general railroad laws of the State, and as provided therein, whenever so using or appropriating said lands.

Sec. 4. That the capital stock of said company shall be one million dollars, (including all its property, real and personal, franchises and rights to property,) to be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, five per cent. to be paid at the time of subscription, and the remainder in installments of five per cent. as often as it may be called for, after giving-
thirty days’ notice of said call in some newspaper published in the city of Houston. Such subscriptions, upon failure of the payment thereof, may be enforced by said company in any court having jurisdiction in the State, or may be sold at public auction, after twenty days’ public notice given, the delinquent being liable in the full amount for all deficiencies between the amount so received at the sale thereof and the unpaid balance on his subscription, and for all proper charges and interest thereon. Said shares of capital stock shall be deemed personal property, and shall be transferable under such rules and regulations as may be provided for in the by-laws of the company. Nevertheless, the board of directors shall have authority to dispose of the shares in its capital stock in such manner and on such terms as they may deem most conducive to the interest of the company and the fulfillment of the objects of this act: and shall be, furthermore, authorized to commence operations whenever five hundred shares shall have been taken.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 5. That the company may receive in payment for its shares or bonds, the work of contractors done, hire of agents, laborers, and em-
ployes, materials or machinery furnished in constructing the enterprise, city or town lots, houses, lands, and real or personal property of any kind whatever, bonds of the city of Houston, or any other corporate city or town, or of any county within the limits of the State; and such corporate city or town or county is hereby authorized to subscribe for said stock or bonds, and to issue its bonds for the same. Said property so subscribed shall be at such valuation as may be determined upon between the parties and the company. Each share shall be entitled to one vote, either in per-
son or by proxy, and all dividends shall be paid at the principal office in the city of Houston, but no dividend shall, at any time, be declared im-
pairing the capital stock.

Sec. 6. The management of the said company shall be confided to a board of nine directors, to be elected annually by the stockholders. For the purposes of organization and commencement of the enterprise, the corporators named in the first section of this act shall constitute the first board of directors, to serve one year, or until their successors are duly elected. The board of directors, when duly constituted, shall elect their own officers at their first meeting, and shall have authority to fill any vacancies that may arise in the board from death, resignation, or other-
wise. During the intervals between the regular election by the stock-
holders, the said board (five of whom shall constitute a quorum) shall manage and control the business affairs and property of the company, and shall keep, or cause to be kept, full and accurate records of the trans-
actions of the company, of all receipts and expenditures made, and of all property, real or personal, held, received or transferred, and shall cause such records, or a synopsis of the same, to be submitted, at each annual meeting of the stockholders.

Sec. 7. That whenever said company shall have made snch ship channel navigable through Red Fish Bar and Morgan’s Point for ves-
sels drawing six feet of water, it shall be authorized to impose and collect of all vessels passing through that portion of said chan-
nel cut through Morgan’s Point, toll at the rate of ten cents, each way, per ton measurement; and when said company shall have made such ship channel navigable through Red Fish Bar and Morgan’s Point for vessels drawing eight feet of water, it shall be authorized to impose and collect of all vessels passing through that portion of said channel cut through Morgan’s Point, additional tolls at the rate of ten cents, each way, per ton measurement of such vessels; and when said company shall have made said channel navigable from the Gulf of Mexico at Bolivar Channel to the city of Houston, for
Laws of the State of Texas.vessels drawing nine feet of water, it shall have the right to impose and collect of all vessels passing through that portion of said channel, be-
tween Morgan’s Point and the city of Houston, or stopping at any of the points of landing between Morgan’s Point and the city of Houston, addi-
tional tolls at the rate of ten cents, each way, per ton measurement, of such vessels passing through the channel, or any portion thereof, made by said company; provided, that the whole amount of tolls upon vessels passing through the entire length of said channel from the Gulf of Mex-
ico, at Bolivar Channel, to the city of Houston, shall never exceed thirty cents, each way, per ton measurement. And should the city of Houston cede, transfer, lease or grant to said company its rights and privileges of imposing and collecting toll and wharfage of all vessels navigating Buf-
falo Bayou within its corporate limits, then said company are empowered hereby to impose and collect such rates of toll and wharfage as they may determine upon; the toll, however, not in any case to exceed in the whole amount, and including all toll collected, forty cents, each way, per ton measurement of any vessel.

Sec. 8. That if any person or persons shall wilfully and maliciously obstruct, impair, or destroy said ship channel, or ship basins, or any part thereof, or injure the property of the company, such person or persons so offending shall be punished, when presented by indictment of law, and shall also be liable to action for damages by said company, or any person or persons whatsoever that may suffer injury in person or prop-
erty from said obstructions, and for full amount of damages that may be occasioned thereby.

Sec. 9. The organization, of the “Buffalo Bayou Ship Channel Com-
pany” heretofore entered into at the city of Houston, in accordance with the terms of the aforesaid declaration of the Convention, is hereby legal-
ized; and all the acts and contracts of the company done and entered into, in accordance with the aforesaid declaration, are hereby declared to be of full force and effect; provided, nothing herein contained shall be con-
strued as making valid any land grant to said Buffalo Bayou Ship Chan-
nel Company.

Sec. 10. That Eugene Pilot, H. E. Perkins, T. H. Scanlan, J. G. Tracy, E. W. Cave, J. W. McDonald, and Peter Gabel are hereby added and created the associate incorporators with those named in section first, with the same duties, powers, and rights as those mentioned in this act.

Sec. 11. The franchise, rights, privileges, and immunities herein granted shall continue to be enjoyed by said “Buffalo Bayou Ship Chan-
nel Company” for the period of fifty years from the twenty-third day of January, A. D. 1869.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 12. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXXV

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the North Texas Manufacturing Company.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That James P. Dumas, Jesse W. Bell, Eliza Emberson, John C. Richards, Robert A. King and James M. Wilson, and their associates, are hereby created and established a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “North Texas Manufacturing Company,” with capacity in said corporate name to make contracts; to sue and be sued; to plead and be impleaded; to grant and receive; to have succession and a common seal; to make by-laws and regulations for the government and regulation of its affairs, and to do and perform all such acts and things as may be necessary or proper for, or incident to, the fulfillment of its obligations, or the maintenance of its rights under this act, and consistent with the constitution; and this charter shall exist for thirty years.

Sec. 2. Said company is hereby invested with the rights, powers and authority to own, erect, establish and maintain and operate a cotton and wool manufactory, separately or conjointly, in the county of Grayson, with a capital stock of five hundred thousand dollars, to be invested in the purchase of lands, buildings, machinery, mills, looms, spindles, etc., together with the rights to establish such mills and shops as may be necessary to the success of said company, and to invest so much of the above capital stock in labor, goods, cotton, wool, chattels and produce, as they may deem expedient in the prosecution of said enterprise.

Sec. 3. The parties named in this act are hereby appointed commis-
sioners and invested with right of forming and organizing said company, and generally of exercising the powers of directors until directors are chosen, as hereinafter provided.

Sec. 4. When one hundred thousand dollars of said capital stock has been subscribed upon the books of said company, the com-
missioners shall proceed to organize said company by calling the stockholders together for that purpose. The capital of said company,
Laws of the State of Texas.to consist of all its real and personal franchise, and rights to property, shall be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each. Each share shall entitle the party owning it to one vote by himself or proxy. Said shares shall be deemed personal estate, and shall be transferable in such manner as the directors may direct. A record of such transfers shall be kept in a book kept for that purpose.

Sec. 5. The government of said company shall be vested in a board of directors, to consist of nine persons, who shall elect one of their number president of said company. No person shall be eligible to the office of director unless he is an owner of five or more shares of said company, Five of said directors, including the president, shall constitute a quorum, with all the powers of a full body. The directors shall hold their office for one year, and shall have power to fill any vacancy that may occur in their number by non-election, death or otherwise, and may appoint a secretary, treasurer, superintendent or any other officers or agents that may be necessary, and prescribe and require bonds of such officers or agents for the faithful discharge of their duties; and they shall have the right to pass such by-laws and regulations that may be necessary in the proper conduct of their business; they shall keep or cause to be kept, accurate records of all meetings of the board of directors and company, which shall always be open to the inspection of the stockholders, together with such other books as may be necessary, to show at all times the re-
ceipts, expenditures and disbursements of said company. The board may be convened at any time by the president, and in his absence a president pro tem may be appointed by the directors.

Sec. 6. The board of directors shall have the power to appoint an executive committee, composed of two of the directors and the president, who shall be invested with all of the powers of the board of directors, and do and perform all of the general business of said company between the meetings of the board of directors, and their proceedings shall be subject to the ratification of the directory. All sales, conveyances, con-
tracts, purchases, together with other business operations of the com-
pany, shall be signed by the president and countersigned by the treasurer or secretary, as the company may require, under the seal of the company, with the approval of the board or the executive committee. Said com-
mittee shall remain in office for one year, subject to removal by the board of directors.

Sec. 7. The books of said company shall be opened publicly for subscription to the stock of said company, upon such terms as the commissioners shall determine will be for the best interest of the company; and any agreement in writing, by which any person or
Laws of the State of Texas.persons shall become a subscriber to the stock of said, company, may be enforced against him according to its terms; and if any subscriber shall fail to pay any installment called for or any amount due upon his or her share or shares, and called for by the directors or executive commiteee within fifteen days from the date said installment or amount due is re-
quired to be paid, the directors or executive committee may sell at public auction and transfer to the purchaser the share or shares of such delin-
quent; and if the proceeds of sale shall not be sufficient to pay the amount due, with cost of selling and interest, such delinquent shall be held responsible and liable for the remainder due the company; and if the proceeds exceed the amount due the company, with interest and charges deducted, said delinquent shall be entitled to the surplus.

Sec. 8. Said company may acquire real estate by purchase or donation, which, when acquired, may form a part of the capital, or when disposed of to aid in the construction of mills and prosecuting the business of the company under this charter.

Sec. 9. Each, subscriber who may invest capital or property of any kind in the stock of said “North Texas Manufacturing Company,” and a holder of the same, shall at all times receive the dividend, if any, when declared upon said stock; but should the directors or stockholders deem it the true interest of the company to invest the profits or dividends in extending their manufacturing operations instead of distributing them among the stockholders, their action in premises shall be binding upon the minority; and should any stockholder, at any time, be displeased with the company, or wish to withdraw from it, or dispose of his interest, or require a distribution of dividends, or otherwise impede the progress and operations of said company, he or she shall not be permitted to in-
stitute legal proceedings against the company to adjust his individual rights, or in any wise to impede the progress of said company, unless sanctioned by a majority of the stockholders in the same; but is per-
mitted and required to dispose of his interest, and he or she so selling shall henceforth be exonerated from any loss said company may sustain, and be debarred from any future profits said stock may realize.

Sec. 10. Each shareholder in the capital stock of this company is hereby made liable to the company for the amount so subscribed for by him or her and due said company, to be collected as provided in the seventh section of this act; provided, that no stock or share-
holder shall be responsible or liable for any other debts or contracts made and entered into by the president of agent of said company not within the legitimate and bona fide business operations of said company, but shall be liable in proportion to the amount of his or
Laws of the State of Texas.her stock, only for the bona fide debts of said company in prosecuting the works and carrying into effect the true interests and intention of the company, in accordance with the provisions of this act, and said liabili-
ties shall be assessed, adjudged and collected in the event of failure, dis-
solution or loss, pro rata upon each stockholder, in proportion to the amount of stock* book of said company shall be the true criterion by which the liability of each stockholder is to be ascertained.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXXVI.

opener.salute:
An Act in relation to the “Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway Com-
pany,” late Union Pacific Railway Company, Southern branch.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway Company, a corporation authorized by Congress to construct a railway into the Indian Territory, shall have the right to extend its railroad, with its present gauge, together with its telegraph lines, from some convenient point on Red River, be-
tween Preston and Doaksville, where its road shall cross from the Indian Territory into and through the State of Texas, in the general direction of Waco and Austin, to the Rio Grande, with a view to extending the same to Camargo and the city of Mexico; and also the right to construct a branch road from a point at or near its crossing of Red River west-
wardly, to connect with the road of the Houston and Texas Central Rail-
road Company; and that said company shall have the right of way, two hundred feet in width, through all public lands, with the right to take such rock, timber, earth and other material as may be needed in con-
structing its road and branches.
* thus, in original.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, In the event said company shall complete fifty miles of its railway in the State of Texas, within three years, and shall extend its road from some point on Red River to the Colorado river, at or near the city of Austin, within six years from and after the passage of this act, then the said State agrees to exempt, and does hereby exempt from all taxation, whether State,
Laws of the State of Texas.county or municipal, the railroad of said company and its appurtenances of every description; provided, that such exemption shall only operate from the passage of this act, and until the period of two years shall have elapsed from the completion of such railroad to said city, and that there-
after said company shall, in lieu of all taxes of every description what-
ever, pay into the treasury of the State, two per cent. per annum upon the earnings of its road in Texas.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That the said company in construct-
ing, extending and operating its railroad and branches, shall have and exercise, and are hereby invested with all the rights, powers, privileges and immunities granted by its acts of incorporation and amendments thereto, so far as the same may be applicable to this State, and not in-
consistent with the Constitution thereof, together with all the rights, powers, privileges, benefits and immunities conferred by all general laws now existing, or that hereafter may be passed by the Legislature of the State of Texas, in relation to railroad corporations, in same manner and to the same extent as if incorporated by this State; provided, the said company shall keep an office within the State.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That the said company shall have the right to purchase, sell, lease, join stocks, unite or consolidate with any connecting railroad company, by and with the approval and consent of a majority, in interest, of the stockholders in each company, and to ac-
quire and merge into itself all or any part of the property, rights, and privileges and franchises of such other company, upon such terms and conditions as may be agreed upon by their respective boards of directors.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, Inasmuch as said company has not solicited special assistance in any form from the State, and only seeks not to be put into a more disadvantageous position than any other like cor-
poration, it is hereby stipulated, and the faith of the State is pledged that no railway corporation subsidized by the State, and authorized to con-
struct a line of railway in the same general direction with the line of said company, shall construct any part of its railway within twenty miles of any part of so much of the line of said company as may be completed and in actual use, without the written consent of said company, on the pen-
alty of forfeiting to said company the one-half of whatever State aid it may have obtained, or may obtain, for such part of its road as shall be constructed within the limits named, the said half to be delivered free of all cost to said company, and of exemplary damages; provided, that when such railway corporation shall cross or intersect said last mentioned line at some one point specified in its charter, thirty
Laws of the State of Texas.miles of the line of such corporation, extending each way from the point of intersection, shall be exempt from the operation of this section; and provided, further, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to a line of road to Toe constructed on a direct line from Fulton, in Arkan-
sas, or by way of Jefferson, in Marion county, direct to the cities of Aus-
tin and San Antonio, to the Rio Grande, at or near Laredo.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That this act shall be taken notice of as if it were a public and general statute; shall take effect from its pass-
age, and shall be and continue in force for fifty years.

div3.head: CHAPTER XXXVII.

opener.salute: An Act to Incorporate the Germania Saving, Trust and Exchange Company.

div3.p:
Section. 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That P. Gabel, E. Pilot, J. Binz, G. Loeffler, F. Mohl, Theo. Oswald and C. Fink and their associates, are hereby incorporated as a company for the purpose of: transacting a general exchange, trust, savings and deposit business; which said company shall be known as “The Germania Saving, Trust and Exchange Company,” and that the incorporators, their asso-
ciates and successors, shall enjoy continuous succession; and by their cor-
porate name shall be capable in law of suing and being sued, pleading and being impleaded, in all the courts of this State; of purchasing, hold-
ing, pledging and receiving in pledge; of transfering and conveying prop-
erty of all descriptions; of making loans and borrowing moneys to the extent of the capital authorized to be employed; of receiving on deposit all sums of money not less than ten dollars; of acting, whenever required, in the capacity of a trust company, being capable in law and in equity, of executing all such trusts as may be performed by an individual trustee; to have and use a common seal, which may be altered at will; to make and adopt, revise and amend, such by-laws, rules and regulations as in their judgment may be necessary to the successful organization and future management of the business of said company; and generally do any act within the scope of this charter, not at variance with the Constitution and laws of the State.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 2. The capital stock of said company shall be one hundred thou-
sand dollars, which may hereafter, by a vote of the directory, be increased to the sum of five hundred thousand dollars. The said stock shall be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, on which there shall be paid at the time of subscribing not less than twenty dollars per share.
