icies, and do all other acts necessary in carrying on such a business; to charge and receive such premiums, commissions and compensations for the risks taken, and the business done, as the president and directors may deem just; to loan money on bottomry and respondentia security at marine interest, to deal in bullion, stocks and public securities; to make loans on real estate, stocks and personal property, discount notes and acceptances, buy and sell bills of exchange, receive money on trust and deposit, and to use its capital and funds in any other lawful manner.

Sec. 4. That the affairs of said company shall be under the control and management of a board of not less than seven directors, each of whom shall be the owner of not less than fifty shares of stock in said company. A majority of said directors shall form a quorum for the transaction of business, and they shall be elected at the annual meeting of the stockholders, to be held on the second Wednesday in January of each and every year, after the passage of this act, by a majority of the stockholders present. Vacancies in
Laws of the State of Texas.said board may be filled by the remaining members thereof, until the next annual election shall take place. The corporation shall not be dissolved by the failure of a regular meeting or election, but the directors for the time being shall call a meeting for an election at an early day, giving twenty days’ public notice of the time and place of such meeting, and shall continue in office until a new board be elected and organized; and it shall be the duty of a newly elected board to meet and organize within ten days after their election. Until the first annual meeting of the stockholders, the persons named in the first section of this act shall constitute a board of directors, with power to elect from their own num-
ber a president and vice-president, and to perform every act within the powers hereby conferred upon the president and directors of said com-
pany.

Sec. 5. That in all elections, and upon all questions arising in a meeting of the stockholders, the vote shall be by ballot; and each stock-
holder shall be entitled to one vote for every share of stock he may hold in said company, and may vote in person or by proxy. To form a quorum to transact business, a majority of all the stock must be present or repre-
sented at the meeting.

Sec. 6. That the board of directors shall elect from among their own number a president of the company, and a vice-president. The said president and directors shall have authority to adopt a by-law, declaring and reserving a lien on the stock of any stockholder indebted to the company, and to adopt all such other rules, regulations and by-laws, not in contravention of the Constitution and laws of the State, and to ap-
point all such, subordinate officers as they may deem necessary for the proper management of the affairs of the company.
Sec. 7. That the principal office of said company shall be in the city of Galveston, and the company may establish such branch offices and agencies as its business may require.
Sec. 8. That said company shall be authorized to commence business under this act, whenever one hundred thousand dollars of its stock shall have been taken, and fully paid up in cash.
Sec. 9. That this act shall take effect from and after its passage, and continue in force for fifty years.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXVI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Allemania Association of the town of La Grange, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That E. Richers, G. Pauli, J. Schuhmacher, H. Scholz, D. Hans, A. Brandt, A. Prause, J. Wertz, C. Kellner, M. Praetorius, W. Steinle, P. Sassna, and their associates and successors, be and they are hereby consti-
tuted a body corporate and politic, for the promotion of morals, benevo-
lence and encouragement of musical and dramatical science, under the name and style of “Allemania,” and by that name may buy, hold, enjoy, sell, convey and alienate property, real and personal, and by the afore-
said name may sue and be sued, defend and be defended, plead and be impleaded, in any court of law or equity in this State; provided, that the property of said association shall not exceed at any time the sum of twenty thousand ($20,000) dollars.

Sec. 2. That the aforesaid association shall have power and make such a constitution and by-laws as they may deem necessary for their own government, not contrary to the Constitution and laws of this State and the United States of America, and may elect from their own body the officers necessary for conducting the business of said association.

Sec. 3. That the aforesaid association shall have the right to give musical and dramatic entertainments, free from taxation, in order to enable them to carry out their objects as stated in section one.

Sec. 4. That said corporation shall have a common seal, and may alter or change the same as they may deem proper, and in general have and exercise all such rights, privileges and immunities as by law are incident thereto or necessary for corporations of a similar character.

Sec. 5. That the privileges, immunities and franchises of this cor-
poration shall expire, unless renewed within thirty years.
Sec. 6. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXVII.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the Screwmen’s Benevolent Association of Gal-
veston.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. V. Riley, F. Marlow, J. Pentney, M. Burns, W. Maggson, O. Monahan, P. L. Lapre, B. Dobson, T. Benson, J. Bush, A. Munn, T. Carrigan, and their associates and successors are hereby constituted and declared a body corporate and politic, for charitable purposes, under the name and style of the Screwmen’s Benevolent Association, of the city of Galveston, Texas, and by that name shall have succession and a com-
mon seal; shall be capable of suing and being sued; of receiving dona-
tions, legacies, bequests and devises; of purchasing, holding, leasing, sell-
ing, or otherwise disposing of any estate, real, personal or mixed, and of receiving and disbursing the rents, profits, income and interest of such estate; provided, the said estates do never exceed the value of one hun-
dred thousand dollars. The money arising from the sale, lease, aliena-
tion, employment, or disposal of said estates, shall be applied to the uses, ends and purposes of said association, according to the rules and regula-
tions which may be established by the said association, in its constitution or by-laws.

Sec. 2. That the capital stock of said association shall be fifty thou-
sand dollars, divided into shares of twenty dollars each, with the privilege of increasing said capital stock to one hundred thousand dollars. The officers of said association shall be such as said association shall declare by its constitution and by-laws.

Sec. 3. That said association shall have power to make, establish and enforce such by-laws and regulations as it may deem proper, not incon-
sistent with this act and the Constitution and laws of the United States or of this State; for alienating, purchasing, leasing, holding, or otherwise appropriating or disposing of the estates, subscriptions, donations, fines, legacies, or any other property belonging to said association, or in which it is in any manner interested, or any part of the same; for the govern-
ment and management of its affairs, and generally for directing, con-
trolling, or closing all matters or concerns of every kind of said associa-
tion.
Sec. 4. That this act shall take effect from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXVIII.

opener.salute:
An Act to amend “An Act to incorporate Herman’s University,” ap-
proved January 27, 1844, as amended by An Act passed April 11, 1846.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Theo. Koesler, George Pfeuffer, F. Morcan, L. Kessler, I. I. Gross, F. J. Lindheimer, George Weber, G. Bodeman, Louis Klappenbach, all of Comal county, be and they are hereby constituted and declared to be, from and after the passage of this act, a body corporate, by the name of “Herman’s University;” and as such they and their successors are au-
thorized to hold property, real, personal and mixed; to sue and be sued, and generally to do any and everything not repugnant to this act of in-
corporation, nor to the Constitution and laws of the United States and the State of Texas.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the above named corporators are hereby authorized to organize a stock company with a capital not to exceed two hundred thousand dollars, divided into shares of twenty-
five dollars each. As soon as a sufficient amount of shares are taken, the said corporators shall call a meeting of the shareholders to elect a board of trustees for the said university, not to exceed twelve nor to be less than seven, whereof a majority shall form a quorum with powers to act. They shall have the right to elect one of their own number president of the said university, and appoint such other officers and professors as may be necessary for said university, and they shall fill va-
cancies in their own body, and pass by-laws and regulations for the gov-
ernment of themselves and said university; they shall provide a seal for the said university, which, with the signature of the president and sec-
retary, shall be evidence of their acts.

Sec. 3. The said trustees shall call once every year a regular meet-
ing of the stockholders of the said university, at which meeting by-laws for the said company may be passed or amended and trustees elected. No new stock shall be issued unless authorized by a regular meeting of the stockholders. Special meetings of the stockholders may be called by the trustees when required. At all meetings of the stockholders each share is entitled to one vote.

Sec. 4. That of the trustees elected at the first meeting of the
Laws of the State of Texas.stockholders, one-half shall be elected for two years, and the balance for one year, so that one-half of the board of trustees is elected annually.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That the trustees shall establish the necessary preparatory schools, and shall have the right to establish four faculties, one theological, one judicial, one medical and one philosophical, and shall have the right to prescribe the course of studies which shall be pursued; and they are hereby empowered to grant such degrees as are usually granted by similar institutions in the United States.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That no religious test or qualification of any kind whatsoever shall be requisite in order to become a trustee, professor, instructor or student in said university, and the theological faculty shall never be styled by the name of any particular religious con-
fession or sect.
Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That the land, public buildings, and other property belonging to the said “Herman’s University,” are hereby declared to be free from any kind of public tax.

Sec. 8. The said university shall be located at a place to be desig-
nated by the shareholders thereof, but after being once located shall not be moved into any other county without the majority of all the share-
holders consenting.

Sec. 9. Be it further enacted. That the right, title and interest of a certain league of land granted to said university by the Republic of Texas, in section twelfth of an act to incorporate Herman’s University, approved January 24, 1844, heretofore located and surveyed in the county of Gillespie, is hereby vested in the corporators created by sec-
tion one of this act, and that the Commissioner of the General Land Office is hereby authorized to issue a patent for said league of land to the corporators of Herman’s University named in section one of this act.

Sec. 10. Be it further enacted, That all laws heretofore passed by the Republic and State of Texas conflicting with this act, be and are hereby repealed; and that this act take effect from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXIX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Sabine Valley Agricultural and Mechanical Society.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That there is hereby created a body politic and corporate, to be styled the “Sabine Valley Agricultural and Mechanical Society.” Said cor-
poration shall be capable of suing and being sued, in any and all courts whatsoever; to use a common seal; to contract, and make and enforce the necessary by-laws, rules and regulations to carry into effect the object of this charter, the same not to be inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of the United States and the State of Texas.

Sec. 2. That said corporation shall be enabled to purchase and hold such real and personal property as may be necessary to effectuate and sustain the objects of its creation, which are hereby declared to be to encourage and promote the development of the agricultural and mechan-
ical interests of the State.

Sec. 3. That the officers of the Sabine Valley Agricultural and Me-
chanical Society, S. W. Wallace, president; W. B. Henderson, vice-presi-
dent; S. H. Horton, secretary; and Samuel Leastrunk, treasurer, be and are hereby authorized to open books at the town of Starville, or Tyler, or both places, for subscription to the capital stock of said corporation, in such amounts only as may be necessary for the legitimate objects of said society, to be determined by them; the said capital stock to be di-
vided into shares of two dollars each, in specie. In the election, by stockholders, each share shall be entitled to one vote; provided, no stock-
holder shall be entitled to more than twenty-five votes.

Sec. 4. That said corporators shall give notice, by publication in the newspapers published in Smith county, of the opening of said books, which shall be kept open for thirty days, or longer, if necessary, to ob-
tain the required amount of stock.

Sec. 5. That at the time of subscribing, the whole amount of such subscription shall be paid in. Such stock shall be deemed personal as-
sets, and shall be transferred only on the books of said corporation, by the person owning the same, or his legally constituted agent, attorney, legal representative, trustee or guardian, and said stock shall ever be held subject to any demand due from the stockholder to the said cor-
poration, before or at the date of the transfer.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 6. On the subscription and payment of the stock advertized for by said corporation, they shall proceed to an organization. The affairs and business of the company shall be managed by a board of directors, not less than five, nor more than seven in number, who shall be elected annually by the stockholders; the day of election to be fixed by said cor-
porators. They shall hold their offices for the term of twelve months, or until their successors are elected, and enter upon the discharge of their duties. ‘Thirty days’ notice shall be given of all elections for di-
rectors. No person shall be eligible as a director, secretary or treasurer, unless he owns at least two shares of the capital stock of said company. The said board shall elect a president and vice-president from their num-
ber, fill vacancies, appoint a treasurer and secretary, and such other offi-
cers as they may deem necessary, and require bond and security for the faithful performance of their official duties, if they see fit, and do all other acts and things that they may deem necessary in conducting the business of said society, not in contravention of the Constitution and laws of the United States and the State of Texas. A majority of the board of directors shall constitute a quorum to transact business.

Sec. 7. Instruments or contracts in writing, authorized by the society, shall be signed by the president, and countersigned by the secretary, with the seal of the society affixed; and said society shall be bound by the parol contracts made by their authorized agents within the scope of their authority, confirmed by resolutions of the board of directors.

Sec. 8. That the stockholders in said corporation shall be liable, in a just ratio or proportion to the amount of their stock held or sub-
scribed, for all debts incurred or created during their said ownership of said stock, to the extent of the amount of their stock subscribed.

Sec. 9. That the said corporation may receive, and hold by gift, grant or bequest, for the benefit of the same, any bonds, money, labor, ma-
terial or other property; but the whole amount of property held by said society shall not exceed fifty thousand dollars.

Sec. 10. That said president and board of directors shall have power to make all necessary rules and regulations for the holding of their fairs, and for the preservation of order and the protection of the fair grounds from imposition,
Sec. 11. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXX.

opener.salute: An Act making appropriation to pay Peter Metzgar for conveying his daughter, Anna Metzgar, from Arkansas to her home in Texas, who was captured by Indians, and recovered at the boundaries of the State.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Comptroller of Public Accounts be, and he is hereby authorized to draw his warrant upon the Treasurer of the State for the sum of three hundred dollars, in favor of Peter Metzgar, and that the Treas-
urer be required to pay the same; and that the sum of three hundred dollars is hereby appropriated, out of any funds in the treasury not other-
wise appropriated, to pay the same.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXI.

opener.salute:
An Act to release A. M. Nips from paying State, county or city incorpora-
tion tax on the sale of goods, wares and merchandise in the State of Texas.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That A. M. Nips be, and he is hereby authorized to sell, barter and trade in goods, wares and merchandise, in person, and not otherwise, anywhere in the State of Texas, free of any State, county or city incorporation tax.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXII.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of James P. Goodnight, late assessor and collector of Dallas county, and his sureties.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That James P. Goodnight, late assessor and collector of Dallas county, Texas, and his sureties on his official bond, be and they are hereby re-
lieved of any obligation to the State of Texas for the amount of twenty-
seven hundred dollars, collected in State tax in Dallas county, Texas, in the year 1867, and of which amount the said James P. Goodnight was robbed.

Sec. 2. That the Comptroller of Public Accounts is hereby instructed and authorized, in his settlement with the late assessor and collector of Dallas county, Texas, for the year 1867, to allow a credit for all amounts due the State by the said James P. Goodnight, and that said Comptroller receipt him in full for all indebtedness to the State.
Sec. 3. That this act take effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Lake Fork Toll Bridge Company.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That George W. Haines, Alexander Lacy and H. G. Fisher, and such associates and successors or assigns as they may associate with them, are hereby authorized to erect a toll bridge across Lake Fork of Sabine river, at or near what is known as Adams’ crossing, in Wood county, on the Quitman and Canton road, and the above named George W. Haines, Alexander Lacy and H. G. Fisher, and their associates, successors and assigns, shall be allowed to erect a toll gate; shall have the right of way, and all other rights and privileges necessary to keep up said toll bridge, slough bridges and road for twenty years.

Sec. 2. Said company shall keep said toll bridge and road
Laws of the State of Texas.through the bottom of said creek in good repair, under the supervision of the County Court of Wood county, and shall be allowed to charge the following rates of toll, and no more, to wit:
For each head of stock cattle....... $0 03
For each head of beef cattle or loose horses..... 04
For each man and horse....... 10
For horse and buggy....... 25
For a two-horse carriage or buggy.......... 35
For a wagon and two horses, or one yoke of oxen....... 25
For each additional pair of horses or oxen............ 15
For each led horse........ 05
For each, footman......... 05

Sec. 3. That said company shall construct the said bridge and road from the timber and dirt of the land of the said George W. Haines, Alexander Lacy and H. G. Fisher, and shall not be permitted to prevent individuals from traveling any road other than by said bridge.

Sec. 4. That if any person shall wilfully fail or refuse to pay tolls after crossing the said bridge, he shall be liable to forfeit and to pay to the said company the sum of five dollars and costs of suit, recoverable before any justice of the peace, as in other cases.

Sec. 5. That do other bridge shall be constructed across said Lake Fork within three miles above or three miles below said bridge company; and that said bridge shall be completed within two years from and after the passage of this act.
Sec. 6. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXIV.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the Lone Star Express and Transportation Com-
pany.

div3.p: Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, Section 1. That R. S. Reid, W. E. Gregory, R. Van Slyke, B. Rush Plumley, Henry B. Andrews, S. J. Adams, C. W. Hurley, and their associates, successors and assigns, be and they are hereby declared to be a body corporate and politic under the name of “The Lone Star Express and Transportation Company.”
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 2. The legal domicile of the corporation shall be in the city of Galveston, Texas.

Sec. 3. The object of said company is declared to be the express and transportation business; to establish express and transportation routes; to own steam and other vessels, also cars, wagons and other vehicles used for express and transportation business; to run its own cars over all rail-
roads, subject to existing laws, and to the terms of contract with any railroad company; to make contracts to forward by railroad, steamboat, steamships and other rapid routes of conveyance, by sea or land, bank-
notes, coin, jewelry, valuables of every description, all kinds of merchan-
dise, stock animals and all kinds of personal and movable property; to draw bills of exchange; to make collections of money, drafts, notes and all other species of debts, claims and demands, and to insure articles of all kind sent by their express or transportation, and generally to trans-
act all business direct and incidental, connected with the express or trans-
portation business.
Sec. 4. That the corporation shall have and use a common seal.

Sec. 5. That this corporation shall have all the privileges and im-
munities of bodies corporate under the laws of the State of Texas, and shall have power to sue and be sued; to acquire by grant, donation or purchase, and to use, occupy and sell, bargain, lease and convey all kinds of property, real and personal, necessary or convenient to operate, use or maintain its business; to make by-laws for the government of the cor-
poration and its officers and affairs, not contrary to the laws of the State of Texas, or of the United States, or of this act. The president shall be the proper officer upon whom may be served citations, notices and all other legal process against the company.
Sec. 6. That this charter shall continue for twenty-five years, unless sooner dissolved, in a manner to be hereinafter provided.

Sec. 7. That all the corporate powers of this corporation shall be vested in, and exercised by, a board of directors, and such officers as they may create. The board of directors shall consist of five or seven members of said company, to be elected by ballot on the first Monday in May, in each year, under such rules as the by-laws of said company may prescribe; of which election fifteen days’ notice shall be given, by advertisement in at least one daily newspaper published in that city. At all elections of the directors by the stock-
holders, a majority of all votes cast shall be required for the election of a director. Each share of stock to be entitled to one vote, either by the owner thereof, or by his proxy; and if, from any cause, the stockholders fail to elect such directors, the old board shall continue
Laws of the State of Texas.until their successors are elected. Any action of three-fourths of the stock shall be binding on all the stock.

Sec. 8. That the board of directors, at their first meeting, shall elect from their number a president, who shall hold his office until his successor is elected. He shall preside at all meetings of the board of directors, and shall conduct the business of the company generally, under the su-
pervision of the board of directors, and in case of his absence or inca-
pability to act, a president pro tempore may be appointed by the board. The president shall sign all contracts and other papers, but when neces-
sary, may act through agents appointed by him, with the consent of the board of directors. The board of directors shall have full power to fill all vacancies that may occur in their body, and to appoint a secretary and treasurer, all superintendents, agents, clerks, messengers and other em-
ployes, and to remove them at pleasure; and they may delegate this power to the president, subject to their supervision. They shall fix sal-
aries of all officers and employes of the company, and may authorize the president to do so, and may also designate such powers for the trans-
action of the ordinary business of the company as they may deem ex-
pedient, and shall have full power to do all other acts which may be necessary for carrying into effect the purposes of this company.

Sec. 9. That this company shall commence business as soon as ten thousand dollars shall have been subscribed to its capital stock. The capital stock shall be one hundred and fifty thousand dollars, divided into shares of fifty dollars each, five per cent. of which shall be pay-
able at the time of subscribing, and other installments as they may be called by the board of directors. The company shall have power to increase its capital stock to any sum not exceeding one million dollars; said increase in any amount not to be made unless by consent of three-
fourths of the issued stock. If any stockholders refuse or neglect to pay the installments within thirty days after the specified time of pay-
ment, the board of directors shall have the right of causing any share, upon which any installment may be due, to be sold at public auction, after ten days’ notice thereof, through any newspaper published in the city of Galveston.

Sec. 10. That this company shall have the right to sell at public auction any unclaimed freight or freights having been refused by the consignees, after having held the same for four months, and having given notice in not less than one newspaper published in Galveston, at least ten days before date of such sale; and to sell for account of whom it may concern, any perishable freights within twenty-four hours after its receipt, or sooner if necessary.

Sec. 11. All transfers of stock, or issuance thereof, shall be under such regulations as the board of directors may prescribe.
Laws of the State of Texas.Minutes of the board of directors shall be kept by the secretary and verified by the president. The president and the secretary shall sign all certificates, bonds, drafts, notes and checks.

Sec. 12. No shareholder shall be liable or responsible for contracts or faults of the company in any amount exceeeding the amount of his stock in the company. No mere informality in the organization shall have the effect of rendering this charter null, or of exposing a stock-
holder to any liability beyond the extent of his stock.

Sec. 13. That the stockholders, at a general meeting, to be convened for that purpose, after thirty days’ notice in one paper, published in the city of Galveston, shall have power to dissolve this association, with the assent of three-fourths of the stock of said company. The liquidation of the affairs of the company shall be made by their commissioners, ap-
pointed by two-thirds of the stockholders, at such meeting convened for that purpose, after thirty days’ previous notice in one newspaper pub-
lished in Galveston; and the commissioners shall have all the powers necessary to wind up and close the business of the company.
Sec. 14. That the corporators in this bill, or a majority of them, shall have authority to organize the company within twenty days after the passage of this act.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXV.

opener.salute: An Act to change the name of Anna O’Donnell to Anna Rowe.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That after the passage of this act, the name of Anna O’Donnell shall be changed to that of Anna Rowe.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXVI.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the Hempstead Eastern and Western Trunk Rail-
way Company of Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Z. Hunt, W. W. Hutchings, Mat. Steussy, Jack Baker, J. G. Bell, A. P. Willis, J. B. McGowan, of Texas, and A. Boody of New York, and their associates be and they are hereby appointed commissioners to or-
ganize a railway company to be styled the “Hempstead Eastern and Western Trunk Railway Company of Texas;” said company to have suc-
cession and a common seal; to make contracts; to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded; to grant and receive; to make by-laws for their own government, and generally to do and perform all such acts and things proper and necessary to be done that usually are done by corporate bodies to carry into effect the objects and ends of said incorporation, and to maintain the rights and privileges thereof agreeably to this act and the laws of this State.

Sec. 2. That said company is hereby empowered to locate, construct, own and maintain a railway, commencing at or near the town of Hemp-
stead, in Austin county, Texas, and running eastwardly to the town of Montgomery, thence to Huntsville, Warner’s Bluff, Sumpter, Homer, Nacogdoches and Caledonia. The western trunk of said railway shall commence at said town of Hempstead and run westwardly to the town of Bellville, stopping at Bellville for three years; provided, the narrow gauge is not there at the expiration of that time; thence to proceed to or near the towns of La Grange and Fayetteville.

Sec. 3. The capital stock of said company shall be ten millions of dollars, divided into shares of one hundred dollars each; each share entitling the owner thereof to one vote, in person or by written proxy, at all meetings of the stockholders. Said shares shall be deemed per-
sonal property, and shall be transferable only on the books of the com-
pany in such manner as the by-laws shall provide.

Sec. 4. That the commissioners named in the first section of this act shall, so soon as convenient, cause books of subscription to be opened at such times and places as they or a majority of them may deem proper, of which due notice shall be given by publication in such newspapers as said commissioners may direct. The collec-
Laws of the State of Texas.tion of any subscription to the capital stock of said company may be enforced by judgment and execution as other debts are collectable.

Sec. 5. That the immediate government and direction of the affairs of said company shall be vested in a board of directors of not less than five nor more than fifteen, who shall elect one of their number president of the company. No person shall be a director unless he be the owner of at least five shares of the capital stock of the company. A majority of said directors shall be citizens of the State of Texas. The first election for directors shall take place within two years from the passage of this act, and shall be held within the State of Texas. When a vacancy oc-
curs by the death, resignation or refusal of any director to act, such vacancy may be filled by the other directors for the unexpired term. Said board of directors shall, after the first year, hold their offices for one year; and in case the stockholders fail to elect at any regular time for holding the election, of which thirty days’ notice shall be given by publishing such notice in one or more newspapers, then those in office shall hold over for another year, or until a regular election can be held. They shall elect a secretary and treasurer, and shall cause a record of their proceedings, and an account of their receipts and expenditures to be kept in books to be provided for that purpose, which shall, at all rea-
sonable office hours, be open for the inspection of any person interested in said company. A majority of said directors shall have the authority of a full board. All contracts and conveyances executed by the president in writing, and countersigned by the secretary and treasurer, shall be valid and binding, if within the scope of their rights, duties and privi-
leges as defined by this act and by the by-laws of the company. Said company shall keep one or more offices on the line of said road, but the principal office may be kept at such place as the board of directors may determine, and branch offices may be established at such other places as the company may designate.

Sec. 6. That no debts or liabilities contracted, or losses sustained by said company, shall be binding upon or a charge against individual stockholders for any amount; but such liability shall extend only to the stock, franchises and property of the company.

Sec. 7. It shall be lawful for said company to enter upon and purchase, or otherwise take and hold, any lands necessary for the purpose of locating, constructing and maintaining said trunk rail-
way, with all the necessary depots and other buildings connected with said trunk railway; and if they shall not be able to obtain said lands by agreement with the owners thereof, they shall pay such compensation as shall be determined in the manner provided in the
Laws of the State of Texas.following section. The land so taken for the road-bed shall not exceed two hundred feet in width, and for depots only such further width as shall be necessary.

Sec. 8. Any person or persons whose land has been taken as afore-
said, without agreement or satisfactory compensation, may apply to the District Court of the county in which said land is situated, for the ap-
pointment of appraisers, and said court shall thereupon appoint three disinterested freeholders of said county, who shall appoint a time and place to hear the applicant and said company, to whom shall be given by said freeholders reasonable notice of the time and place of said hear-
ing; and said freeholders shall, after being duly sworn, and after due hearing of the parties, determine the amount of compensation, if any, to which the applicant may be entitled, and make return of their award at the next succeeding term of said court; and said award, if not re-
jected by said court for sufficient cause then shown, shall be entered upon as the judgment of said court. In determining the question of compensation, said freeholders shall be governed by the actual value of said land at the time it was taken, taking into consideration the benefits or injuries done to other lands or property of its owner by the establish-
ment of said railway; and if the amount of compensation awarded by said freeholders shall not exceed that offered by said company to the owner, prior to said application to the court, the applicant shall pay the cost of the proceedings, otherwise the company shall pay the same. During the inquiry as to the value of said land, or the damage done to the estate of the owner, said company shall in no manner be molested or hindered in the prosecution of their work thereon, or occupation of the same, by any writ or process from any court of this State; but all officers of the law are authorized and required to render prompt assist-
ance to said company in the premises.

Sec. 9. The commissioners hereby appointed in the first section of this act, may acquire, by gift or purchase, any real estate or other prop-
erty, notes, bonds and judgments, and may appoint agents to receive subscriptions of stock and conveyances until the election of the board of directors, after which such powers may be exercised by said board of directors.

Sec. 10. Such company shall have power to borrow money, and to mortgage or hypothecate the property and franchises of the company, or to execute their bonds and notes for the same, at such rates and on such terms as the directors may deem expedient. Said railway shall have the right to cross any stream necessary to be crossed, and to build bridges therefor; but on all such navigable streams the bridges shall be so built as not to obstruct navigation by steamboats lowering their chim-
neys.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 11. That the gauge of track of said road shall not be less than four feet eight inches. This charter is granted subject to the provisions of the general railroad laws of this State, as they now are or hereafter may be enacted, except where the same may be in conflict with the pro-
visions of this act.

Sec. 12. That said company shall commence the construction of said railroad at or near the town of Hempstead, within twelve months from the passage of this act, and shall build twenty miles of road the first three years, or this charter be null and void, and may construct either the eastern or western portion first, or both simultaneously, as said board of directors may determine.
Sec. 13. That this act shall take effect and be in force force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXVII.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the Bean’s Wharf Warehouse and Cotton Com-
press Company of the city of Galveston.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That P. N. Spofford, J. L. Spofford, Gardner S. Spofford, and A. H. Bean, of the city of New York, Thompson H. McMahan, John S. Sellers, A. J. Walker, J. M. Brandon, C. H. Jordan, J. D. Rogers, C. W. Hurley, E. S. Jamison, A. J. Ward, C. E. Richards, J. H. Metcalf and their as-
sociates, successors and assigns be, and they are hereby constituted and created a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of “The Bean’s Wharf, Warehouse and Cotton Compress Company,” and by that name shall be capable of suing and being sued, contracting and being contracted with, and may own, purchase and sell real and personal prop-
erty, have a corporate seal, and enact such by-laws, rules and regula-
tions for the management of said company, as they may deem necessary.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That the capital stock of said com-
pany shall be eight hundred thousand dollars, divided into shares of one hundred dollars each; and when one hundred thousand dollars there-
of is subscribed, the said company may organize, as hereinafter provided.

Sec. 3. That books for the subscription of said capital stock shall be opened at the office of T. H. McMahan, in the city of Gal-
Laws of the State of Texas.veston, and notice of the opening of said books, and the length of time they will remain open, shall be published for ten days in the Galveston newspapers; and on the expiration of the time fixed, the books may be closed, and Thompson H. McMahan shall call a meeting of the sub-
scribers for said stock, at such convenient time and place as he may fix, for the election of directors; and at such election, and at all subsequent elections and votes on measures of interest to the stockholders, the vote shall be by stock, each stockholder having as many votes as he may own shares; and the by-laws shall define a quorum of stockholders.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That the board of directors shall con-
sist of not less than five, nor more than ten persons, stockholders, and the said board, after their election, shall elect one of their number presi-
dent, and one vice-president, and one treasurer, and the by-laws shall define a quorum of directors.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That the said corporation shall have, use and exercise all the powers necessary for the purpose of its creation; and may build and operate wharves, warehouses, and cotton compresses, in the city of Galveston, on property belonging to or acquired by said corporation; and shall be entitled to ask, demand, sue for and recover compensation for the use of their wharves, warehouses and compresses, as may be established by the directors.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That the elections for directors shall be annual, at such times as may be designated by the by-laws of said company; and in case of vacancies, the board of directors shall fill the same until the next regular annual election by the stockholders, and the directors and officers shall hold office until their successors are elected and qualified. The directors may create such offices, and ap-
point such officers as they may deem necessary for the advantageous management of the affairs of the company, and may fix their compen-
sation.

Sec. 7. Be it further enacted, That in all suits against said corpora-
tion, service upon the president, vice-president or treasurer shall be deemed a sufficient service on said company.

Sec. 8. Be it further enacted, That this charter shall continue and be in force for twenty-five years from the first election of directors; and that this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the South-western Insurance and Trust Company.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That George Moore, T. W. House, Leon Blum, John H. F. Chapman, A. M. Hobby, Alphage Hawkins, Dr. E. Randle, Henry B. Andrews, A. D. Harn, T. C. Armstrong, M. Quinn and A. J. Ward, and those that may associate with them, and their successors and assigns, shall be and they are hereby created a body politic and corporate, by the name of the “South-western Insurance and Trust Company” with the power, in that name, to contract and be contracted with, sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, answer and defend in all courts and places whatever as a natural person, and to have and use a common seal at pleasure.

Sec. 2. It shall be lawful for said company to transact financial busi-
ness as a natural person, to loan money, discount promissory notes, buy and sell exchange, stocks, and other mercantile securities, and the prom-
issory notes made payable and negotiable at the office or principal place of business of said company, or of any of its branches in this State, and inland bills which may be discounted or purchased prior to maturity by said company, shall be and they are hereby put upon the footing of foreign bills of exchange, and like remedy may be had thereon.

Sec. 3. The said company shall have power to make advances on approved security, and upon the agricultural and other products of the country. It may receive bonds, stocks, produce and merchandise in pledge for the security of money. It may also receive in pledge, or as security for money loaned or debts owing, United States vouchers, cer-
tificates or bonds of indebtedness, or the bonds of the State of Texas, or any other character of property or security whatsoever, and sell the same on the non-payment of debt, or demand, at the stipulated time of payment, according to any agreement made between the parties for the payment of the same, and pass a good title to the purchaser, and any power given for that purpose shall be irrevocable until the debt or de-
mand is paid or duly tendered.

Sec. 4. The company may receive deposits of gold, silver, bank notes, United States’ treasury notes, and other currency, and pay the same in kind, or as may be agreed by general or special contract,
Laws of the State of Texas.and may allow interest on deposits. It may issue letters of credit pay-
aide throughout the United States, Canada, Europe, Mexico and the West India Islands, for the convenience of merchants and travelers, hut shall not issue promissory notes to circulate as money.

Sec. 5. The said company may borrow money, but not in excess of its capital stock subscribed, and may secure the same by mortgage on its real and personal property, or pledge of stocks, or bonds, or other-
wise, and on such time as the president and directors, or a quorum thereof, may deem expedient; provided, that no mortgage or loan shall be made against the property of said company, by said directors, until general or special authority shall be given by a majority of the stock-
holders in amount.

Sec. 6. The capital stock of said company shall not exceed one mil-
lion dollars, and shall be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each. The shares shall be personal estate, and transferable on the books of the company according to its by-laws; but the company shall hold a lien on the shares of any stockholder who may be indebted to it, and such shares shall not be transferable without the consent of the presi-
dent and directors, until such debt shall be paid or discharged. Bach share of said capital stock shall entitle the holders to one vote at all elections of directors, and at all meetings of stockholders, and any action of three-fourths of the issued stock, expressed in writing, or by vote at any meeting of the stockholders, shall be binding on all the stock of said company. Said company shall have power and authority to invest their money in buying, holding and leasing lots of land, and to build thereon houses or buildings for private or public uses, and to sell or lease the same.

Sec. 7. The said persons named in the first section of this act, shall act as commissioners to receive subscriptions of stock, and shall fix the time and manner of paying in the same, and prescribe in the subscrip-
tions what failure shall authorize a forfeiture of the stock subscribed for; and when not less than twenty-five thousand dollars shall have act-
ually been paid in, or secured to be paid, on account of subscriptions to said capital stock, the said company may be organized and proceed to business.

Sec. 8. The said persons named in the first section of this act shall be the first board of directors of said company, and shall organize by choosing one of their number president; but if any of said persons shall fail to subscribe for as much as five shares of said capital stock, or to pay in on account thereof, as prescribed, his or their place or places as directors may be deemed and treated as vacant, and the vacancy or vacancies filled by the remaining direc-
tors; and no person shall at any time be president or director in said
Laws of the State of Texas.company, who does not own at least five shares of said capital stock, and said president and directors shah provide by the by-laws, for the annual election of president and directors, after two years from the first organization of the company, and the president and directors shall always hold their offices until their successors are duly qualified. The legal domicile of said company shall be in the city of Galveston, Texas.

Sec. 9. The president and directors shall, from time to time, make all necessary by-laws, rules and regulations, and alter and amend the same, not in contravention of the Constitution of this State or the Con-
stitution and laws of the United States, and prescribe the number of directors necessary to make a quorum for the transaction of business; and may provide for administering oaths and taking bonds from its offi-
cers and employes, to secure the faithful discharge of their duties; said by-laws must be approved by a majority of the stockholders in amount.
Sec. 10. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage, and shall continue for the space of twenty-five years.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXVIX.

opener.salute: An Act to re-incorporate tire stockholders of the “Union Marine and Fire Insurance Company,” of the city of Galveston.

div3.p:
Whereas, The Union Marine and Fire Insurance Company, a body corporate and politic, was created by an act of the Legislature of the State of Texas, approved January 26, 1848, to continue for twenty years, which time has expired, and the said company has, since its cre-
ation, executed the chartered rights and privileges conferred by said act successfully, and for the benefit of commerce, and in accordance with its charter, and under an amendment thereto, passed on the thirteenth August, 1856, has increased its capital stock to the sum of two hundred thousand dollars, which sum has been paid in and subscribed; and

Whereas, by an ordinance or declaration of the Convention, which framed the present Constitution of the State of Texas, the said charter as amended, was extended to remain in force, until the
Laws of the State of Texas.close of the first Legislature to meet after the adjournment of the said Convention; and the stockholders of said company now desire a new charter; therefore,

Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of. Texas, That I. Dyer, J. Frederick, A. C. Crawford, J. W. Joekusch, Henry Runge, J. P. Davie, H. B. Yard, M. Kopperl, T. Wagner, C. R. Hughes, James M. Brown, C. F. Hohorst, and Jesse Batts, now acting as directors of said company, together with their associate stockholders, and all per-
sons who may hereafter subscribe to or hold shares of the capital stock of said company, and their successors and assigns, be and they are hereby made and continued a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of the “Union Marine and Fire Insurance Company,” and by that name shall have and use a common seal, and be capable of suing and being sued, and maintaining any action to final judgment and execution, and shall be in law, capable of purchasing, holding improv-
ing and conveying any property or estate, real, personal or mixed, for the use of said corporation; and the said corporation, is hereby invested with the power to ordain, establish and execute all such by-laws, ordi-
nances and regulations as may be convenient or necessary for the govern-
ment thereof, and for the conducting of the business for which it was created; and it shall be lawful for the said corporation, after the ex-
piration of the term of this charter, to use the corporate name, seal and style, for the purpose of suits at law or in equity, and for the final settle-
ment and liquidation of the business of the corporation, for the sale and disposition of its property, but not for any other purpose, or in any other manner whatsoever, nor for more than three years after the expiration of the term of incorporation.

Sec. 2. That the present capital stock of said corporation, amounting to two hundred thousand dollars, as authorized by the above recited acts, may be increased to the sum of five hundred thousand dollars, divided into shares of fifty dollars each, whenever the stockholders shall deem it for the interest of the company, and shall so decide by a vote taken at an annual meeting of stockholders, or at a meeting called for the pur-
pose of voting on that question, after ten days’ notice, published in a Galveston newspaper, and said additional stock shall be subscribed and paid in at such times, and in such manner as the board of directors of said corporation may direct and require, after first giving public notice of such subscription in one or more of the Galveston daily newspapers.

Sec. 3. That for the well ordering of the affairs of said com-
pany, there shall be elected by the stockholders, at their next an-
nual meeting, and at successive annual meetings, or at such meeting as any annual meeting may be adjourned to, a board of thirteen di-
Laws of the State of Texas.rectors, who shall be stockholders in the company, and said annual meet-
ing shall hereafter take place on the second Monday in January in each year, and at such election, each stockholder shall have one vote for every share he may hold, which vote shall be by ballot, and absent stockholders may vote by written or printed proxies, or under a general power of at-
torney, when no special proxy is offered; provided, that all directors and officers of said company shall hold their offices until their successors shall be elected and duly qualified.

Sec. 4. That the directors of said company, five of whom shall con-
stitute a quorum for the transaction of business, and to include the president or vice-president, or any director acting as president pro tem-
pore, by appointment in the absence of the president, shall have power to appoint such officers, clerks and agents as they shall consider necessary for conducting the business of said corporation, and shall grant and allow them such compensation for their services as they may deem just and reasonable, and generally to exercise all other authority and powers that may be necessary and sufficient for the well ordering and governing the affairs and funds of said company.

Sec. 5. That it shall be lawful for the said corporation to employ its funds in establishing, sustaining and carrying on the business of marine, inland and fire insurance, in all its departments, and to issue policies and make contracts of insurance against all risks that are usually in-
sured against, on buildings, or any other property in stores or houses, or in course of transportation on land, or by vessels of any description, at such premiums, and for such compensation as the directors may de-
termine to be just and reasonable, under such conditions, and with such exceptions as may be stated in the policies or contracts of insurance made by said company: and it shall be lawful for said company to invest their funds in stocks, bonds or real estate: to buy and sell bills of ex-
change, discount negotiable paper, receive deposits and pay out the same on cheeks of depositors, and to loan money at such rate of interest as may be customary, or shall be agreed on under such rules and regula-
tions, as to security and extent of loans, as the directors may establish.

Sec. 6. That the shares of the stock of said corporation shall be transferable upon the books of said company, under such rules and reg-
ulations as the directors shall establish.

Sec. 7. That the board of directors of said corporation may, at such periods as the condition of the company shall justify it, on an examination of the business and accounts of the company, divide such parts of the profits thereof among the stockholders as they may deem to be advisable; provided, no dividend shall be made, ex-
Laws of the State of Texas.cept when the capital stock of the company, on a fair valuation of its assets, shall remain unimpaired.

Sec. 8. That the principal office of said company shall remain lo-
cated in the city of Galveston, with such branch offices and agencies as the business of the company may require.

Sec. 9. That the corporate powers and franchises granted by this act shall continue and be in force, and he held and enjoyed by the said corporation for the term of fifty years from and after the passage of this act.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXX.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of David Cole or his assigns.

div3.p: Whereas, By certificate No. 62, approved November 9, 1866, the amount of fifty dollars, as “back pension,” was due David Cole, which certificate is duly attested January 14, 1867; therefore,

Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the sum of fifty dollars be and the same is hereby appropriated to pay the said David Cole, or the holders of said certificate of public debt of the State of Texas, and that an order be drawn by the Comp-
troller upon the Treasurer for the same.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXXI.

opener.salute: An Act to prohibit the sale or otherwise disposing of spirituous or vinous liquors within two miles of “Greenwood Masonic Institute.”

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the sale of all intoxicating liquors, including all vinous, fermented or medicated liquors, except for medical or sacra-
Laws of the State of Texas.mental purposes, within two miles of “Greenwood Masonic Institute,” in the town of Bound Bock, Williamson county, Texas, is prohibited; and the furnishing or the giving away of any intoxicating liquors or drinks, to any student or students of said institute, is hereby prohibited.

Sec. 2. That any person or persons violating the provisions of the foregoing section shall be fined in any sum not less than ten or more than one hundred dollars for each violation of the same, by any court of competent jurisdiction.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXXII.

opener.salute: An Act to prohibit the sale of intoxicating liquors within certain limits of “Johnson Station High School,” in the town of Johnson Station, in Tarrant county.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That no person shall be permitted to make, sell or distribute any spirit-
uous, vinous or other intoxicating liquors within two miles of the John-
son Station High School, situated in the town of Johnson Station, Tarrant county, Texas; provided, that this act shall not prohibit any person from purchasing the same for medical purposes, under the pre-
scription of some practising physician, or for sacramental purposes.

Sec. 2. Any person violating the provisions of this act shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction thereof before any court having jurisdiction, shall be fined in a sum not less than ten, nor more than one hundred dollars for every such offense.
Sec. 3. That this act take effect and be in force for fifty years, from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXXIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Agricultural and Mechanical Association of North-eastern Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That John A. Turner, B. A. Baker, John P. Hill, C. English, A. G. Talbot, W. C. Wright, L. Collins, Joel Arrington, Joshua E, Johnson, and others, their associates and successors, be and are hereby declared a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the “Agricul-
tural and Mechanical Association of North-eastern Texas/-’ and as such shall be capable of suing and being sued, pleading and being impleaded, contracting and being contracted with, and doing and performing all things necessary to carry into effect the objects of this act. That the parties named in this act shall act as commissioners to obtain, by sub-
scription, the capital stock of said association, and that the stockholders shall organize the same in the manner hereinafter provided.

Sec. 2. That the objects of said association are declared to be the improvement of the breed of domestic animals, and the encouragement of agricultural and mechanical improvements; and for these purposes said association is authorized to purchase, import, breed exhibit and sell any kind of domestic animals; to purchase, import, manufacture, exhibit and sell such improved machinery and implements as will promote the mechanical, agricultural and manufacturing interests of the people of this State; provided, nothing herein contained shall infringe upon the rights of patentees; and for the further purpose of carrying out the ob-
jects and purposes of this association as above declared, said association is hereby authorized to own the necessary real estate for fair grounds, pastures and training grounds, not to exceed five hundred acres, and to erect upon the same such improvements as may be necessary to carry out the objects of this association. That the fair grounds and other improvements of said association shall be located in the county of Titus, in this State.

Sec. 3. That the capital stock of said association shall not ex-
ceed fifty thousand dollars, divided into shares of twenty dollars each, and that the affairs of said association shall be conducted by a board of directors elected by and from the stockholders of said asso-
ciation, and that said board shall consist of not more than seven, who shall elect one of their number president, and shall make such
Laws of the State of Texas.by-laws, rules and regulations, and appoint such officers and agents as may be necessary for the government and conduct of said association.
Sec. 4. That this act shall take effect and be in force for twenty-five years from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXXIV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Texas Land Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted Toy the Legislature of the State of Texas, That T. W. House, P. F. Spofford, Jas. B. Shaw, J. M. Jones, C. R. Johns, George Butler, S. M. Swenson, Wm. Clemsen, M. Kopperl, Isa-
dore Dyer, P. De Cordova, J. E. Rector, and their associates, he and they are hereby incorporated and declared to be a body politic, under the name of The Texas Land Company; and under such name may trans-
fer their rights by succession, and shall be persons in law capable of suing and being sued, impleading and being impleaded, and that they and their successors, by the same name and style, shall be in law capable of holding and conveying any estate, real, personal or mixed, and doing and performing all things necessary for the business of said company, and not contrary to the Constitution and laws of the State. Said com-
pany shall have a corporate seal with such device as they may select, and may alter the same at their pleasure.

Sec. 2. The objects of said company are declared to be to promote immigration to Texas, to facilitate the sale and purchase and the settle-
ment of lands by immigration, and to introduce laborers, skilled opera-
tors and capital into the State.

Sec. 3. The capital stock of said company shall be one million of dollars, divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, and the said company may commence operations with all the powers and penalties of this act, whenever fifty thousand dollars of the capital stock shall have been subscribed.

Sec. 4. The management of the affairs of said company shall be conducted by a board of directors, and under such rules and regulations as the stockholders may determine at their first regular meeting, and the organization of said company and appointment, of officers shall take place at such meeting.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 5. The company may dissolve by a vote of two-thirds of the issued stock, in which event, after the payment of all outstanding obli-
gations, the land and other possessions held by the company shall be sold at public auction, to be paid for in outstanding shares of the capital stock of the company, until all such outstanding shares shall have been redeemed, and if not sooner dissolved its rights and franchises shall ex-
pire by limitation in twenty years.

Sec. 6. That a majority of the board of directors of said company shall have power to pass all necessary regulations, ordinances and by-laws for the regulation and government of said company in its business and contracts as are not in contravention of the Constitution and laws of the State.
Sec. 7. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate Salter’s Commercial and Literary College.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. M. Salter, T. J. Johnson, J. D. C. Hunter, G. D. Kelley, W. H. Howard, J. F. Watts, W. M. Waddell, H. H. Link and A. Jovst, trustees of Salter’s Commercial and Literary College, situated in the town of Palestine, county of Anderson, be and are hereby created a body cor-
porate, under the name and style of the “Trustees of Salter’s Commer-
cial and Literary College,” and by that name may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, enact by-laws rules and regulations, purchase, take, hold and enjoy all property of every and all kinds for the benefit of said college; to convert said property into money, and dispose of the same, and shall have a common seal for the transaction of its business.

Sec. 2. That the rights and privileges herein granted shall ex-
tend to the trustees named in the preceding section and their sur-
vivors, and to no other person. In the event of the death of one or more of said trustees, all the rights and privileges granted by the provisions of this act shall be taken, exercised and enjoyed by their
Laws of the State of Texas.survivors, and on the death of all the said trustees, then the corporation herein created shall be extinct.

Sec. 3. That the board of trustees shall have power, upon the recom-
mendation of the faculty, to confer diplomas in the commercial depart-
ment, and degrees in the arts and sciences upon the graduates of said col-
lege, and upon such persons as they may deem worthy, and give diplomas of the same by the proper signatures and endorsement of the president and faculty of the said college, and by the board of trustees, or a ma-
jority of said trustees.
Sec. 4. That all donations and bequests to said college shall be good and binding, although the corporate name may not have been properly stated by the person making such donation or bequest.

Sec. 5. The board of trustees may elect from their own number, under such rules and regulations as they may adopt, and for such terms and times as they may see proper, a president, secretary and treasurer, or any officer or agent necessary in the board; they shall also have the power to contract, enlarge, alter or remove all things necessary to the proper con-
duct and management of said college, not contrary to law, or inconsistent with this charter.
Sec. 6. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXXVI.

opener.salute:
An Act to revive an act, and amend the first section of the same, incor-
porating the Burnett Male and Female Academy.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That an act, entitled “An act to incorporate the Burnett Male and Female Academy,” approved on the nineteenth day of October, one thousand eight, hundred and sixty-six, be and the same is hereby revived, and declared in full force and effect from and after the passage hereof; and that the first section of said act be amended, so that the same shall read as follows, to-wit: Section 1. That E. Sampson, W. A. Blackburn, S. A. Posey, W. W. Brooks, and Hiram Daugherty, and their successors in office, be and they are hereby constituted a body corporate and politic, for educational purposes, by the name and style of the “Burnett Male and Female Academy,” by which name they may sue and be sued, plead and be
Laws of the State of Texas.impleaded, buy and sell property, real, personal and mixed, and may have a seal to authenticate their acts, for the purpose of maintaining an institution of learning in Burnett, Burnett county, Texas.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXXVII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate Butler Male and Female College, in the County of Freestone.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That for the management and control of an institution of learning, lo-
cated in the town of Butler, Freestone county, to be styled the “Butler Male and Female College,” John Stillwell, Janies B. Mobley, Thomas P. Whitt, Thomas C4. Mayes, and Wm. McDaniel, are hereby constituted a board of trustees for said college, and that they and their successors in office are made a body corporate, capable in law of suing and being sued, holding or alienating property, real or personal.

Sec. 2. That said board of trustees shall have succession—shall have a common seal—may hold property to the amount of five hundred thou-
sand dollars—may establish a course of studies, grant diplomas or cer-
tificates of scholarship, and do all other things necessary and incident to the maintenance and promotion of good morals and sound learning, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of the United States or of this State.

Sec. 3. That this act of incorporation, and this charter for said college, shall remain in full force and effect until said trustees, or their successors, shall neglect or refuse to maintain in said college a school organization during the accustomed scholastic months of any one year.

Sec. 4. No person or persons shall engage in the sale of intoxicating liquors within three miles of said college, except for medicinal purposes; and any one violating this section of this act shall be fined in a sum not less than twenty-five nor more than one hundred dollars for each viola-
tion thereof, by any court having competent jurisdiction.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXXVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate Trinity University, located at Tehuacana Hills, Limestone county, Texas.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That an institution of learning, heretofore located and now in operation at Tehuacana Hills, Limestone county, Texas, be and the same is hereby incorporated by the name of Trinity University, and James M. Love, D. M. Prendergast, Isaac H. Roberts, J. H. Bell, J. S. Wills, H. A. Boyd, D. R. Oliphant, S. B. Campbell and M. M. Burgess, and their successors in office, are hereby constituted a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of “The Board of Trustees of Trinity University,” to have charge of the interests of said institution, by which name they shall have succession, and be capable in law to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded; to contract and be contracted with; to enact by-laws, rules and regulations; to buy, sell and hold property of any and every kind, and manage the same, whether purchased or acquired by said institution by gift, devise, bequest or otherwise, and generally to do and perform whatever, in the opinion of said board, will advance the interests of said institution, without being inconsistent with the laws of the land.

Sec. 2. The board of trustees shall have a common seal for the transac-
tion of its business, which shall be kept by the secreary of the board, and shall have the direct control and management of the said institution; but the several synods of the Cumberland Presbyterian Church in Texas shall have a general advisory supervision of the same; and said board shall, once in each year, report to said synods the condition of said insti-
tution, with such details as may be necessary to understand its workings and prospects.

Sec. 3. The faculty of said institution shall consist of a president, and such professors and tutors as the board of trustees may deem neces-
sary, who shall be appointed, and may be removed, and whose salaries shall be fixed by the board of trustees.

Sec. 4. Said institution shall consist of both male and female depart-
ments, and the male department may embrace, besides the ordinary liter-
ary department, a department of law, medicine, theology, and such other departments as the board of trustees may, from time to time, deem proper.

Sec. 5. All property purchased, donated, bequeathed or other-
Laws of the State of Texas.wise acquired by said institution, shall be deemed to be held by said board of trustees in trust for the Cumberland Presbyterian Church in Texas, with full power, however, to sell, control, and manage the same for the benefit of said institution.

Sec. 6. The board of trustees shall elect from its own number a chair-
man, secretary and treasurer, who shall hold their offices for such time, and shall, respectively, perform such duties, and be subject to such orders, rules, restrictions and obligations as may be prescribed by the board. But all sales, contracts and obligations shall have the sanction of the board, and shall be signed by the chairman and attested by the secretary, with the seal of the board affixed, or by the agents of the board regularly ap-
pointed and thereto duly authorized.

Sec. 7. The board of trustees shall meet on its own adjournment, but meetings may be called by the chairman, with the concurrence of one other member thereof, or by two members of the faculty. A majority of the board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of all business, except the election or removal of a member of the faculty, which shall require the concurrence of at least two thirds of the members of the board. No meeting of said board shall be held elsewhere than at the in-
stitution, nor shall any member of the board reside at a greater distance than twelve miles therefrom.

Sec. 8. The board of trustees shall have power to remove or expel any of its members for grossly immoral or disreputable conduct, or for continued and wilful neglect of the duties incident to his position; to do this, however, it shall require a two-thirds vote of the entire board, and the reasons for so doing shall be entered in full upon the minutes of the board.

Sec. 9. All donations heretofore made to said institution, or to the board of trustees acting in behalf thereof, and all sales, contracts and ob-
ligations heretofore made and entered into by or with said board, shall be held to be as valid and of the same binding force as if said institution had at that time been incorporated, and said board of trustees had then been by law a body corporate and politic.

Sec. 10. The board of trustees shall reorganize as soon as practicable after the passage of this act, and shall continue in office for twelve months, and until their successors are duly appointed and are prepared to enter upon the discharge of their duties, and may fill such vacancies as shall in the meantime occur by death, resignation or otherwise.

Sec. 11. At the expiration of the term of service of the present board of trustees, the Texas synod of the Cumberland
Laws of the State of Texas.Presbyterian Church shall appoint three trustees to take the place of the three first named in this act; the Brazos Synod of the Cumberland Presbyterian Church shall appoint three to take the place of the three next named; and the Colorado Synod of the Cumberland Presbyterian Church shall appoint three to take the place of the three last named. The members of the present board shall be eligible to re-appointment, and the trustees so appointed shall hold their offices during the pleasure of the synods so appointing them; and in case of a vacancy by death, resignation or otherwise, the board shall fill the same, until the synod which made the appointment shall act in the premises. Should one or more syn-
ods of the Presbyterian Church be organized in Texas, such synod or syn-
ods shall have the same rights and privileges in connection with said in-
stitution as those named in this act; and in that case, for each additional synod so organized, three additional trustees, to be appointed by such synod, shall be added to the number named aboved.

Sec. 12 The board of trustees, acting in conjunction with the faculty, shall have power to confer such degrees upon graduating students and upon other deserving persons as are usually conferred by institutions of learning of like grade, and to give diplomas or certificates thereof in such form as they may deem proper.

Sec. 13. The property owned and held by said institution, being set apart exclusively for educational purposes, is hereby declared to be ex-
empt from both State and county taxation.

div3.head: CHAPTER LXXXIX.

opener.salute: An Act to amend an act to incorporate the Fire Association in the City of San Antonio, approved February 8, 1858.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the first section of an act, entitled “An act to incor-
porate the “Fire Association of the city of San Antonio,” ap-
proved February 8, 1858, be amended so that the same shall here-
after read as follows, to-wit: That A, A Lockwood, L. Zork, F. R. Frankel, and their associates, are hereby constituted a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of “San Antonio Fire As-
sociation, No. 1, of the city of San Antonio,” and by that name
Laws of the State of Texas.shall have succession, and may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded; have a corporate seal, buy, sell and hold property, real, personal and mixed, not to exceed in value fifty thousand dollars; make contracts, and all rules and by-laws that may be necessary for the government of the association, and have and exercise all the powers and rights generally in-
cident to such associations.

Sec. 2. That the third section of the above recited act be so amended as to read as follows, to-wit: That the actual active members of the as-
sociation shall be exempt from serving on juries, except in capital cases.
Sec. 3. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XC.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Houston Hook and Ladder Company No. 1, of the City of Houston.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. C. Wagner, A. C. Rogers, O. L. Cockrane, J. C. Baldwin, E. L. Bremond and E. H. Bailey, and their associates and successors, shall be and they are hereby constituted a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of Houston Hook and Ladder Company No. 1, of the city of Houston, with power to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, to appear and prosecute to final judgment in any court or elsewhere; to have a common seal with such device as they may adopt; to elect, in what-
ever manner they may choose, the officers necessary to command them; to establish by-laws for tire government and regulation of their affairs not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of this State, and the same to alter and amend at pleasure, and to hold real and personal prop-
erty and to dispose of the same; provided, that such real estate and per-
sonal property shall, at no time, exceed twenty thousand dollars ($20,000) in value, and that said company shall never exceed sixty men, rank and file.

Sec. 2. That the active members of said company shall be exempt from serving on juries and from militia duty, except in times of insurrec-
tion, rebellion or war.

Sec. 3. That said company shall have power, by their constitu-
Laws of the State of Texas.tion and by-laws, to try all violations of their ordinances agreed upon by a majority of the members of said company; to suspend, expel or fine, not exceeding ten dollars, those members violating the constitution or laws of said company.

Sec. 4.
