That so much of an act entitled “An act to incorporate the Houston Hook and Ladder Company No. 1, and Liberty Fire Company No. 2, of the city of Houston,” approved December 31, 1859, as pertains to the Houston Hook and Ladder Company No. 1, of the city of Houston, be and the same is hereby repealed.
Sec. 5. That this act of incorporation shall take effect from the date of its passage, and shall be and continue in full force and effect for and during the full term of twenty-five years.

div3.head: CHAPTER XCI.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the Stonewall Fire Company of the City of Hous-
ton.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That F. I. Frank, William Glass, J. F. Meyer, Ed. Schultz, and their associates and successors, shall be and they are hereby constituted a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of “Stonewall Fire Com-
pany of the city of Houston,” with power to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded; to appear and prosecute to final judgment in any court or elsewhere; to have a common seal, with such device as they may adopt; to elect, in whatever manner they may choose, the officers necessary to command them; to establish by-laws for the regulation and government of their affairs, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of this State and the same to alter and amend at pleasure and to hold real and personal property, and dispose of the same; provided, however, that said real estate and personal property shall at no time exceed twenty thousand dollars in value, and said company shall never exceed fifty men, rank and file.

Sec. 2. That said company shall have power, by their constitution and by-laws, to try all violators of their ordinances, agreed upon by a majority of the members of said company; to suspend, expel or fine, not exceeding ten dollars, those members violating the constitution and laws of said company.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 3. That this act of incorporation shall be and continue in force, for and during the term of twenty years, from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XCII.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the Houston and San Jacinto Canal and Naviga-
tion Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. R. Morris, Alexander McGowan, and their associates, be and are hereby appointed commissioners to open books and receive subscrip-
tions to the capital stock of a corporation hereby created, to be styled the Houston and San Jacinto Canal and Navigation Company.
Sec. 2. That the majority of the commissioners shall constitute a board for the transaction of business, and shall hold meetings, from time to time, until directors shall be elected.

Sec. 3. That at the time of subscribing to the stock of this company, five per centum of the amount subscribed shall be paid to the commis-
sioners or the directors; and whenever one hundred thousand dollars are subscribed, the company shall be fully organized for the transaction of business.

Sec. 4. The subscribers to the capital stock of this company are here-
by created and established a body corporate and politic, under the name and style of the Houston and San Jacinto Canal and Navigation Com-
pany, with capacity to contract; to sue and be sued; to plead and be im-
pleaded; to have succession and a common seal; to grant and receive; to make by-laws, and generally to do and perform all things necessary and proper to maintain their rights under this act.

Sec. 5. The capital stock of this company shall be —, to be increased to such an amount, if required, as may be requisite to carry out the object of this company, divided into shares of one hundred dollars each; each share shall entitle its holder and owner to one vote at all elections, and a majority of stock shall govern. The said shares of stock shall be deemed personal estate, transferable only on the books of the company.

Sec. 6. The direction and control of said corporation and its
Laws of the State of Texas.affairs shall be vested in a board of seven directors, to be chosen by the stockholders, at an annual meeting, the first of which shall be held in the city of Houston, whenever one hundred thousand dollars shall have been subscribed and paid, as heretofore provided.

Sec. 7. A majority of the board shall constitute a quorum to do business; at their first meeting they shall elect one of their body presi-
dent and one vice-president. The board shall appoint a secretary and treasurer and other officers requisite to carry on the business of the com-
pany.

Sec. 8. That said company, when duly organized, shall be and is hereby invested with the right of locating, excavating, constructing, own-
ing, operating and maintaining a canal, commencing at or near White Oak or Buffalo Bayou in the city of Houston, and running north-west to the eastern north branch or fork of the San Jacinto river, above the junction thereof, with the privilege of erecting such dams, locks, water-
wears, and creating such slack-water navigation as may be deemed to the interest of the company and the successful maintenance and operation of said canal.

Sec. 9. It shall be lawful for said company to enter upon, purchase, or otherwise receive, take, hold and appropriate any lands necessary for locating, constructing, excavating or embanking and maintaining said land, with all the necessary locks, water wear approaches, inlets or out-
lets, connected with or useful to the operators of said canal. When land cannot be obtained by agreement, the land taken for the canal shall not exceed one hundred and fifty yards in width, unless for buildings, waste water, locks, or other necessary conveniences, during the construction and operation of said canal.

Sec. 10. That said corporation shall have the right to cross all public highways and all railroads that it may be necessary to cross to establish and complete said canal, erecting such bridges and crossings as the vari-
ous cases may require.

Sec. 11. That the said canal company shall have the power to borrow money, issue bonds or bills of credit, with or without mortgage; pro-
vided, it is done in conformity to a vote of two-thirds of the directors; and generally, this company shall have all the power requisite to carry into effect the object of the company.

Sec. 12. That this canal shall be constructed not less than sixty feet wide at its surface, and of not less depth than three feet, with locks, when requisite, of sufficient capacity to pass boats, lumber rafts, or other craft at least twenty-five feet in width, and eighty feet in length; and that all boats, barges, rafts, or other craft, navigating or passing through this canal, shall be entitled to right of passage and locking in their due order of arrival.

Sec. 13. That said company are authorized to construct, own
Laws of the State of Texas.and navigate, any and all craft, boats, barges, required for transporta-
tion, either on the bodies of said canal, slack-waters created or existing, connected with the waters of the canal, or any navigable waters with which said canal may connect by lockage or otherwise; that the company shall be able to contract for and charge and collect pay, for the use of water drawn from the canal, for hydraulic power or for irrigation, at such rates and prices as may be agreed upon by parties wishing the use thereof; but in no case shall the said company flow lands to the detriment of owners without their consent or on due payment to the parties aggrieved.

Sec. 14. That this company shall have power to charge and collect such rates of freight and such water rates as they may deem just and proper; provided, that freight rates shall not exceed, by the pound avoirdupois or by the cubic foot, over the rates allowed by law on railroad freights over the same distance.

Sec. 15. The first meeting of the company shall be called by the commissioners, whenever one hundred thousand dollars of the capital stock shall have been subscribed, by giving thirty days’ notice, in some paper published in Houston, and the stockholders shall then proceed to elect directors, who shall hold office until the annual election, which shall take place in the city of Houston, on the first Monday of March in each year. Should a majority of the stock be represented, the election shall proceed; if not, the directors shall appoint another day, within thirty days thereafter, and an election on that day shall be valid. Direc-
tors elected under the provision hereof shall hold their office for one year, and until their successors are duly elected and qualified. No person shall be a director who does not own at least two shares of the company.

Sec. 16. That the charter shall remain in force and effect for the period of fifty years from the date of the completion, of said canal; that no taxes shall be levied on the stock of the company or the property of said company, by either the county or the State, until the work is com-
pleted, and for five years thereafter. The company shall be entitled to receive from the State such loans or assistance or advantages as may be granted to any canal company for a like number of miles of completed canal, within the State of Texas; and generally the company shall be en-
titled to and shall receive all the privileges and immunities to which companies engaged in internal improvements shall be entitled to receive or obtain from the State.
Sec. 17. That this act shall take effect and he in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XCIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Pacific and Great Eastern Railway Company of Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That J. S. Mills, Hugh Hudson, H. B. Adams, J. A. Williamson, Robert P. Robertson, A. B. Hall, John Orr, J. W Allen, D. R. Diffendorffer, W. H. Hamman, citizens of the State of Texas; Jesse Hoyt, Archibald M. Allerton and Alexander H. Sibley, of the State of New York; Sidney D. Miller and Simon Mandlebaum of the State of Michigan; Angus Smith and J. J. Peck, of the State of Wisconsin; Charles Morehead, Sid-
ney Ross of Kansas; J. Q. A. Saylor, of Iowa; George W. Cook, of New Mexico; Ambrose E. Burnside, of the State of Rhode Island; Chauncey J. Filley and W. H. Maurice, of Missouri; Henry Keyes, of the State of Vermont; C. W. Pierce, of the State of Massachusetts; M. La Rue Harri-
son and J. M. Johnson, of the State of Arkansas; Rush R. Sloan, S. S. L’Hommedieu, and Stillman Witt, of the State of Ohio; and J. Don Cam-
eron, G. C. Davis, John L. Speel, of the State of Pennsylvania; Joseph N. Vaughan, of Virgina, and H. B. Sherman, of the State of Mississippi, and all such other persons who shall or may be associated with them, and their successors, are hereby created and erected into a body corporate and politic, in deed and in law, by the name and title of “The Pacific and Great Eastern Railway Company of Texas,” and shall by that name have succession, and remain and be in force for the period of ninety-nine years; shall be able to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, defend and be defended in all the courts of the State, and shall have a common seal, and capacity to make contracts; to grant and receive; to make by-laws for their government and the management of their business, and generally do and perform all such acts and things as may be necessary and proper for, or incidental to the fulfillment of their obligations, or the main-
tenance of their rights under and by virtue of this act, and consistent with the Constitution of the United States and of this State; and the said company are hereby invested with the powers, privileges and im-
munities necessary and proper to carry into effect the purpose of this act, as herein set forth.

Sec. 2. The persons hereinbefore named are hereby constituted and appointed commissioners, and shall be called the Board of Com-
missioners of the Pacific and Great Eastern Railway Company of
Laws of the State of Texas.Texas, and any five of them shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. The first meeting of said board shall be held at Austin, on the first day of January, A. D. 1871, or at such time, within three months thereafter, as the said commissioners shall appoint, notice of which shall be given by a quorum, as above provided, to the other com-
missioners, by publishing said notice in one daily newspaper in Gal-
veston, Texas, and in the city of New York, for at least four weeks pre-
vious to the day of meeting. Said board shall organize by electing, by ballot, from its number, a president, vice-president, secretary and treas-
urer, and such officers as they shall deem necessary for their organiza-
tion, and they shall require from said treasurer such bonds as may be deemed proper, and may, from time to time, increase the amount there-
of as they may deem proper. The secretary shall be sworn to the faith-
ful performance of his duties, and such oath shall be entered upon the records of the company and signed by him. The president, secretary and treasurer, or any two of them, shall in like manner call all other meetings, designating the time thereof.

Sec. 3. It shall be the duty of said board of commissioners to open books, or cause books to be opened, at such time and in such of the prin-
cipal cities in the United States and Europe, as they, or a majority of a quorum of them shall determine, within twelve months after the pas-
sage of this act, to receive subscriptions to the capital stock of said corporation, and a cash payment of five per centum on all subscriptions, and to receipt therefor. And so soon as two thousand shares of the stock of said corporation shall, in good faith, be subscribed, and five dollars per share actually paid into the treasury of the company, the president, secretary and treasurer of said board of commissioners, or any two of them, shall apoint a time and place for the first meeting of the sub-
scribers to the stock of said company, and shall give notice thereof in at least one newspaper in each State in which subscription books have been opened, at least thirty days previous to the day of meeting; and such subscribers to said stock as shall attend the meeting so called, either in person or by lawful proxy, then and there shall elect, by ballot, nine directors for said corporation; and in such election each share of said capital stock shall entitle the owner thereof to one vote, which may be cast by the person owning such stock, either in per-
son or by proxy, authorized in writing. The president, secretary and treasurer, and such other officers as may have been appointed by said board of commissioners, shall then deliver over to the di-
rectors so elected, all the money and property whatsoever, subscrip-
tion books and other books in their possession, belonging to said company, taking their receipt therefor; and the organization and
Laws of the State of Texas.duties of said commissioners and officers previously appointed by them, shall cease and determine forever, and thereafter the stockholders shall constitute said body politic and corporate.

Sec. 4. And the said Pacific and Great Eastern Railway Company of Texas is hereby authorized and empowered to lay out, locate and con-
struct, furnish, maintain, own, operate and enjoy a continuous line of telegraph and railroad, together with all the rights and appurtenances to the same belonging, namely: crossing and beginning on Red River, in Texas, at or near the confluence of the Big Wichita and Red River, as may be expedient and most practicable; thence in a southwesterly di-
rection, on the most practicable and expedient route across the State of Texas to the Rio Grande river at such point, or near Presidio del Norte, as may be selected by said company, as affording the best facilities for a continuation of said railroad through the Republic of Mexico, in the direction of the harbor of Altata, on the Gulf of California.

Sec. 5. That the right of way through the public domain of the State of Texas is hereby granted to the Pacific and Great Eastern Rail-
way Company of Texas, its successors and assigns, for the construction of a railroad and telegraph, as herein proposed and designated; and the right, power and authority is hereby given to said company to take from the public lands adjacent to the line of said roads, material of earth, stone, timber, etc., for the construction thereof, and said right of way is granted to said company to the extent of one hundred feet in width on each side of said railroad where it may pass through the public do-
main, and also to include the necessary ground for station buildings, workshops, depots, machine shops, switches, side tracks, turn-tables and water stations, etc., including herein the right, so far as the jurisdiction of the State of Texas extends, to bridge the said Red and Rio Grande rivers; also, the right to cross the track of any other railroad along its line which it may intersect.

Sec. 6. That the said Pacific and Great Eastern Railway Company of Texas be and are hereby authorized and empowered to enter upon, purchase, take and hold any lands or premises necessary for the pur-
pose of establishing and constructing said railroad and telegraph line, and all depots, stations, turnouts, standing places for cars, or any other structures required in constructing and operating said road; pro-
vided, always, that the lands and premises so taken for the road-bed shall not exceed two hundred feet, and that for depots, turnouts, machine shops and other purposes, only such further width as may be necessary for such purposes. And the said company shall have the right to cut down and remove trees and any other matter that
Laws of the State of Texas.may, by falling or otherwise, encumber its road-bed, though standing or being more than two hundred feet from the bed of said road.

Sec. 7. That if any person or persons, whose lands and premises may be taken for the uses aforesaid of said railroad, and the said company can-
not agree as to the value thereof, either party may apply to the District Court of the county in which said lands and premises are situated, for the appointment of commissioners, and said court shall thereupon, in va-
cation or term time, appoint three disinterested freeholders of said coun-
ty, who shall appoint a time to view the land and premises aforesaid, and hear the owner thereof and the said company, to whom shall be given, by said commissioners, reasonable notice of the time and place of said hearing; and said commissioners, after being first duly sworn, and after hearing the parties, shall determine the amount of compensation, if any, to which the owner of the land and premises shall be entitled, and make return of their proceedings and of their award to the next succeeding term of said court; and said award, if not rejected by said court for cause then shown, shall be entered up as a judgment of said court. In deter-
mining the amount of compensation, said commissioners shall be govern-
ed by the actual value of the property at the time it was taken, regarding the benefits and injuries done to other lands or premises of the owner by the establishment of said railroad. During the inquiry as to the value of said land, said company shall in no manner be molested or hindered in the prosecution of their work thereon, or the occupation and use there-
of. The payment into court for the use of the owner of said land and premises so taken, a sum equal to that finally awarded shall be held to vest in said company the title to said land and premises, and of the right to use and occupy the same for the construction, maintenance and operation of said railroad.

Sec. 8. And in case any of the lands to be taken as aforesaid, shall be owned and held by an infant, insane person, or person subject to any legal disability, the court may appoint a guardian for any party under such disability to appear in person, and who shall give bond with suf-
ficient sureties for the proper and faithful execution of his trust, and who shall represent in court the person disqualified as aforesaid, when the same proceedings shall be had in reference to the appraisement of the land and premises to be taken for the use of the company as aforesaid, and with the same effect as already described. The title of the said company to the lands and premises taken by this act shall not be affected or im-
paired by reason of any failure by any guardian to discharge faithfully his trust. In case any party shall have a right to any land for a, term of years, or any interest therein, in possession, reversion or remainder, the value
Laws of the State of Texas.of such estate, less than fee simple, shall be estimated and determined in the manner hereinbefore provided.

Sec. 9. When it shall be necessary for said company to enter upon any lands and premises which are unoccupied, and of which there is no apparent owner or claimant, or of a person who resides beyond the limits of the State, said company may take and use the same for the purposes aforesaid, and may institute proceedings in the manner described for the purpose of establishing the value thereof, and of acquiring title to the same; but the judge of the court hearing said suit shall determine the kind of notice to be given to such, owner or owners; and he may, in his discretion, appoint an agent or guardian to represent such owner or own-
ers in case of his or their incapacity or non-appearance. But in the event that no owner shall appear within five years from the time of open-
ing said road across any lands, all claim to damage against said company shall be barred.

Sec. 10. The directors chosen in accordance with the provisions of this act shall, so soon as may be thereafter, elect from their own number a president and vice-president; and said directors shall, from time to time, so soon as may be after their election, choose a sercretary and treasure, who shall hold their offices at the will and pleasure of the said directors. The secretary and treasurer shall give such bonds with such securities as the said directors may, from time to time, require. The secretary shall, before entering upon his duties, be sworn to the faithful discharge there-
of, and the said oath shall be made a matter of record upon the books of said corporation. No person shall be a director of said company unless he shall be a stockholder thereof, and qualified to vote for directors at the election at which he shall be chosen.

Sec. 11. The immediate control and direction of the business and af-
fairs of said company shall be vested in the directors aforesaid, of whom five, including the president, and, in his absence, the vice-president, shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. The president, vice-presi-
dent and directors shall hold their offices for a period to be fixed in the by-laws of said company, not to exceed two years, respectively, and until others are chosen and qualified. If it shall so happen that an election of directors shall not be made on any day appointed in the by-laws of said company, the corporation shall not for that reason be dissolved. The di-
rectors shall have full power to make and publish such by-laws, rules and regulations as shall be needful and proper for the disposition and manage-
ment of the stock, property, estate and effects of the company; to pre-
scribe the duty of the officers and regulate the conduct of the servants, and the elections and meetings of the directors, and the general business
Laws of the State of Texas.of the corporation. They shall have power to fill any vacancy or va-
cancies that may occur, from any cause, in said board of directors, and the officers so appointed shall hold their appointments until next regular election thereafter. The directors shall, at the meeting of the stock-
holders, which shall be every year, submit the by-laws of said company for the ratification of said stockholders.

Sec. 12. The said Pacific and Great Eastern Railway Company of Texas and telegraph line, shall be constructed in a substantial and work-
manlike manner, with all the necessary draws, culverts, bridges, viaducts, crossings, turnouts, stations, watering places and all other appurtenances, including rolling stock, equal in all respects to the first class railroads, when prepared for business; and it shall be the duty of the Pacific and Great Eastern Railway Company of Texas, to permit any other rail-
road, authorized to be built by the United States, or by the Legislature of the State of Texas, or any other State, to form running connection with it on fair and equitable terms; and said company shall also have the right to cross the track of any other railway, which their road may inter-
sect, along its line.

Sec. 13. The directors of said company shall make and publish an annual report of their proceedings and expenditures, verified, by the affi-
davits of the president, or in his absence, by the vice-president and at least four of the directors, a copy of which shall be deposited in the office of the Comptroller of the State; and they shall, from time to time, fix, determine and regulate the fares, rates and charges to be received and paid for transportation of persons and property on said railroad, or any part thereof, within the limits prescribed by State laws.

Sec. 14. The capital stock of said company shall not exceed twenty-
five million dollars, which shall be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each. Each share shall entitle the owner thereof to one vote, either personally or by proxy, constituted in writing, at all the meetings of the stockholders; provided, that any action or vote of three-fourths of said stock, by vote at any meeting of said stockholders, shall be bind-
ing on all the stock of said corporation. Said stock shall, in all respects, be deemed personal estate, and shall be transferable in such manner as the laws of said corporation shall provide.

Sec. 15. The said croporation shall have power, and they are hereby authorized to borrow money and to purchase property, upon their own credit, for the purpose of constructing and maintaining and operating their railroads and telegraph lines, and they may issue bonds and obligations therefor, payable at such time and place, and at such rates of interest as the directors of said company shall di-
Laws of the State of Texas.rect; and to secure the payment of said bonds or obligations, may mort-
gage their railroad and telegraph line, their capital stock, their corporate franchises, and any and all property, real and personal, or any part or portion thereof, in such manner and form as said company or its di-
rectors shall deem best and most expedient.

Sec. 16. It shall be lawful for the directors of said company to re-
quire payment of the sum of five per centum cash assessment upon sub-
scription received of all subscribers, and the balance thereof at such times and in such proportions and on such conditions as they shall deem to be necessary to complete said road and telegraph line within the time this act prescribes. Sixty days’ previous notice shall be given of the payments required, and the time and place of payment, by publishing a notice thereof once a week in one daily newspaper in each of the cities of New York, St. Louis, Galveston and Austin; and in case any stock-
holder shall neglect or refuse to pay, in pursuance of such notice, the stock held by such person shall be forfeited to the company, and also any payments that shall have been made on account thereof, subject to the condition that the directors may allow the redemption thereof, sub-
ject to such terms as they may prescribe; and provided, that said stock, at the time of the failure to pay as aforesaid, shall not be the property of a minor or person of unsound mind.

Sec. 17. That the said company is hereby authorized to accept to their own use any grant, donation, loan, power, franchise, aid or assist-
ance which may be granted to or conferred upon said company; and said corporation are authorized to hold and enjoy any such grant, donation, loan, power, franchise, aid or assistance to their own use, for the pur-
poses aforesaid.

Sec. 18. That each and every grant, right and privilege herein are so made, and given to and accepted by the Pacific and Great Eastern Railway Company of Texas, upon the following conditions, namely: that the said company shall commence the work, and complete fifty miles of said road within three years from the first day of January, 1871, and one hundred miles every two years thereafter, until their road is com-
pleted; and that, unless the said company shall obtain a bona fide sub-
scription to their stock, to the amount of five hundred thousand dollars, within two years from the date of the passage of this act, it shall be null and void.
Sec. 19. That this act shall be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XCIV.

opener.salute:
An Act supplementary to “An Act to incorporate the Victoria and Co-
lumbia Railroad Company,” approved November 13, 1866.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the charter of said company, approved November 13, 1866, is here-
by revived and made valid, and in order that no doubt may exist as to the validity of said charter, and all the rights and privileges therein con-
ferred, the same is hereby recognized as being in full force and effect, except the rights and privileges contained in section eleven of said origi-
nal charter.

Sec. 2. The time for the commencement of the railroad named herein and provided for in the twelfth section of the above recited act, to which this is a supplement, is hereby extended to the first day of January, 1872, and said company shall have the right to complete the first twenty-five miles of said road and put the same in running order by or before the first day of January, 1873, any provision in said act to the contrary not-
withstandina:.

Sec. 3. That John Duncan, E. S. Rugeley, A. H. Cromwell, Richard Owens, Thomas M. Harwood, Richard King and William P. Hardeman are hereby named as commissioners to organize said company pursuant to the terms of said charter, the commissioners heretofore named and appointed in the first section of said act having failed to organize the same; and all the rights, powers and duties granted to or required of the commissioners appointed in the first section of said act by the terms thereof, are hereby conferred on and required of the said commissioners herein named.

Sec. 4. Said company are hereby authorized to extend their railroad from the town of Victoria to the Rio Grande river, striking said river at or below Laredo, and to this end are hereby granted the right of way from the town of Victoria to the Rio Grande river upon the same terms and conditions as that part of their line from Columbia to Victoria, and all the rights, privileges and interests of every character granted in said original act, for that part, of said road between Columbia and Victoria, are hereby conferred, and vested, in every respect whatsoever, upon that part of their line beyond Victoria to the Rio Grande river, so that the same shall be in effect one and the same line; and the said company are hereby authorized to enlarge their capital stock to ten millions dollars.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 5. Said company are further authorized to construct branch rail-
roads from any points on their main line to such points on the Gulf of Mexico as they may deem best; provided, said branch railroads do not affect injuriously any roads now chartered; said branch railroads to be entitled to all the rights and privileges and subject to all the restrictions relating to their said main line.

Sec. 6. If the State of Texas hereafter passes any general law, the ob-
ject of which is to aid in the construction of railroads, thereupon the com-
pany owning this charter will he invested with all the rights and privi-
leges conferred by said law on any other company.

div3.head: CHAPTER XCV.

opener.salute: An Act to establish the Sabine Pass and Red River Railway Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature at the State of Texas, That a body politic and corporate be and the same is hereby created and established, under the name and style of the “Sabine Pass and Red River Railway Company,” with the capacity to make contracts; to have succes-
sion and a common seal; to make by-laws for its government, and in its corporate name to sue and be sued; to grant and to receive, and generally to do and perform all such acts and things as may be necessary and proper for, or incident to the fulfillment of its obligations, or the main-
tenance of its rights under this act, and consistent with the provisions of the Constitution of this State.

Sec. 2. That the said company be, and hereby is invested with the right of making, owning and maintaining a railway from Sabine Pass through, in as direct line as practicable, the counties of Jefferson, Jasper, Panola, the city of Jefferson, in Marion county, and through the county of Bowie to Red River; with the privilege of making, owning and main-
taining such branches to the railway as they may deem expedient.

Sec. 3. That Thomas C. Durant, Russell Sturgis, William B. Duncan, A. EL Barney, John A. Griswold and Henry C. Crane, and such other persons as they may associate with them for the pur-
pose, are hereby appointed commissioners, and invested with the right and privilege of forming and organizing the said company, of
Laws of the State of Texas.obtaining subscriptions to the capital stock, and distributing the shares thereof, and generally of taking such lawful measures, to secure the effectual organization and successful operation of said company, as they may deem expedient.

Sec. 4. That the meetings of the commissioners provided for by this act may be held at such times and places as they may appoint; and, at said meetings, the commissioners may act in person or by proxy.

Sec. 5. The capital stock of said company, to consist of all its prop-
erty, real and personal, franchises and rights of property, shall be di-
vided into shares of one hundred dollars each; each share entitling the owner thereof to one vote, by himself or proxy, at all meetings of said company. The said shares shall be deemed personal estate, and shall be transferable by any conveyance in writing, recorded by the treasurer in the books kept by him at his office, or in such other manner as the by-
laws of said company shall provide.

Sec. 6. The immediate government and direction of the affairs of said company shall be vested in a board of not less than six directors, who shall elect one of their own number a president of said company. No person shall be eligible to the office of director unless an owner or subscriber of at least five shares of the stock of said company. The di-
rectors shall have the power to fill any vacancy that may occur in said board from non-election, death or otherwise, and may appoint a secre-
tary, treasurer and such other officers and agents as they may consider necessary, and prescribe and require bonds for the faithful performance of their duties; they may, if not otherwise provided by the by-laws, de-
termine the manner of conducting all meetings, the number of members that shall constitute a quorum, and to do, or cause to be done, all other lawful matters and things which they may deem necessary and proper, in conducting the matters of the company. They shall keep, or cause to be kept, accurate records of all meetings of the directors and com-
pany, and accurate books of accounts of the receipts and expenditures of the company, and all other books necessary and proper to be kept by the company, which shall be open to the inspection of the stock-
holders; a majority of the board of directors shall have the authority of a full board, and all conveyances and contracts in writing, executed by the president, and countersigned by the secretary, or any other officer or person authorized by the directors, under the seal of the company, and in pursuance of a vote of said directors, shall be valid and binding.

Sec. 7. The shares may be disposed of, and books, opened for subscriptions thereto, in such manner and on such terms as said com-
Laws of the State of Texas.missioners shall determine will be best for the interest of said company; and any agreement in writing, by which any person shall become a sub-
scriber to the capital stock of said company, may be enforced against him according to its terms; and if any subscriber shall fail to pay any amount due upon shares subscribed by him, according to the terms of his subscription, the directors may sell at auction and transfer to the purchaser the shares of such delinquent; and if the proceeds of sale shall not be sufficient to pay the amount due on said subscription, with the interest and charges, such delinquent shall be held liable to the com-
pany for the deficiency; and if the proceeds shall exceed the amount so due, with the interest and charges, said delinquent shall be entitled to the surplus. The said company is hereby authorized to borrow money from time to time, for the construction of their railway, and to secure such loan by pledging and mortgaging the property, both real, personal and mixed, of said company, and to issue bonds, with interest warrants annexed, and payable at such time and place, and at such rate of in-
terest, as the directors may deem proper.

Sec. 8. It shall be lawful for the company to enter upon and pur-
chase and otherwise take and hold, any lands necessary for the purpose of establishing and constructing said railway, with all necessary depots and other buildings; and if they shall not be able to obtain said lands by agreement with the owner thereof, they shall pay therefor such com-
pensation as shall be determined in the manner provided by the follow-
ing section; provided, that the lands so taken for the road bed shall not exceed two hundred feet in width, and for depots and other buildings, only such further width as shall be needed for such purposes.

Sec. 9. Any person, when land has been taken as aforesaid, without agreement or satisfactory compensation, may apply to the District Court of the county in which said land is situated, for the appointment of, and said court shall thereupon appoint three disinterested freeholders of the county, who shall appoint a time and place to hear the applicant and the company, to whom shall be given, by said freeholders, reasonable notice of the said time and place; and said freeholders shall, after being sworn, and after due hearing of the parties, determine the amount of compensa-
tion, if any, to which the applicant may be entitled, and to make return of their award to the next succeeding term of said court; and said award, if not rejected by said court for sufficient cause then shown, shall be en-
tered up as the judgment of said court. In determining the question of compensation, said freeholders shall be governed by the actual value of the land at the time it was taken, taking into consideration the benefits or injury done to other lands and property of the owner, by
Laws of the State of Texas.the establishment of said, railway; and if the amount of compensation awarded by said freeholders shall not exceed the amount offered by said company to the owner, prior to said application to the court, the appli-
cant shall pay the cost of the proceedings, otherwise the company shall pay the same.

Sec. 10. It shall be the duty of said company, whenever any State or county road now by law established, shall be crossed by the track of said railway, to make and keep in repair, good and sufficient causeways and crossings; and in all cases when any person who shall own lands on both sides of said railway, and there shall be no other convenient access from one part to the other, such owner shall have the right of passage, free of cost, at all reasonable times, across the track of said railway.

Sec. 11. This company is hereby required, at all reasonable times, and for a reasonable compensation, to draw over their road the passengers, merchandise and cars of any other railroad corporation which has been, or hereafter may be authorized by the Legislature to enter with their railroad, and connect with the railroad of this company; and if the re-
spective companies shall be unable to agree upon the compensation afore-
said, it shall be the duty of the president of each company to select, each, one man as a commissioner, and the two commissioners so selected shall choose a third in case of disagreement, neither of whom shall be a stock-
holder in either road, or interested therein, and they shall fix the rates, which shall not be changed for one year from the time of going into effect. The said commissioners shall also fix the stated periods at which said cars are to be drawn as aforesaid, having reference to the convenience and interests of said corporations and the public who will be accommo-
dated thereby. The right of power is specially conferred on this said company to connect and contract with any railroad company chartered by this State, for the performance of like transport; and in case of dis-
agreement between said companies, the same shall be referred and settled as aforesaid, and be binding for one year as aforesaid.

Sec. 12. That the said company may acquire real estate by gift or purchase, and that such commissioners, hereinbefore mentioned, shall have full authority to solicit and receive subscriptions and conveyances of land to said company, until the time fixed for the first meeting of the commissioners, which authority may be extended by said meeting; which land, so obtained, shall be alienated by said company in the following manner: one-fourth in six years, the one-fourth in eight years, the one-
fourth in ten years, and the other fourth in twelve years from the time the same was acquired.

Sec. 13. If the track of this railway shall cross any navigable
Laws of the State of Texas.stream, it shall clo it in such way as not to obstruct its navigation. The said company shall have the right to cross any navigable stream, by ferry, bridge or otherwise, and shall have the right to acquire and exercise such ferry privileges as may be necessary for its business, and said road cross-
ing any such streams, by a good and convenient ferry, shall be considered as continuous as if crossing upon a bridge; provided, the same shall not obstruct the navigation of any such stream.

Sec; 14. Said company shall have the right to demand and receive such rates and prices for the transportation of passengers and freight, as they may think proper to establish, not to exceed five cents per mile for passengers, and fifty cents per hundred pounds for freight, for every hundred miles the same may be carried.

Sec. 15. If any person shall wilfully injure or obstruct sand rail-
way or its property, such person may be punished, when prosecuted by indictment for said offense in due course of law, and also liable to action by said company, or any person whatever who may suffer in person or property from said wilful obstruction, for the amount of damages oc-
casioned thereby.

Sec. 16. Said company shall be required to have a good and sui-
ficient brake upon every car in all trains transporting passengers or mer-
chandise, and also permanently stationed there a trusty and skillful brakesman, under a penalty not exceeding the sum of one hundred dollars for each offense, to be recovered in any court of competent jurisdiction, for the benefit of the State; and said company shall cause to be placed on each locomotive engine passing over the road, a bell of the weight of at least thirty-five pounds, or a steam whistle, and the said bell shall be rung, or the whistle blown, at a distance of at least eighty rods from the place of crossing any highway or turnpike, and kept ringing or blowing until the engine has passed or stopped. Said company shall be required to construct their railroad with good “T” or “V” iron rails.
Sec. 17. Nothing in this act shall be so construed as to confer banking privileges or powers of any kind whatever.

Sec. 18. If said railway shall not be commenced within one year from the passage of this act, and at least twenty-five miles thereof are not completed within two years, then this charter shall be null and void. And it is hereby provided and declared, that it shall be lawful for any other railway, hereafter to be constructed, to cross the said railway, or any branch thereof, or to connect with any point therewith; provided, that should any unforeseen cause, such as epidemic, war, revolution or internal strife ensue, so as to hinder the construction of said road thereby, the time the company may be thus hindered shall be excepted out of the limitation above named,
Laws of the State of Texas.and a certificate from the Governor certifying the time of such detention, filed with the Secretary of State, shall be taken, deemed and held as an exemption from the limitation as above provided.

Sec. 19. The said company shall have the right to take and hold as much of the public land, not exceeding two hundred feet wide, as the said railway, or any of its branches, may pass through, for the track thereof, and such additional width as may be absolutely necessary for any depot or other work, for the purpose of the railway, that the com-
pany may deem proper to establish.
Sec. 20. Nothing contained in this act shall authorize or allow the company established by this act to run over or across the track of any railway now constructed between Sabine Pass and Beaumont.

div3.head: CHAPTER XCVI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Jefferson and Shreveport Railroad Company; to provide the ways and means for constructing and maintaining their road, and to authorize the sale of said road, and the acquisition by the company of other road or roads.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Donald Campbell, Wm. M. Harrison, Samuel M. Hart, John A. Bridgland, John Speake, and their associates and successors, are hereby created a body corporate, in deed and in law, to be known by the name, style and title of the “Jefferson and Shreveport Railroad Company,” and by that name shall be able to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, and shall have succession for ninety-nine years, and make and have a common seal; and the said corporation is hereby authorized and empow-
ered to lay out, locate, construct, equip and thereafter to own, maintain, operate and enjoy a continuous single or double track railway from the city of Jefferson, in the State of Texas, and running from thence to any point on the boundary line dividing the States of Texas and Louisiana, by such route as the company may deem proper and practicable, with a view of continuing and completing the said railroad to Shreveport, in the State of Louisiana.

Sec. 2. That the capital stock of said company shall be fixed
Laws of the State of Texas.at one million of dollars, in shares of one hundred dollars each, with power to said company to increase its capital stock to two millions of dollars; and the stock of said company shall be deemed personal prop-
erty, and shall be transferable on the books of the company, at such trans-
fer office as the company may establish, and under such rules and regula-
tions as the company may prescribe.

Sec. 3. That the domicile of this company be fixed in the city of Jefferson; the business of the corporation shall be conducted at its dom-
icile in the city of Jefferson by the corporators, or a majority thereof, until the election of a board of directors under this act; all service of process may be made upon a president, to be elected by the corporators until the organization of a board of directors, and thereafter upon the president of the company elected by the board, or, in case of his ab-
sence, upon the president pro tem.; the said corporators shall open books of subscription to the stock of said company; a payment of five per cent. on the amount of each share shall be made at the time of subscribing; the subsequent payments shall be made in such sums and at such periods as shall be fixed by the board of directors. As soon as one hundred thou-
sand dollars of the stock of said company shall have been subscribed, and the first payment of five per cent. thereof paid to a treasurer elected by said corporators, a meeting of the stockholders shall be called, which stockholders shall elect a board of directors, to consist of five or more members who shall be stockholders; the said call and election shall be made and held under such inspectors or tellers, and with such regulations as the corporators may prescribe; a majority of the corporators named in this act shall be a quorum for the transaction of business; after the elec-
tion of a board of directors, a quorum thereof shall be a majority of the board; the directors shall meet and elect one of their body as president of the company as soon as practicable after their election; the board of directors shall have power to elect such further officers as, in their opinion, the board or the road may require; after the first year, all shares of stock must be owned and possessed by each voter in his own right, or that of his principal, if held by proxy, sixty days before voted on; votes may be given in person or by proxy; the term of office of each board of directors shall be one year; and no act of any board shall be valid after the close of its year of service, except the calling of and election by the stockholders for a board of directors; in default of such call being pre-
viously made, any ten stockholders may make such call.

Sec. 4. That the board of directors may make such rules, regu-
lations and by-laws, for the government of its officers and the man-
agement of its business as they may deem expedient, and may de-
Laws of the State of Texas.termine when the subscription books hereby authorized to be opened for subscription to the capital stock shall be closed, and may fix the time and place for holding annual meetings of stockholders for the election of di-
rectors; may fill vacancies that may occur in their board, and may, in the name and on behalf of said company, make such contracts, enter into such engagements, and do and perform all such acts as they or a majority of them may deem proper, convenient or necessary for the accomplish-
ment of the objects for which said company is created.

Sec. 5. That said Jefferson and Shreveport Railroad Company be, and the same is hereby authorized and empowered to enter upon, purchase, take and hold any lands that may be necessary and proper for the con-
struction and uses of said railroad, not exceeding one hundred feet on each side of its centre line, together with such other lands and premises as may be required by said company for excavation or embankment, or for turnouts, depots, station houses, docks, wharves, or other purposes in the conduct of the business of said railway; adequate compensation to be given to, or satisfactory settlement to be made with all owners of prop-
erty so to be taken and used by said company; and the right of way is hereby granted to said Jefferson and Shreveport Railroad Company, through any and all lands belonging to the State of Texas, and through which said railroad may pass, to the distance of two hundred yards on each side of the centre line of said railroad; and said company is author-
ized to enter upon any lands owned by the State of Texas, and adjacent to the line of said company’s railroad, and take and remove therefrom, and appropriate to the use of said company, any timber, earth or other ma-
terial.

Sec. 6. That in case any lands, through which said company may con-
clude to construct its railway, belong to the estate of any deceased person, it may then contract therefor with the executor or administrator of such; or in case such lands belong to a minor or to a person non compos men-
tis, then with his guardian or tutor; or in case said lands be held by trustees of school sections, or other trustees of estate, then with such trustees of estates; and such executors, administrators, tutors, guardians and trutees are hereby declared competent for such estate, person or minor, to contract with said company to use, occupy and possess the lands of such estates, persons and minors or trustees, so far as may be use-
ful and necessary for the purposes of said railroad; and the act and deed of such executors, administrators, tutors, guardians or trustees, in rela-
tion thereto, shall pass a title in such lands in the same manner as if the said deed or act were made or done by a legal owner of full age and sound mind; and such executor, administrator, tutor, guardian or
Laws of the State of Texas.trustee shall account to those interested in theirrespective bonds, for the amount paid in pursuance of such agreement and composition; and if the said company and the parties representing lands prefer, they may refer the question of compensation to arbitrators mutually chosen, whose award, or that of their umpire (in case of disagreement,) shall vest title accord-
ing to its terms.

Sec. 7. That if said company is unable to agree for the purchase of any real estate, or of the right of way thereupon, or any estate therein required for the purposes and uses of said company, or is unable to obtain the title or right of way therein, it shall have the right to acquire title to the same in the following manner: the said company may apply to a court of competent jurisdiction over the county in which the land, the title whereof is sought, is situated, for the appointment of commission-
ers of appeal at any general or special term, or to any judge thereof in vacation; such application shall be made in writing, and signed by the president or one of the directors of said company authorized for that pur-
pose, and shall substantially set forth and state:
First. The court wherein, or the judge to whom the application is made, and the character of the application.
Second. The name and official character of the person applying in behalf of the company.
Third. The metes and bounds of the real estate which the company seek to acquire; and several parcels of land owned by different persons may be included in one application.
Fourth. That the company has not been able to acquire the estate in said lands required, and the reasons of such inability.

Fifth. The names of all parties or owners interested in said real es-
tate, so far as the same are known to the applicant, must be set forth, and if not known, that fact must be stated; a copy of such application, and notice of the time and place the same will be presented, must be served on all persons named in said application as owners or interested in said real estate, at least ten days prior to the presentation of the same; provided, such owners so named are residents and can be found within the State of Texas, and are not infants, idiots, or persons of unsound mind; in that case, upon their tutors, curators or guardians.

Sec. 8. That on presentation of the application to the court or judge therein named, and no person appearing to oppose said application, and whenever it shall satisfactorily appear from said application and proofs thereunto attached, that service of the notice of the time and place of the presentation of said application upon all the owners and persons interested in said land has been made, the said court or judge thereof shall forthwith make an order appointing
Laws of the State of Texas.three disinterested and competent freeholders, who reside in the county where the premises are situated, or an adjoining county thereto, as com-
missioners to ascertain and appraise the compensation to be made to the owners or persons interested in the real estate proposed to be taken by the said company for its purposes, and shall fix the time and place for the first meeting of said commissioners. In case any person who shall be the owner, or who shall have a vested interest in said premises, shall appear at the time and place of the presentation of such application, the said court or judge, before making said appointment of commissioners, may hear such person and said company in relation to any person proposed for appointment as such commissioners, their place of residence, their competency and interest, and after such hearing the said court or judge shall make an appointment of three commissioners as aforesaid, in accord-
ance with the discretion or judgment of said court or judge. In case it shall appear by said application that any person, or any of the persons owning or interested in the said premises described in the application, or any part of the same, are not known to the said company, or are not resi-
dent of the comity wherein said real estate is situated, or cannot be found therein after due diligence, or are infants, idiots, or persons of unsound mind, then and in such case the said court or judge, before making said appointment of commissioners, shall make such inquiries as to such own-
ers and parties interested in said premises, and shall make such orders for service of notice upon them, or upon any person in regard to such appli-
cation, and such other order or orders in the premises as the court or judge may deem necessary, proper and just, and shall then make such appoint-
ment of commissioners as aforesaid, and in connection therewith make such orders, as to the service of any future notice upon the owners of said premises, of the meeting and appraisement of said commissioners, and the confirmation of the same, as may seem to said court or judge equitable and just.

Sec. 9. That the commissioners so appointed, or a majority of them, shall hold their first meeting at a time and place appointed by the court or judge, and may adjourn, from time to time, at their discretion; they shall take and subscribe an oath, before any officer authorized to adminis-
ter oaths, in the State of Texas, to the effect that they and each of them will impartially and to the best of their judgment and ability perform the duties of said commissioner; and any one of said commissioners may issue subpoenas and administer oaths to witnesses. Whenever they meet to take testimony or hear the parties, except by the appointment of the said court or judge, or pursuant to adjournment, they shall cause reasonable notice of such meeting to be given to any of the parties in interest, who shall
Laws of the State of Texas.have theretofore appeared before them, or to their agent or attorney. They shall hear the proofs and allegations of the parties, and reduce the same to writing; and after all the testimony offered in the case, that, in the judgment of said commissioners, is pertinent to the value of said premises, is taken they, or a majority of them, shall, without any un-
necessary delay, ascertain and determine the compensation which ought justly and equitably to be made by said company to the owners or persons interested in said real estate appraised by them; and said commissioners shall take into consideration the advantages that the said owners or per-
sons interested in the said real estate may derive from the construction of said proposed railroad for which said real estate is proposed to be taken. They shall make a report in writing to the court or judge by whom they were appointed, which shall contain the proceedings in the cases before them, with the minutes of the testimony taken by them, if any, and their award and determination. They shall be compensated for services as such commissioners, by the said company, at the rate of five dollars per day for actual service.

Sec. 10. That on such report being made by such commissioners, the court or judge shall appoint a time or place for the hearing of said com-
pany, and all parties interested in said lands, in regard to the confirma-
tion of said report, and shall, by order, direct the manner and form of the service of any notice of the same upon any persons that, in the judgment of the said court or judge, should be notified; and on the day of such hearing, if no person should appear to oppose the confirmation of said report, the same shall be confirmed by the said court or judge, and an order shall be made reciting the proceedings of the appraisal, the con-
firmation of the same, and a description of the real estate, and directing to whom the money or value of said real estate is to be paid, or in what manner the same shall be deposited by said company for the use and benefit of said owner; and if any person shall appear to oppose the con-
firmation of said report, the said court or judge shall hear the parties for and against the confirmation; and if said court or judge shall decide in favor of said confirmation, then the same proceedings shall be had in the premises as heretofore provided, in case no person appear to oppose said confirmation; and if said court or judge shall decide against such con-
firmation, an order shall be entered directing said commissioners, or other commissioners named in said order, to proceed to a re-appraisal of the said premises, the proceedings of which shall be afterwards conducted as in the first instance, except that the appraisal and report of the commissioners, in the appraisal order, shall be final, and shall be confirmed by said court or judge; and the order of said court or judge, confirming any ap-
Laws of the State of Texas.praisal as aforesaid, shall be final and conclusive on all parties interested; provided, that any party to said decree shall have the right to appeal, ac-
cording to law, from any decree adverse to their interests, or the inter-
ests of those they may represent.

Sec. 11. That the order of said court or judge confirming an appraisal of lands, as heretofore provided, or a certified copy of the same, shall be filed in the office of the clerk of the court having jurisdiction over the district in which the real estate appraised shall be situated, and there shall remain a record; and such order so entered and filed shall vest in said company the lands described therein, and such estate as may therein be set forth, on the payment or tender of payment or deposit of the amount of the appraisal and damages by said company, as provided in said order; or a duly certified copy thereof, with proof of such payment and deposit as therein provided, will be considered as a legal evidence of the title and estate of said company to the real estate acquired by the ap-
praisal by said company under and in pursuance to this act, and said title and estate shall be deemed to be acquired for public use.

Sec. 12. That the said company is hereby authorized to obtain, by grant or otherwise, from any county, incorporated city, town or village, within the State of Texas, that may be situated upon its railroad, any rights, privileges or franchises, that any county, incorporated city, town or village, may choose to grant in reference to the construction, main-
tenance and management of the railroad of said company, its depots, ears, locomotives, and its business, within the limits of such county, in-
corporated city, town or village; and any such county, incorporated city, town or village, as hereinbefore named, is hereby authorized and em-
powered to grant to said company any such rights, privileges and fran-
chises, as it may deem proper and advisable; and such rights, privileges and franchises, when granted to and accepted by said company, from any such county, incorporated city, town or village, shall be deemed and taken as rights, privileges and franchises, vested and confirmed in said com-
pany, and not liable to be hereafter revoked, changed, altered or im-
paired, except with the consent of said company.

Sec. 13. That said company is authorized and empowered, from time to time, to borrow money or to purchase property upon its own credit, for the purpose of constructing and maintaing said railroad, or estab-
lishing continuous and connecting lines of railroad; and as evidence of the indebtedness of said company for such loans, or the purchase of such property, may issue its corporate bonds or promissory notes, bear-
ing interest at a rate not to exceed eight per centum per annum, and to secure the payment of said bonds and notes, may mortgage its railroads, its capital stock, its corporate franchises,
Laws of the State of Texas.and any and all of its real and personal property, or any part or portion of the same; and it may, by its president or other officers or agents, duly authorized by its directors, sell, dispose of, negotiate such bonds or notes, or may sell, dispose of or negotiate its capital stock, or any of its per-
sonal property, at such times and places, and at such rates and for such prices, either within or without this State as, in the judgment of said company or its directors, will best advance its interests; and if such bonds, notes or stocks are thus sold at a discount, such sale shall be in all respects valid and binding upon this company, and such stocks, bonds or notes shall be as valid for the par value thereof, as if the same had been sold at par value.

Sec. 14. That the said company, with the consent of the owners of lands fronting upon any navigable water course, or after such lands have been acquired by the company by purchase, release, donation or in any other manner, in accordance with the laws of the State of Texas, may erect, construct and thereafter maintain and use wharves, warehouses, depots or other buildings and structures in and upon the margins, or upon the portions of the margins, reserved to public use, of any and all navigable rivers, bayous or water courses in the State of Texas, whenever the same may be deemed, by a majority of the directors of the company, necessary for the legitimate and convenient transaction of the business of the company, and within the limits of incorporated cities or towns, the mayor and a majority of the council of such city or town may authorize the construction of said wharves, warehouses, depots, or other build-
ings and structures, in front of all public squares or streets, that may be bounded by such navigable water courses.

Sec. 15. That the said company he, and it is hereby fully authorized and empowered, at such time or times, and upon such terms and condi-
tions as to the said company may seen right and proper,, to sell, assign, transfer or convey to any person or persons, or to any body politic or cor-
porate whatsoever, the whole or any part of the railroad of said company within the State of Texas, together with the right of way, road-bed, rails, depots, stations, shops, buildings, machinery, tools, engines, cars and real and personal estate within the State of Texas, appurtenant to, or necessary for the operation of said road, owned by the said company at the date of such sale, assignment, transfer, or conveyance, or thereafter to be acquired, and also the corporate franchises and privileges of said com-
pany, granted or to be granted by the State of Texas, relative to the con-
struction, operation or use of said road. And the said company is fur-
ther authorized and empowered, at such time or times, in such way or manner, and upon such terms and conditions, as the said company may deeem right and proper, to acquire from any person
Laws of the State of Texas.or persons, or from any body politic or corporate, or from any company whatsoever, the railroad owned by such person or persons, corporate body or company within the State of Texas; also the right of way, road-bed, rails, depots, stations, shops, buildings, machinery, tools, engines, cars and real and personal estate within the State of Texas, appurtenant to, or necessary for the operation of the road to be acquired by the Jefferson and Shreveport Railroad Company, together with the franchises and priv-
ileges belonging to the person or persons, body corporate or companies, from whom the road is acquired as aforesaid.

Sec. 16. That should the State of Texas hereafter adopt a general system to aid in the construction or maintenance of railroads within the State, all the rights and privileges granted by such general law or system, shall inure to the benefit and advantage of the Jefferson and Shreveport Railroad Company; and the said company, should it so desire, shall be considered as embraced by the provisions of the general system or law referred to in this section.

Sec. 17. That in case the said company should fail to complete the road from Jefferson to the boundary line between Texas and Louisiana, within three years from and after the approval of this act, then, and in that event, this charter or act of incorporation shall become forfeited, and cease to have any force or effect.
Sec. 18. That this act shall take effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER XCVII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Rio Grande Railroad Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That H. E. Woodhouse, S. Celaya, H. M. Field, Chas. Andre, H. B. Illius, F. Cummings, A. M. Erhard, Antonio Lan-
goria, I. Eversman, Nestor Maxan, S. P. Gelston, Jos. Kleiber, A. Werbiski, Chas. MacManus, John S. Ford, — Maltby, D. E. Diffendorffer, be and are hereby constituted a body politic and cor-
porate, under the name of the Rio Grande Railroad Company, by and under which name they and the stockholders in the same, their successors and assigns, shall have succession for ninety-nine years; and are hereby granted the right, power and authority, to enter into
Laws of the State of Texas.contracts; to borrow money; to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded; to establish such by-laws and regulations as the board of directors may deem proper for the conducting and management of the affairs of said company; to have and use a common seal, and to do and perform all other acts necessary and proper to carry out the objects and purposes of this act, not in conflict with the constitutional law of the land; and that the persons above named shall be and are hereby constituted the first board of directors of said company, and shall continue in office as directors until their successors are duly elected and qualified in accordance with the by-laws of the company to be by them, or a majority of them, adopted. The capital stock of said company shall be ($500,000) five hundred thousand dollars, but may be increased to seven hundred and fifty thou-
sand dollars, on a two-thirds vote of the directors, at a regular meeting thereof; said stock shall be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, and each share shall be entitled to one vote, either personally or by proxy, at all meetings of the company; said shares shall be deemed per-
sonal estate, and shall be transferable by any conveyance in writing, re-
corded by the secretary in the books of the company kept by him in his office, or in such other and further manner as the by-laws of said com-
pany may provide; and said company may establish an office for the transfer of the stock out of the State, under such rules and regulations, regarding the same, as may be deemed best and expedient, and as shall be provided in the by-laws of said company.

Sec. 2. That the said Rio Grande Railroad Company shall have, and the right, power and authority is hereby granted to said company to construct, equip, operate, maintain and own, a railroad and telegraph line from Point Isabel on the Laguna Madre to Brownsville on the Rio Grande.

Sec. 3. That said company shall have the right to enter upon and take possession of lands, to the extent of two hundred feet in width, for purposes of road-bed and construction, and such additional quantity of land for purposes of depots, sidings, turnouts, machine shops, and other buildings, as may be necessary, by paying the owner thereof the price agreed upon; and if no agreement can be made, or the owner or owners be absent or unknown, the said company may institute proceedings before a judge of the District Court for the county in which said lands are situ-
ated, to be determined by arbitration, as to parties present, and by pub-
lication according to the law of citation, by publication, as to parties as-
sent or unknown, describing the land required, whereupon the judge of such tribunal shall call a jury of twelve freeholders, who shall, upon oath, assess the value of the land; and upon the payment of the same by the
Laws of the State of Texas.company to the treasurer of the county where the land lies, subject to the order of the owner, said judge shall execute a bona fide title to the land, to the said company, which shall be recorded as other deeds; hut nothing in this section or act contained shall be construed to hinder said company from proceeding with the construction of said road during the time such arbitration or other legal proceedings are being had. That said company shall have the right to purchase, construct and own any warehouses, docks and wharves, that may be convenient or necessary for the storage or transfer of freight transmitted to or from said road, and shall have the right of owning and running such number of steam tugs and lighters as shall be found convenient to conduct the business of said company, and charging therefor the rates usual for such service.

Sec. 4. The persons named in the first section of this act, or a majority of them, shall meet in the city of Brownsville within ninety days after the passage of this act, and temporarily organize said company toy elect-
ing a president, secretary, and treasurer. The said persons shall, at the same time, provide for the opening of the books of subscription to the capital stock of said company, and when one hundred thousand dollars of stock shall have been subscribed, and five per cent. therof paid to the directors temporarily appointed, the president of said company shall notify the stockholders to meet at a time and place to be designated by him, when a permanent organization shall be bad, by electing a board of not less than five directors, who shall elect from their number one presi-
dent, and proceed to the appointment of all such other officers and agents as said board of directors may consider necessary to the management of the affairs of the company. The directors shall have power to fill any vacancy in their body, arising from death or any cause, and shall, at the time and place of said meeting, submit the by-laws of said company for the ratification of the said stockholders, which by-laws shall provide all necessary rules for the holding of meetings, and all other things con-
sidered to be necessary for the carrying out the provisions of this charter and the business of the company.

Sec. 5. Said company shall have power to borrow money or to pur-
chase property upon its own credit, for the purpose of constructing and maintaining its railroad, and may issue its bonds and obligations there-
for, payable at such time and place, and at such rates of interest, in the lawful money of the United States, or in the gold coin of the United States, or of any foreign country, as the direc-
tors of said company may elect; and to secure the payment of said bonds or obligations, may mortgage its road, its capital stock, its corporate franchises, and any or all of its property, real and personal, or any
Laws of the State of Texas.part or portion thereof, in such manner and form as said company or its directors shall deem best and expedient.

Sec. 6. The said company shall commence said road within one year, and complete the same within three years from the passage of this act, otherwise this act to be null and void, and the charter forfeited.

div3.head: CHAPTER XCVIII.

opener.salute:
An Act to change the gauge of the Brazos Branch Railroad, extend the time of construction, erect a telegraph line, and to permit the com-
pany to extend their line of road.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted, by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Brazos Branch Railroad Company shall have the right to change the gauge of their road to correspond with connecting roads; provided, that the gauge of said road shall not be less than four feet eight and a half inches; and they shall have the further right to extend their road to the International road at or near San Antonio, commencing at Sabine town, or at such point as the Sabine and Natchitoches Railroad, in Louis-
iana, may strike the Sabine river.

Sec. 2. Said company shall build their road from Navasota, in Grimes county, to Huntsville, in Walker county, within three years, and estab-
lish a depot within one mile of the State penitentiary, and the balance of the road within five years thereafter; and if said company should fail to build the road as herein provided, they shall forfeit all the rights and privileges granted by this act.
Sec. 3. Said company shall have the right to put up and operate a telegraph line along said road.

Sec. 4. That said company shall not be entitled to a renewal of their land grants by virtue of this extension of time, but shall be entitled to all the rights, privileges, immunities and franchises that may be granted to railroads by the state under any general law.
Sec. 5. That this act shall take effect from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER XCIX.
div3.p: An Act amendatory of and supplementary to an act entitled “An Act to incorporate the Young Men’s Heal Estate and Building Association,” approved November 6, 1866.

Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That a majority of the whole body of the shareholders of the “Young Men’s Mutual Real Estate and Building Association,” or that two-thirds of a quorum of the shareholders of said association, at any regular an-
nual meeting, or at any special meeting called for this purpose, of which special meeting notice of at least two weeks shall have been given by the president in some newspaper published in the city of Houston, may, from and after the passage of this act, and from time to time, continue and re-
quire the payments of installments of ten dollars per month upon each and all of the hundred shares, for as many years after the expiration of the payments of the first five years, as they may see fit, not to exceed in all twenty years, in addition to said first five years, under the same terms that the original act or charter of said association prescribes for the rais-
ing of the capital stock of sixty thousand dollars; the object of this sec-
tion being to define how the capital stock may be increased to three hun-
dred thousand dollars, in accordance with the power and privilege so to do, granted in section three of said original act or charter.

Sec. 2. That section ten of the act to which this is amendatory and supplementary, be so amended as to read as follows: “This act or charter shall remain in full force and effect from and after the sixth day of No-
vember, 1866, for and during the period of fifty years.”
Sec. 3. That this act take effect from its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER C.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the New Anhald Manufacturing Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That T. H.
