Mundine, and such persons as he may associate with him, be and are hereby created a body corporate, under the name and style of the “New Anhald Manufacturing Company,” and by that name may make contracts, sue and be sued, implead and be impleaded, transfer their rights by assignment or succession; may purchase, hold or convey real and personal property, and do all acts in conducting the interest of said com-
pany as fully as a natural person could do, consistent with the terms of this charter and the laws of this State; and may have a corporate seal.

Sec. 2. That said company shall have the right to erect and operate machinery in the county of Burleson, on or near the premises of the said T. H. Mundine, known as the P. Wimberby survey, for the manufactur-
ing of cotton and woolen fabrics, machinery and iron, any or each of them, and such other articles and fabrics as may be deemed desirable by said company.

Sec. 3. That the capital stock of said company shall not exceed two hundred thousand dollars, and shall be equal at all times its actual in-
vestments, and shall be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each; and that the capital stock may be increased, from time to time, as ex-
penditures are made, and that additional stock may be created by the ad-
mission of other stockholders, upon such terms as the board of directors may, at the time of application, determine upon.

Sec. 4. That the corporate powers of the company shall be exercised by directors, to be elected by the stockholders, and not to be more than five in number, each of whom must own at least ten shares of the capital stock, a majority of whom shall constitute a quorum to do business; they shall have power to elect a president from their own, num-
ber, and to appoint such other officers and agents as may be deemed necessary in conducting the business of said company, and to require bonds and security of such officers and agents, and to remove them at pleasure; and that, after the first election of the first board of directors, then there shall be an annual election by the stockholders, after due notice is given, and that they shall have power to fill vacancies that may occur by death, resignation or other-
Laws of the State of Texas.wise; and that, in case of the failure to elect annually a new board, the old board are authorized to hold their places, and transact the business of the company until their successors shall be chosen.
Sec. 5. The board of directors shall convene at any time at the call of the president, who shall preside over their meetings, and in his absence the board may appoint a president pro tem.
Sec. 6. That each stockholder shall be entitled to one vote for each share of capital stock held by him or her, and may vote in person or by proxy.

Sec. 7. That each subscriber who may invest capital in the stock of said company, or a holder of the same, shall at all times be entitled to re-
ceive the dividends declared upon said stock, unless the directors or stock-
holders should deem it the true interest of said company to invest said dividends in the extension of their operations, and that such action shall be binding upon the minority; and that, in case any stockholder shall be-
come dissatisfied, or wish to withdraw from said company, or dispose of his or her interest, or require a distribution of dividends, or otherwise im-
pede the operations of said company, that he or she shall not be permitted to institute legal proceedings against the company to adjust his or her individual rights, nor in any wise impede the progress of the company, unless sanctioned by a majority of the stockholders, but is permitted and required to dispose of his or her interest, in the market, at such price as such stock may command; and he or she selling shall henceforth be exonerated from any loss of said company, and be debarred from any future profits said company may realize. But before a dissolution of said company can be considered by the directors, and a sale of the property and effects, and a distribution of the same, a majority of the stockholders, in regular meeting, must express their approval of such dissolution.

Sec. 8. That the company shall be governed by the laws of the State regulating the right of way to railroad companies, in obtaining the right of way through the lands of individuals through which the same may pass, should they deem it to their interest to change the streams and con-
duct water to their machinery, and for the necessary grounds to erect their buildings on, and to carry on said manufacturing business for twenty-five years.

Sec. 9. The board of directors shall have power to establish such by-
laws and regulations as may be necessary for the transaction of the busi-
ness of the company.
Sec. 10. All contracts, releases, deeds and certificates of stock shall be signed by the president and attested by the seal of the company, or, in the absence of such seal, by his private seal.

Sec. 11. All shares of capital stock of said company shall be
Laws of the State of Texas.deemed personal property, and shall be transferable by conveyance in writing, to be recorded upon the books of the company, or in any such manner as the by-laws may prescribe.
Sec. 12. That this act shall take effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Austin Joint Stock Building Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That James H. Raymond, C. W. Whitis, Robert N. Lane, George Han-
cock, F. W. Chandler, J. M. Litten, James Manen, A. B. Palm, and such other persons as now hold full paid certificates of stock in the Austin Joint Stock Building Company, a private company heretofore organized, and their successors and assigns, shall be and they are hereby constituted and declared to be a body corporate, under the name and style of the “Austin Joint Stock Building Company,” with capacity to have succession and a common seal; to sue and be sued; to buy and sell real and personal estate; to erect, own and maintain buildings; to borrow money; to make contracts, and by-laws for the government of said as-
sociation, and generally to do and perform all such acts and things as may be necessary or incident to the business of said company, or for the maintenance of its rights, under this act, and consistent with the Consti-
tution and laws of this State.

Sec. 2. The said corporation shall be and is hereby vested with the full title of all property, rights and credits that are now owned by the said private company, known as the Austin Joint Stock Building Company, whether the same are in the name of the officers and agents of such pri-
vate company, or any other persons as trustees for said company, and shall be liable for and bound to pay all debts and demands now existing against said private company.

Sec. 3. The capital stock of said corporation shall not exceed one hundred thousand dollars, which shall be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each; and the holders of such shares, for the time being, shall constitute said corporation; and each individual or firm shall be entitled to one vote, in person or by proxy, for each
Laws of the State of Texas.and every share owned by such individual or firm, at all meetings of the stockholders, and such shares of stock shall be transferable only on the books of said corporation.

Sec. 4. The affairs and business of said corporation shall be conducted and managed by a board of five directors, to be elected by the stock-
holders, annually. The first meeting of the stockholders, for the election of directors, shall be held at such time and place in the city of Austin as may be designated by any three of the persons who are named in the first section of this act, after a notice of such meeting shall have been pub-
lished for at least ten days in some newspaper printed in the city of Aus-
tin. The first board of directors shall designate the time for future an-
nual meetings of the stockholders for the election of directors; and in case there shall be a failure to elect directors at the time designated for the annual meeting of stockholders, the directors then in office shall con-
tinue until there be an election, the time for which shall be designated by said board, of which at least five days’ notice shall be given in some newspaper printed in the city of Austin.

Sec. 5. No person shall be eligible as a director unless he be the owner of five shares of stock. The board of directors shall choose one of their number as president, and shall have power to fill vacancies that may hap-
pen in their board, and to appoint such other officers and agents as they may deem necessary; and they may require bond and security from any officer or agent of the corporation for the faithful performance of his duties.

Sec. 6. The board of directors may issue additional stock of said cor-
poration, until the whole stock shall amount to the limit established by this act; but they shall issue no such stock until it shall have been fully paid for. All certificates of stock in said corporation shall be signed by the president of the board, and shall have the seal of the corporation af-
fixed. A majority of the board shall constitute a quorum, and shall have authority to do and perform all such acts and things as may be neces-
sary for conducting the business of said corporation; and all instruments in writing, executed by the president, under the seal of the corporation, with the consent of a majority of the board of directors, shall be valid and binding upon the corporation; but no stockholder shall be personally liable for an amount greater than the stock he may own.
Sec. 7. This act shall take effect from its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CII.

opener.salute: An Act to amend an act entitled “An Act to incorporate the Western Texas Life, Fire and Marine Insurance Company of the city of San Antonio, Texas,” passed February 16, 1858.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the third section of the above recited act be and is hereby amended so that it shall hereafter read as follows, to-wit: That for the well order-
ing and managing of the affairs of said corporation, there shall be no less than five nor more than nine directors, who shall be elected by the stock-
holders at their annual meeting, to be held on such day as may be agreed on, in each year, for that purpose, at the city of San Antonio, and shall hold their office for one year, and until others are elected, and who, at the time of their election shall be citizens or residents of the State of Texas, or of the United States, and holders, respectively, of not less than five shares of the company’s stock; and the directors, at the first meeting after their election, shall choose one of their own number as president. In all elections for directors the vote shall be by ballot, and each stock-
holder shall have one vote for, each share of stock he or she may hold; but ho stockholder shall vote at any election unless the share or shares upon which he may claim to vote shall have been standing in his or her name on the books of the corporation for at least three months previous to such election; and in case of absence from any general meeting, any stockholder may vote by proxy in meeting;* provided, that until the first annual election for directors of said corporation shall be held under the provisions of this act, the persons named in the first section of this act, or a majority of them, shall have and may exercise all the privileges and powers given to the president and directors by this act.
* thus, in original.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Navasota Insurance Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Henry Y. Jones, J. Q. Yarborough, Isaac, Yarochinski, W. T. Smitheal, J. S. Mills, George Stoneham, C. T. D. Ham and Henry D. Patrick, and their present and future associates, successors and assigns, be and they are hereby incorporated and created a body politic and cor-
porate, by the name and style of the “Navasota Insurance Company,” and by the same name and style they and their successors shall be capable of suing and being sued, and maintaining any action to final judgment and execution, and shall be in law capable of purchasing, holding, improv-
ing and conveying any estate, real, personal or mixed, for the use of said corporation; and the said corporation shall have the power to ordain and establish and put into execution such by-laws, ordinances and regulations as shall be necessary for the-government thereof; and it shall be lawful for said corporation, after the expiration thereof, to use the corporate name, style and capacity for the purpose of suits for the final settlement and liquidation of affairs and accounts of the corporation, and for the sale and disposition of their estate, real, personal or mixed, but not for any other purpose, nor for a period exceeding three years after the ex-
piration of the term of incorporation.

Sec. 2. That the capital stock of said corporation shall not be less than one hundred thousand dollars, with privilege of raising it to two hundred thousand dollars, divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, and the same shall be created and paid in such manner and at such times as the president and directors of said corporation shall require, of which requisition at least one month’s notice shall be given, by publica-
tion in one newspaper published in Grimes county; and if any stockholder shall fail to pay any installment so required to be paid, he or she shall cease to be a member of said corporation, and shall forfeit his or her stock, and the share or shares so forfeited may be sold by said corporation in such manner as they may think proper; but such forfeiture and sale of such stock shall not release the holder thereof, nor his or her securities, on the notes contemplated to be given in section sixth and eighth of this act, and his or her liability on account of said notes to any person or persons
Laws of the State of Texas.having a just claim against said corporation, which shall have accrued before such sale.

Sec. 3. That for the well ordering of the affairs of said corporation, there shall be seven directors, who shall be stockholders of the corpora-
tion; they shall be elected by the stockholders at their annual meeting, to be held on the first Monday in May of each year, for that purpose, and the directors, at their first meeting, shall choose one of their own number as president, and another as vice-president; provided, nevertheless, that until the first annual election, the persons named in the first section of this act shall have and exercise all the powers given to the president and directors by this act; and in all elections for directors, the vote shall be by ballot, and each stockholder shall have one vote for each share he may hold, but no stockholder shall vote at any election until the share or shares upon which he may claim to vote, shall have been standing in his or her name on the books of said corporation for at least three months previous to such election. In case of absence from any general meeting, any stockholder may be entitled to vote by proxy.

Sec. 4. That the directors of said corporation, for the time being, four of whom, including the president, shall form a quorum, shall have power to appoint such officers, clerks, agents and other persons as shall be neces-
sary for conducting the business of said corporation, and to allow said per-
sons so appointed such compensation for their services as they shall deem proper, and generally to exercise all other powers and privileges as are given by law to corporations.

Sec. 5. This corporation shall have full power to make insurances upon all ships or other sea, river or bay vessels, and their freights, of whatever character, against loss from the dangers of navigation or fire, or upon railroad cars and goods, waxes and merchandise, conveyed upon railroad ears, against losses by fire while in transitu, and upon houses, stores, ware-
houses and other buildings, and upon goods, wares, merchandise, etc., against loss or damage by fire, and to fix the rate of premium thereon; and it may loan its moneys to any person or persons on any security it may think proper. It may receive deposits, buy and sell bills of exchange, drafts or other obligations, bonds and other securities.

Sec. 6. That the shares of said corporation shall be assignable and transferable upon the books of said company according to such rules and regulations as the president and directors thereof shall, for that purpose, ordain and establish; and in case the assignee of any share or shares of stock shall deposit his note, with securities, as contemplated and provided for in section eight of this act, then the assignee of such share or shares shall have the right to withdraw and cancel his note or notes and securities given for such share or
Laws of the State of Texas.shares of stock, otherwise the notes and securities of said assignor to be and remain subject and liable to all the conditions and provisions con-
tained in section nine of this act.

Sec. 7. That the president and directors of said corporation shall an-
nually, or semi-annually, make such dividends of the net profits of the company as shall appear advisable, which dividend, when declared, shall, by the president and directors, be endorsed on the unpaid stock notes of the party entitled to the dividend, until such notes are paid in full, or may, in their discretion, be paid to the parties entitled; but no dividend of any of the profits of the company shall be made at any time unless the capital paid in remain unimpaired.

Sec. 8. That the office of the company incorporated by this act shall be located in the city of Navasota; and so soon as the president and di-
rectors thereof shall establish, by evidence, to the satisfaction of the Police Court of Grimes county, that ten per cent. of the capital stock of said corporation has been paid by the stockholders thereof, and that the balance or residue of said capital of one hundred thousand dollars has been secured to be paid when called for, as contemplated in section second of this act, by the notes of the holders of said capital stock, se-
cured by good and solvent security or securities, and shall also estab-
lish to the satisfaction of said Police Court that the directors of said cor-
poration have been organized in conformity with the provisions of the third section of this act, then said Police Court shall give them a certifi-
cate thereof, which shall be their warrant to commence business oper-
ations under the authority vested by this act.

Sec. 9. That service of any and all legal process, in any suit or pro-
ceeding against said company, shall be sufficient if made upon the presi-
dent or secretary of the board of directors.
Sec. 10. That the charter granted by this act shall continue in full force and effect for the term of twenty-five years from and after the passage of this act.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CIV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Jefferson Insurance, Savings and Exchange Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That there may be established in the city of Jefferson a company, for the purpose of transacting the business of insurance, deposit and exchange, which company shall be called and known by the name of the “Jefferson Insurance, Savings and Exchange Company;” and all such persons as shall be stockholders, and their successors, shall and may have succession for the term of twenty-five years; and shall be capable of suing and being sued, answering and being answered unto, defending and being defended, in all manner of actions, suits, complaints and causes whatsoever; and may have a common seal; and shall be in law capable of purchasing, hold-
ing and conveying all kinds of property, real and personal; of receiving in trust, on deposit, from any person or persons, moneys, jewels, plate, or other valuable thing, and of giving their acknowledgments of such de-
posits in such form as the directory of said company may deem best suited for the mutual protection and convenience of the depositor and the com-
pany. That said company shall also be authorized to loan of their own funds and earnings, on any bills, or public stocks of incorporated com-
panies, and to buy and sell exchange.

Sec. 2. That the capital stock of said company shall be one hundred thousand dollars, with the privilege of increasing the same to one million of dollars, whenever the board of directors may deem it expedient to do so, to be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each. Twenty-five dollars shall be paid on each share, in cash, at the time of subscribing, and the remainder in such installments as the board of directors may di-
rect.

Sec. 3. That books of subscription to said copital stock shall be opened in the city of Jefferson, under the superintendence of F. C. Baker, W. C. Baker, W. H. Johnson, S. F. Mosely and John M. Waskeni, or any three of them. Said books of subscription shall be open until one hundred thousand dollars be subscribed; but no share shall entitle the holder to vote at any election, unless the same shall have been bona fide held by him or her, at least ten days next immediately before said election.

Sec. 4. That there shall be elected from amongst the stock-
holders not less than five nor more than nine directors, who shall hold
Laws of the State of Texas.their office for one year, and until their successors are elected and quali-
fied; which directors, at the time of their election, and during their con-
tinuance in office, shall be holders, in their own right, of at least five shares of stock; and they shall be elected annually, after the first elec-
tion, at the office of the company, or at any other convenient place in the city of Jefferson, and at such time of the day as the president of the com-
pany may appoint, of which election the stockholders shall have timely notice through the printed newspapers of the city of Jefferson. Said election shall be by ballot, and in person or by proxy, and each stock-
holder shall be entitled to one vote for each share of stock that he or she may own.

Sec. 5. That as soon as the sum of one hundred thousand dollars shall have been subscribed, it shall be the duty of the said F. C. Baker, W. C. Baker, W. H. Johnson, S. F. Mosely and John M. Waskem, or a majority of them, to appoint a time and place of meeting of the stockholders, for the election of the first board of directors; and at the time and place ap-
pointed, the stockholders shall determine, by a majority of votes, whether the number of directors shall be five or nine; and having so determined, shall proceed to elect said directors in a similar manner; and the persons then, there and thus elected, shall constitute the first board of directors, who shall serve for one year, and until their successors are duly elected and qualified. The said board of directors shall, immediately after their own election, meet and elect one of their number president of said com-
pany, who shall serve twelve months, and until his successor is duly elected and qualified.

Sec. 6. That the directors of said company, or a majority of them, shall have power to make such by-laws, rules and regulations, not incon-
sistent with the laws of this State and of the United States, as to them may appear needful and proper, for the management and government of said company, its stocks, property, estate and effects.

Sec. 7. That said company shall have power and authority to make general insurance upon houses, live stock, life, health, marine and fire risks, freights, moneys, goods, cottons, wares and merchandise, and to fix premiums for the same; and all policies of insurance by them made, and subscribed by the president (or by two directors in his absence,) with the seal of the company affixed thereto, shall be lawful and binding.
Sec. 8. That any stockholder who, after subscribing, shall neglect or refuse to pay the amount due on his stock, when called on to do so, shall forfeit the same, if not paid in sixty days.

Sec. 9. That all jewels, plate, moneys, bills, notes, checks, or other valuable thing deposited for safe keeping in the vaults or
Laws of the State of Texas.drawers of said company, shall not be jeopardized by any risk or obliga-
tion of said company, but shall be free from any risk, loss, liabilities or indebtedness arising or growing out of said insurance business.

Sec. 10. That in case of a vacancy in the board of directors of said company, the remaining directors shall fill the vacancy by electing from among the stockholders another director, whose time shall expire with the others.
Sec. 11. That all contracts, certificates or obligations, for the payment of money by said company, shall be signed by the president and secretary.

Sec. 12. That the amount of capital actually paid into, and the prop-
erty belonging to said company, shall be, at all times, liable to the same rates of taxation, as the property of individuals and like corporations in this State.

Sec. 13. That the company shall have power to establish agencies, as they may deem expedient for the interest of the company, and that said agencies shall be alike subject to all the rights, privileges and penalties of this act; and said company shall have the right and privilege to or-
ganize, as soon as the terms of this charter are complied with.

Sec. 14. That the company shall have the right to elect or appoint a secretary, and such other officers, for the management of the affairs of said company, as they may deem necessary, and to require bonds, if they desire to do so.

Sec. 15. That the stockholders shall at all times have access to the books of said company. If any depositor shall present his certificate of deposit, and the company shall fail to pay the same, within three days after such presentation is made, then the stockholders in said company shall become individually liable for said deposit, unless said deposit was destroyed by fire, and the certificate pertaining thereto was indorsed, “not insured.”

Sec. 16. That no person shall participate in any election for directors or officers of said company who has not paid, or caused to be paid, or otherwise satisfactorily secured his or her stock in said company; neither shall a delinquent stockholder participate in the profits, nor be cnargeable with losses, until he or she shall have paid or satisfactorily secured said stock subscription.
Sec. 17. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Home Insurance Company of Houston, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That there may be established in the city of Houston a company for the purpose of transacting a general insurance business, which company shall be called and known by the name of the “Home Insurance Company of Houston, Texas,” and the stockholders and their successors shall have continuous succession, and by that name shall be capable of suing and being sued; of purchasing, holding and conveying property of all descrip-
tions; to make, have and use a common seal, and the same to alter and renew at pleasure, and generally to do any act necessary to carry into effect the objects of the corporation, not inconsistent with the laws of the State or the United States.

Sec. 2. That the capital stock of this company shall be two hundred and fifty thousand dollars, to be divided into twenty-five hundred shares, of one hundred dollars each, and the same to be paid in the following manner: ten dollars on each share at the time of subscription, and the residue at such time as the president and directors may direct; which capital stock may hereafter be increased to one million dollars, at the discretion of the president and directors of the corporation. The said stock shall be deemed and held as personal property; and if any stock-
holder shall neglect or refuse to make the payments as required, his stock may be sold by order of the president and directors, in such manner as they may think fit to direct, and such stockholder shall be liable for the balance due by him as stockholder to the corporation, as it becomes due, and may be sued in the District Court of Harris county for the same.

Sec. 3. That the books of subscription shall be opened in the city of Houston for said shares, under the superintendence of John Shearn, S. K. Mcllhenny, A. J. Burke, James Converse, J. G. Tracy, J. R. Morris, H. R. Allen and C. S. Longcope, or any three of them; that said books, of subscription shall be opened at any place in said city as the commis-
sioners, or any three of them, may direct; advertisement of the time and place of opening such books to be made for one week in a newspaper published in Houston, and they shall be kept open until the sum of two hundred and fifty thousand dollars shall be subscribed for; and the said commissioners,
Laws of the State of Texas.or any three of them, shall, as soon as may be, after the books of sub-
scription are closed, call a meeting of the stockholders, and shall proceed to the election of not less than five, or more than nine directors, as may be determined by them, and the said directors shall elect one of their own number president; and the said president and directors, elected in pur-
suance of this act, shall have full power and authority to make, appoint and remove at pleasure all officers and agents of said corporation; to fix their compensation, prescribe their duties, and provide for the taking bonds from them for the faithful discharge of their duties, and generally to manage the affairs of said corporation. They shall also have power to fill any vacancy which may occur in their own body, and also appoint a president pro tem. when the president may be absent from their meet-
ings, and, if the president or any director be absent, without leave, for five successive regular meetings of the board, a majority of the same may declare his place vacant, and proceed to fill it without notice to such ab-
sent president or director.

Sec. 4. That the directors of this corporation shall call an annual meeting of the stockholders to make such election for directors, who, when so elected, shall hold their office for the term of one year, or until their successors are elected; and in all meetings of the stockholders, those holding a majority of the stock shall constitute a quorum, and each stockholder shall be allowed one vote for each share he holds, and the stock may be represented either in person or by proxy, and the power to cast the votes of absent stockholders, may be constituted by any writ-
ten expression of the stockholder so appointing a proxy to vote for him.

Sec. 5. That said corporation shall have full power to make insurance on houses, stores, and all other buildings, household-furniture, goods, wares, merchandise, and property of every description, against loss or damage by fire, and upon vessels, steamboats and all river crafts and freights, goods, wares, merchandise, specie, bullion, bank notes, bills of exchange and all evidence of debt against all maritime, river and in-
land transportation risks, on bottomry and respondentia interests, and upon lives and against accidents; in other words, to effect fire, marine, river, inland, life and accidents’ insurance of any kind whatsoever, with the privilege of exercising all or either of said purposes, and to fix the premiums and rates therefor; and it may loan its money or other prop-
erties to any person or persons on any security it may think proper; pro-
vided, that nothing in this act shall be so construed as to authorize this corporation to use its money or other property in any manner which it may not be lawful for any citizen of this State to do.

Sec. 6. That the president and directors of said corporation
Laws of the State of Texas.shall have power to fix the place and mode of transfer of stock certificates, as well as the payment of interest and dividends; that a majority of the board of directors shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of busi-
ness, and that said board of directors shall also have power to pass such by-laws as they may deem necessary to carry this act into effect; to dele-
gate authority to such officers or persons as they may think proper, and to execute, or authorize the excution, of all such bargains and contracts as may seem to them for the best interests of the company.

Sec. 7. That this charter, and all the privileges and powers herein granted, shall continue in force and effect for the term of fifty years from the passage of this act, and that the property, funds and business transac-
tions of the corporation shall be subject to the same rate of taxation as is by law imposed upon the property and similar transactions of individuals, and the stockholders shall not again be subject to tax on their shares or dividends.
Sec. 8. That any association in the city of Houston, now engaged in the business of insurance, may organize under this charter and transfer its assets to the corporation contemplated herein.
Sec. 9. That said corporation shall be responsible to the extent of its property, both real and personal.
Sec. 10. This act shall be in force from its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CVI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Comal Cemetery Association.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That John F. Torrey, J. J. Groos, John Goldenhargen and Earnest Grume, and their associates and successors, be and they are hereby con-
stituted in law and in fact a body corporate and politic, to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded in any courts of the State, under the name, style and title of the “Comal Cemetery Association,” by which title they shall have power to buy, sell and hold real and personal estate; contract and be contracted with; make by-laws and regulations for their govern-
ment; to have and use a common seal, and enjoy all the franchises and perform all acts incident to a corporation or an individual, and to have perpetual succession.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 2. The legal domicile and place of business of said association shall be in New Braunfels, Comal county.

Sec. 3. The affairs of this association shall be managed by the afore-
said corporators and their successors, a majority of whom shall have au-
thority to fill any vacancy occasioned by death, resignation or otherwise, and shall have power to elect their president, secretary, treasurer, sexton and other officers, and perfect their organization. They shall have power to purchase or acquire grounds and locate a cemetery; to make convey-
ance of any lot or lots for individual or family burial grounds; to en-
close, improve and adorn said grounds and avenues of said cemetery, and to erect such buildings as they may deem necessary, and to prescribe rules for improvement, adornment and enclosures in said cemetery, and to pro-
hibit any use or adornment of any lot or lots they may think improper; and all persons buying, procuring, holding or controlling any lot or space in the said cemetery shall be subject, absolutely, to all rules and regula-
tions established by said company.

Sec. 4. The capital stock of said company shall not exceed the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000,) which the corporators may raise by do-
nation, subscription, sale of lots or otherwise, and shall be applied to the uses and purposes required by this act, in the purchase of ground, the im-
proving and embellishing and enclosure thereof, and for the payment of the salaries of the sexton and other officers.

Sec. 5. The real and personal estate of this corporation shall be ex-
empt from taxation; and all lots of ground, within the said cemetery, conveyed to individuals for burial purposes, shall not be subject to taxa-
tion, appropriation for public purposes, to execution for debt, or to be liable for any claim whatever.

Sec. 6. Any person who shall wilfully destroy, mutilate, deface, injure or remove any tomb, gravestone, monument, fence, railing or other struc-
ture, tree, shrub, plant or flower, placed in said cemetery for protection or ornament, or otherwise, or injure any lot in said cemetery, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by fine not less than ten nor more than one hundred dollars, and impris-
onment in the county jail of not less than ten nor more than thirty days, and shall also be liable in damages before any court of competent juris-
diction, in the name of the said corporation; and the corporators, or lot-
holders, or stockholders shall be competent witnesses for or against the corporation.
Sec. 7. That this act shall take effect from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CVII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Catspring Social Turn Verein.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That F. A. Schmitt, H. Peters and A. Janhsen, their associates and suc-
cessors, be and they are hereby constituted a body corporate and politic, by the name and style of the “Catspring Social Turn Verein,” and by that name shall have succession, and may have a common seal; may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded; may buy and sell, receive and con-
vey; may purchase and own property real, personal and mixed, and dis-
pose of the same; may make by-laws for their government, and generally do and perform all such acts and things as pertain to such bodies with corporate powers.
Sec. 2. The capital stock of said corporation shall not exceed twenty thousand dollars.
Sec. 3. This charter shall remain in force for twenty years, unless sooner repealed.
Sec. 4. This act shall take effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to establish and incorporate the Beneficial Society of Galveston.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That William A. Clark, Richard Nelson, Daniel Coleman, Charles Red-
mond and Ephraim Jordan, and such other persons as they shall choose to associate with them, be and are authorized to organize, constitute and establish themselves into an association in the city of Galveston, under the name and style and title of “Beneficial Society of Galveston,” with the view and purpose to attend the sick and bury the dead members of said society, the duration of which shall be twenty years, dating from its incorporation.

Sec. 2. Said society shall be and the same is hereby established
Laws of the State of Texas.a body corporate, and shall have a common seal, having for its inscription the name of said society and the date, month and year of its incorpora-
tion.

Sec. 3. The officers of said society shall consist of a president, vice-
president, secretary and treasurer, and first, second, third and fourth marshals, which shall be elected annually by the members of the same in such manner and at such times as they may direct.

Sec. 4. Said society shall be capable, through its president and its name and title in law, to sue and be sued, and shall be authorized and empowered to make rules and by-laws, and to do everything needful for its good government and support that is not in contravention of the laws of the State; to receive and hold all manner of lands, tenements, rents and hereditaments, and any sum or sums of money, and any manner and portion of goods, chattels and property generally, given and bequeathed unto it or acquired by it, by purchase or any other lawful manner, and the same to be employed, invested and disposed of for and according to the objects, purposes, articles and conditions for which said corporation is formed and established.

Sec. 5. Said corporation shall have power, by its rules and regula-
tions, to fix the amount of admittance fee, and monthly and other dues to be paid by such as shall become members of the same, and to enforce the collection of the same by fines and forfeitures, and shall, moreover, have power to expel members for violations of its rules, by-laws and regulations, by vote, in manner and form as said society shall direct in its constitution and by-laws.

Sec. 6. No member of said society, withdrawing or being expelled therefrom, shall be entitled to demand or withdraw from the same any moneys or other property, real, personal or mixed, that may be or shall have been transferred or conveyed by him or her, or by any person of whom he or she may or shall be the heir or legal representative, by gift, sale or devise, or as contributions or dues, but the same shall be and re-
main vested in said corporation, absolutely to be used, employed and ex-
pended as hereinbefore provided.

Sec. 7. Said society shall be composed of such members, male and female, as shall be chosen in manner and form, and under such regula-
tions, rules, stipulations and conditions as may be, upon the organization of the same, or from time to time, adopted by said society.
Sec 8. That this act shall be in force from and after the date of its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CIX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Weatherford Masonic Institute.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That R. W. Pollard, E. A. Leach, W. J. Carson, J. M. Cole, J. C. Loving, J. N. Roach and W. R. Shannon, with their associates and successors in office, be and the same are hereby incorporated a body politic, under the name and style of the “Weatherford Masonic Institute,” and by that name may make contracts, sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, ac-
quire, hold and transfer property, both real, personal and mixed; and have and use a common seal; and may do and perform all things neces-
sary to be done to carry out the provisions of this act for the benefit of said institute; and may make such by-laws, rules and regulations for the government thereof as may be deemed necessary, and which may not be inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of the State of Texas and the provisions of this charter.

Sec. 2. That said institute shall be located in the town of Weather-
ford, Parker county, State of Texas, and no religious test shall ever be required of any officer of or teacher in said institute, nor shall any sec-
tarian doctrine be taught therein.

Sec. 3. That the capital stock of said company shall consist of one thousand shares, and each share of the value of twenty-five dollars cur-
rent money of the United States, which may be transferred by the owners thereof as personal property.

Sec. 4. That there shall be an election held regularly on the first Wednesday in January of each year (at which election at least one-half of the capital stock shall be represented,) for the purpose of electing a board of trustees, which shall consist of ten stockholders, members of the company, five of whom shall constitute a quorum to transact any business pertaining to the company, who shall hold their office until their succes-
sors are duly elected and qualified; which said board shall have power to elect a president and vice-president, and such other officers from their own number as they may deem necessary, and shall have power to require any officer, having in his possession funds or property belonging to the com-
pany, to give bond, payable to the president, in such sum as they may require.

Sec. 5. That the persons herein and heretofore named shall
Laws of the State of Texas.constitute the first board of trustees, and shall hold their office until the time appointed for the first annual election.

Sec. 6. That said board of trustees and their successors shall have power to receive donations or contributions in money or property for the purpose of purchasing a lot and erecting a suitable building or buildings thereon for masonic and educational purposes.

Sec. 7. That all conveyances of property of said institute, made by said board of trustees, may be acknowledged by the president of said board in the same manner as prescribed by law for private individuals, except the stock issued to the members of said company, which shall only be required to be signed by the president and countersigned by the secre-
tary.
Sec. 8. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CX.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the officers and members of San Antonio Har-
monia Lodge No. 1, O. D. H. S.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the officers and members of San Antonio Harmonia Lodge No. 1, O. D. H. S., and their successors and future associates, be and they are hereby created a body politic and corporate, by the name and style of San Antonio Harmonia Lodge No. 1, O. D. H. S., and by that name shall be capable of acquiring, holding, selling and conveying property, real, per-
sonal or mixed; provided, the same shall not exceed in value, at any one time, the sum of twenty-five thousand dollars; and they may establish and manage institutions of learning in the usual manner, and under such rules and regulations as they may think proper to make, not inconsistent with the Constitution and general laws of the State of Texas.

Sec. 2. That said corporation may, by the name and style aforesaid, sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, answer and be answered, defend and be defended, in all suits, actions, demands, pleas or complaints of any character, in any court of law or equity within this State.

Sec. 3. That the said corporation may have a common seal, and change or alter the same at pleasure; may make, repeal or change a
Laws of the State of Texas.constitution and by-laws for their government, not inconsistent with the laws of the land, and shall, in general, have and exercise all rights, privi-
leges and immunities by law incident to, and commonly enjoyed by cor-
porations of like kind, for and during the term of twenty years.

Sec. 4. That in any suit or other proceeding against the said corpora-
tion, service of process or of notice, or of any other papers, may be made by delivering to any officer of the corporation a copy thereof, duly cer-
tified, and the officer or other person serving the same, shall state in his return, the officer of the corporation upon whom it was served, naming him.

Sec. 5. That any deed of conveyance, duly signed and executed by the officers of said corporation, in pursuance of a resolution authorizing the same, shall be deemed valid in law, and shall in law have the same force and effect as any other like deed of conveyance.
Sec. 6. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXI.

opener.salute: An Act supplementary to and amendatory of an act entitled “An Act supplementary to an act to incorporate the city of Corpus Christi,” approved February 13, 1854.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That section two of the above recited act be amended so as to read as follows:

Sec. 2. That there shall be held in said city of Corpus Christi a court to be called the city court of Corpus Christi; said court shall be held by the mayor of said city, or in case said mayor shall notify the board of aldermen of said city, in writing, that it is im-
practicable for him to hold said court, then said court shall be held by an officer to be called “recorder of the city of Corpus Christi,” who shall be chosen by the mayor and board of aldermen of said city, and whose term of office shall expire, unless sooner revoked, with that of the mayor and board of aldermen appointing him; that said court shall be held at such times as the mayor of said city may direct, and that said court shall have the jurisdiction of a jus-
Laws of the State of Texas.tiee of the peace, within the limits of said, corporation, and shall have jurisdiction of all cases under the by-laws, rules, regulations and ordi-
nances of said city, with full and complete judicial power to enforce the same. The recorder of the city of Corpus Christi shall have power to fine and imprison in all cases when the mayor of said city is now, or shall hereafter be empowered by law, so to do; and when a fine is now, or shall hereafter be made recoverable before the mayor of said city, by law, the same shall also be recoverable before the said recorder.

Sec. 3. That the recorder of the said city of Corpus Christi shall re-
ceive from said city such fees or other compensation for his services as the mayor and board of aldermen of said city may determine.

Sec. 4. That all acts and parts of acts conflicting with, or contraven-
ing the provisions of this act, are hereby repealed; and that this act take effect from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the town of Bonham, in Fannin county.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the citizens of the town of Bonham, in Fannin county, be and they are hereby declared a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of the “Corporation of the town of Bonham,” and by that name shall have power to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, and to hold and dispose of property, real and personal; provided, such real property is situated within the limits of said corporation.

Sec. 2. That it shall be the duty of the citizens of said corpora-
tion to elect a mayor, constable and five aldermen; that the con-
stable shall be ex officio assessor and collector of taxes; that said aldermen shall elect from their own body a treasurer and secretary, and shall have power to appoint such other inferior officers as they may deem necessary for said corporation. The treasurer and assessor and collector of taxes shall each be required to give bond, with security, to be approved by the mayor, for the faithful performance of their duties, and to make reports when required by the board of aldermen; and the mayor shall have power to suppress riots and dis-
Laws of the State of Texas.turbances of the peace; to call out the citizens of said corporation for the purpose of restoring order, and to impose a fine, not exceeding twenty-
five dollars, on any citizen of said corporation for refusing to obey such call.

Sec. 3. That the first election shall be held under the order of the jus-
tice of the peace of precinct number one, of Fannin county, on the first Monday in the month following the passage of this act, of which elec-
tion ten days’ notice shall be previously given by said justice of the peace; provided, the said notice can be given within that time, and if not, then said election shall be held on the first Monday in the month next but one, after the passage of this act, and annually thereafter, under the direction of the mayor, who shall give at least ten days’ notice thereof, before his term of office shall expire. That in case of vacancy in any of the offices of said corporation, a special election shall be held under the direction of the mayor, but if there be no mayor, then said election shall be held by order of the board of aldermen.

Sec. 4. That no person shall be eligible to any office under the provis-
ions of this charter, who is not a qualified voter of this State, and shall have been a resident within the limits of said corporation for at least six months prior to his election; nor shall any person have a right to vote for officers who has not been a citizen and resident, within said corporate limits, at least six months next preceding the day of said election.

Sec. 5. That the mayor and board of aldermen of said corporation shall have power to pass such rules and regulations and ordinances, as may be necessary for the preservation of law and order, within the cor-
porate limits; for the levying of taxes; for the removal of nuisances, and keeping the streets in good order, and for any and all other purposes necessary to promote the public welfare and good government within said corporate limits; and they shall have power to prescribe penalties for the violation of the laws and ordinances of the corporation; provided, no tax shall ever be levied exceeding one-half the State tax, allowed by law; and provided, further, that they shall in no case prescribe penalties to exceed one hundred dollars, or imprisonment for more than six months.

Sec. 6. That the limits of said corporation shall be as follows: com-
mencing one-half mile west of the court-house in Bonham, and running south one-half mile; thence east one mile; thence north one mile; thence west one mile; thence south one-half mile to place of beginning.
Sec. 7. That the mayor, with a majority of the board of aldermen, shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business.

Sec. 8. That this act take effect and be in force from and after
Laws of the State of Texas.its passage; provided, nothing in this charter contained, shall interfere with the law passed by this Legislature, entitled “An act to provide for the appointment by the Governor of certain officers to fill vacancies.”

div3.head: CHAPTER CXIII.

opener.salute: An Act to amend the ninth section of an act entitled “An Act to amend the charter of the town of Goliad.”

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the ninth section of the act entitled An act to amend the charter of the town of Goliad, shall be so amended as hereafter to read as fol-
lows, viz: Section 9. That the Common Council shall represent the cor-
poration, using its name and seal in all appropriate business under the charter, and not violating any general law; it may enact all necessary and proper ordinances for the government of the town in all respects; it may collect revenue in all kinds of cases in which the State shall do so from time to time, but the rates shall not exceed one-half of those im-
posed by the State; and the corporate revenue shall be collected, as near as practicable, in conformity with the laws that may be in force for col-
lecting the State revenue; the Common Council may acquire and hold any property for public uses, and may improve, sell, or otherwise dispose thereof at pleasure; it may collect the prices of any lands of said town sold by the corporate authority since the autumn of eighteen hundred and forty-six, or may acquire the title and control of any part thereof from any purchaser, by compromise or other legal means, or may refund the price with interest on failure of title, and may so act under future sales; and may sell at public auction, on sixty days’ notice in some news-
paper published in this State, any portion that may at the time be un-
sold of the land heretofore conceded to said town by the late Republic of Texas, except such parts as may hereafter be necessary for a public square, a public cemetery, a court-house, a jail, a public market, and public highways. The Common Council shall proceed as fast as practicable, without unreasonably sacrificing the land, to ob-
tain and appropriate the proceeds of former and future sales, to the amount of eight thousand dollars, for the erection of a jail and a court-house, which shall include necessary clerks’
Laws of the State of Texas.offices for the county of Goliad; and on the completion of said court-
house in a manner suitable for the clerks’ offices, as well as for other pur-
poses of a court, the remainder of said lands, or the proceeds of the sales of said lands, shall be held, sold, exchanged, or otherwise used and dis-
posed of by the Common Council for the purpose of repairing the streets, building bridges, and enclosing the court-house square and cemetery, and for such other purposes, within the corporate limits of said town, as may be deemed necessary and proper by said Common Council. And all books and papers pertaining to the corporate authority of the town of Goliad, be and the same is hereby required to be turned over to the Com-
mon Council by any person or persons who, at the time of the passage of this act, may have possession of the same. The persons composing the Common Council of said town, being required to be citizens of, and live within the corporate limits of the town proper; and in case of any vacancy of members of said town council, by reason of any member elect failing to qualify, or the resignation or death of any member, the Common Coun-
cil shall supply such vacancy by appointment. And all lands within said corporate limits shall be liable for any and all fines assessed by said Com-
mon Council against the owners thereof, for failure to comply with the ordinances of the Common Council, in regard to cleaning streets, repair-
ing sidewalks, or removal of obstructions or nuisances.
Sec. 2. That this act shall be in full force from its passage, and all laws and parts of laws inconsistent with it are hereby repealed.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXIV.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the town of Canton, in Van Zandt county.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the citizens of the town of Canton, in Yan Zandt county, be and they are hereby declared a body politic and corpo-
rate, under the name and style of the “Corporation of the Town of Canton,” and by that name shall have power to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, and to hold and dispose of property, real and
Laws of the State of Texas.personal; provided, such real property is situated within the limits of said corporation.

Sec. 2. That it shall be the duty of the citizens of said corpora-
tion to elect a mayor, five aldermen and a constable, who shall also be ex officio assessor and collector of taxes; and a treasurer and secre-
tary shall be elected by said mayor and aldermen. The treasurer and assessor and collector of taxes shall be required to give bond, with se-
curity to be approved by the presiding officer, for the faithful perform-
ance of their duties, and to make reports when required by the mayor or board of aldermen; and the mayor shall have power, when necessary, to suppress riots and disturbances, and to call out the citizens of said corporation for the purpose of restoring order.

Sec. 3. The mayor, aldermen and constable shall, for the present time, be appointed as provided for in an act entitled “An act to au-
thorize the Governor to appoint certain officers to fill vacancies;” and upon the expiration of their term of office, there shall be an election held, under the direction of the mayor, who shall give at least ten days’ notice of such election before his term of office shall expire; and said elections for the offices as aforesaid shall be held every two years thereafter; and all male inhabitants of said town, who have resided within its limits for the space of four months preceding any election, and who are qualified voters under the Constitution and laws of this State, shall be deemed qualified electors of said corporation.

Sec. 4. That the mayor and board of aldermen of said corporation shall have power to pass such rules, regulations and ordinances as may be necessary for the regulation of the police, and the preservation of order within the corporate limits; for the levying of taxes; for the re-
moval of nuisances, and keeping the streets in good order; for building a market house; for improving and ornamenting public property within said corporate limits, and for any and all other purposes tending to promote good order and government; and they shall have power to prescribe and enforce the collection of penalties for the violation of the ordinances of the corporation; provided, no tax shall ever be levied exceeding one-half the State tax allowed by law; and provided, further, that they shall in no case prescribe penalties to exceed one hundred dollars, or imprisonment for more than twenty-four hours.
Sec. 5. The limits of said corporation shall extend one-half mile in every direction from the centre of the public square in said town of Canton.

Sec. 6. That the mayor, with a majority of the board of alder-
men, shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business; and
Laws of the State of Texas.in the absence of the mayor, the board of aldermen shall elect one of their own number mayor pro tempore.
Sec. 7. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXV.

opener.salute: An Act to re-organize the city of Indianola, in Calhoun county, Texas.

div3.p: Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, as follows:

div4.head: Article First, The corporate powers.
div4.p:
Section 1. The corporation now existing and known as the “City of Indianola,” in Calhoun county, shall continue to be a body corporate in fact, by the same name, and shall have perpetual succession, with all the grants, powers and privileges heretofore held by said corpora-
tion, and not modified or repealed by the provisions of this act. Said corporation shall also have such enlarged jurisdiction and additional powers as are hereinafter conferred by this act.

div4.head: Article Second. Limits of the Corporation.
div4.p:
Section 1. The limits of said corporation shall be ascertained and de-
fined as follows: All that plat of land known as the “Hensault Map” as the former limits of said city, together with that portion of the harbor of Matagorda Bay between said former city limits and the channel in said bay; provided, that said city limits may be hereafter extended, including and adding more territory, whenever a majority of the inhabitants of said territory shall indicate a desire to be included within the limits of said city, until said limits shall be ascertained and defined as follows: beginning at a post set two miles in a direct line south, fifty and one-half degrees east, below
Laws of the State of Texas.the centre of the outlet of Powderhorn Bayou; thence north thirty-nine and one-half degrees east, to the channel of Matagorda Bay, where is a post, and which is the first corner; thence, following the meanders of the channel in a north-westerly direction, to a point opposite the mid-
dle of the outlet of Stephens’ Bayou, sometimes called White’s Bayou, said bayou being above what is known as “Old Town;” said point in the channel is to be found by running from the middle of said bayou, at its outlet, north, thirty-nine and one-half degrees east, till it inter-
sects the channel, for the second corner; thence south, thirty-nine and one-half degrees west, to the centre of said Stephens’ Bayou, at its outlet, and following the same course south, thirty-nine and one-half degrees west, to a post three and one-half miles distant in the prairie, which is the third corner; thence south, fifty and one-half degrees east, run-
ning such a distance, that a line running south, thirty-nine and one-
half degrees west from the first corner, will intersect the line running south, fifty and one-half degrees east from the third corner; said point of intersection is the fourth corner; said corners to be established by the true north, variation ten degrees east.

div4.head: Article Third. Extent of jurisdiction.
div4.p:
Section 1. The jurisdiction of the corporation shall be co-extensive with the limits as defined in article second, and shall also include the harbor in Matagorda Bay, as far south, fifty and one-half degrees east, as the first corner, and as far northwest as the second corner named in article second; and for all sanitary purposes, said, jurisdiction shall ex-
tend five miles in every direction beyond the limits specified in article second.

div4.head: Article Fourth. Officers.
div4.p: Section 1. The elective officers of the corporation shall be one mayor, seven aldermen, one recorder, one treasurer, and one marshal.

Sec. 2. The mayor and aldermen shall constitute “The Common Council of the city of Indianola;” and when in session, as such common council, may appoint and remove, at their pleasure, such subordinate officers as may be needed, from time to time, to secure an efficient ad-
ministration of all ordinances of the corporation.

div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div4.head: Article Fifth. The Powers of the Corporation.
div4.p: Section 1. The powers of the corporation shall be vested, in the mayor and aldermen; and a majority of the aldermen present at any regular or called session shall constitute a quorum competent to do business.

Sec. 2. The form of all ordinances shall be as follows: “Be it or-
dained by the Common Council of the city of Indianola.”

Sec. 3. No ordinance shall take effect and be in force until the same is published for two weeks in a newspaper published within the cor-
porate limits of the city, or in the absence of such newspaper, by post-
ing up such ordinances in at least six public places within the limits of the corporation for the length of time above stated. Sanitary or-
dinances, when their speedy enforcement is deemed necessary by the Common Council, may be made to take effect the day after their being posted up, in at least twelve public places within said limits.
Sec. 4. The Common Council, by ordinances, shall have power as follows:

1. To appoint subordinate officers, and require bond and proper security for the faithful performance of their duties; to prescribe the duties to be performed by such subordinate officers; to prescribe the duties to be performed by the recorder and by the treasurer, and mar-
shal, respectively, and to enforce their performance in such manner and mode as said common council may deem appropriate, not inconsistent with the laws of the State.
2. To fix the salaries of all officers entitled to the same, either by this act or by an ordinance of the Common Council.

3. To levy taxes on all property within the limits of the corporation, subject to taxation under the laws of the State, but said taxation is not to exceed one-half of one per cent. ad valorem, as estimated in the assessment for State taxes; and to levy a specific tax on dogs.
4. To collect said taxes through their own officer in the mode and manner as prescribed by law for the collection of the State taxes.

5. To license merchants and traders in goods, wares and merchan-
dise of every description, wholesale and retail wine and liquor dealers, wholesale and retail grocers, apothecaries, innkeepers and boarding houses, brokers and money changers, carts, wagons, hackney coaches and livery stables, hawkers and peddlers, showmen,
Laws of the State of Texas.theatres, pawnbrokers and the keepers of beer saloons, barbers and other occupations, beer gardens, and to collect said licenses through their own officer in the mode and manner prescribed by law for the collection of licenses granted by the State.
6. To regulate the use of the streets, highways, roads, and public places, by foot passengers, vehicles, railways and locomotives.
7. To regulate the rise of the sidewalks.
8. To prevent and remove encroachments upon, and obstructions to the streets, highways and public places.
9. To regulate the opening of street surfaces, and to extend the streets as laid down in the recorded plat of said city, in continuation to the corporate limits of said city.
10. To regulate the laying of gas or water pipes, and erecting of gaslights.
11. To regulate or prevent the throwing of ashes, offal, dirt, or garbage in the streets.
12. To regulate or prevent animals running at large, or being rode, driven, or led through the city.

13. To regulate the cleaning and grading of the streets and side-
walks, the making and cleaning of gutters.
14. To regulate the erection, use and continuance of slaughter houses.

15. To define, regulate and control the conduct of police, and their relation to other officers of the peace and other persons, in respect to maintaining peace and good order, and preserving the rights of persons and property.
16. In relation to street beggars, mendicants and vagrants.
17. In relation to the use of guns, pistols, fire-arms, fire crackers of all kinds within the city.
18. In relation to the keeping and storage of gunpowder and other explosive materials.
19. In relation to intoxication, quarreling and fighting in the streets and in places of public amusement.

20. In relation to public morals, in exposing the person, or exhibit-
ing obscene pictures.

21. In relation to the public health, the prevention and removal of nuisances, the regulation of interments, the business of bone boiling or grinding, meat packing, soap making, and other operations or occupa-
tions noxious to health or comfort, and the removal, keeping and de-
posit of manure, offal and garbage.
22. In relation to disorderly and gaming houses, their inmates and frequenters, the suppression of vice and immorality.
23. In relation to the construction, care and use of markets, docks, wharves, piers, and slips.
div4.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div4.p:
24. In relation to quarantining, in apprehension of, or during epi-
demics.
25. In relation to the berth of ships in the harbor and at the wharves; and in relation to the guarding and protecting property on the same.

26. In relation to the prevention and extinguishment of fires, and the formation of a fire department, its officers, its regulations and sup-
port.

27. In relation to the assessment and collection of assessments made on the owners of lots, for the grading, filling up and improving the sidewalks and streets adjacent to said lots, which assessment is hereby made a charge against the owners of such lots, and a charge and lien on said lots.
28. In relation to the affixing of a penalty for a violation of any ordinance, and the collection of said penalty.

29. In relation to the imposition of port charges on all vessels arriv-
ing in the harbor, and their collection.
30. In relation to the erection of a city hospital, its conduct and maintenance.

31. In relation to the inspection, weighing and measuring of fire-
wood, coal, hay and straw, and the cartage of the same.

32. In relation to the inspection and sealing of weights and meas-
ures, and enforcing the keeping and use of proper weights and meas-
ures by venders.
33. In relation to public order and keeping the peace.
34. In relation to the mode and manner of proceedings of their own body when in session.
35. In relation to the time, necessary notices, mode and manner of holding elections for elective officers of the corporation; also, in relation to contested elections for elective officers.

36. In relation to the employing of legal counsel for the assistance of the Common Council, and to prosecute on behalf of the corporation in criminal cases, and to institute and defend civil suits in their be-
half.
37. In relation to the employment of a city surveyor.
38. In relation to the employment of an adequate police force and night watchmen.
39. In relation to the imposition of fines and penalties for a violation of ordinances.

div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div4.head: Article Sixth. Tenure of office of elective officers.
div4.p: Section 1. Elective officers shall hold their offices for one year from the date of their installment, and until their successors are qualified.
Sec. 2. All elections to fill vacancies shall be for the unexpired term of the office to be filled.

div4.head: Article Seventh. Publicity of proceedings of the Common Council.
div4.p:
Section 1. All the proceedings of the Common Council shall be re-
corded in proper journals and books kept for that purpose, and shall be open to the inspection of the public.

div4.head: Article Eighth. The mayor, his duties and salary.
div4.p: Section 1. The mayor, when, present at the sessions of the Common Council, shall be the presiding officer. He shall have the casting vote in case of a tie.

Sec. 2. The mayor shall have power to act in a judicial capacity, and alone, in all cases arising within the jurisdiction of the corpora-
tion, involving a breach of the peace, a violation of any penal ordinance of the Common Council, and a violation of any law in the Criminal Code of the State.

Sec. 3. In cases of a breach, of the peace, or a violation of a law in the Criminal Code of the State, the mayor shall have the same power as is conferred by law on a justice of the peace in relation to the same subject matter. In relation to a violation of penal ordinances passed by the Common Council, lie shall have power to try the same, and on conviction, to execute the penalty through the marshal, sheriff or con-
stable, in the mode and manner prescribed in the ordinance violated.

Sec. 4. The mayor, as a judicial officer, on complaint made be-
fore him under oath, shall have power to issue writs of arrest, and warrants for all violations of the ordinances of the corporation, and for all violations of the Criminal Code of the State; and when such violations of ordinances and of the Criminal Code of the State are
Laws of the State of Texas.committed in his view, he shall have power to arrest without complaint made, and without a writ of arrest or warrant. He shall also have power to issue subpoenas for witnesses.

Sec. 5. The mayor, as a judicial officer, shall keep a record of all his proceedings, and transmit the same to the Common Council on the termination of his office, and the same shall be kept as an archive of the corporation.

Sec. 6. The mayor shall, at all times, by virtue of his office, see that the ordinances of the Common Council are executed; that all sub-
ordinate officers perform their duties, and, as occasion may require, re-
port to said council as to delinquencies and misconduct of such officers. He shall also, from time to time, recommend to the council such meas-
ures for consideration as he may deem important.

Sec. 7. The mayor shall receive an annual salary, to be fixed as to the amount, by the Common Council preceding his term of office. As a judicial officer, he shall recive the same fees as are or may be provided by law for a justice of the peace.

div4.head: Article Ninth. Finances.
div4.p:
Section 1. All property, real and personal, acquired by the cor-
poration of the city of Indianola, whether by conveyance, donation, be-
quest, or by the imposition of taxes, fines or penalties, or the granting of licenses, or acquired from any other source, or in any other manner, shall be held in trust by said corporation for the use and benefit of the same, and shall be appropriated for no other purpose.
Sec. 2. The funds of the corporation shall be used:
First. To sustain the municipal government.
Second. For the erection and maintenance of a city hospital.
Third. For the erection and maintenance of a house of correction for juvenile delinquents.
Fourth. For such improvements in, and adornments of the city as shall be sanctioned by a vote of a majority of the legal votes east in an election to be held for that specific purpose.

Sec. 3. The corporation shall not incur debts to exceed, at any one time, the sum of five thousand ($5,000) dollars. If the Common Coun-
cil deem it advisable to incur debts exceeding that amount, they may specify the amount desired, and submit the question to the legal voters within the corporate limits, and the same shall be sanctioned by a ma-
jority of the votes cast

div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div4.head: Article Tenth. Electors.
div4.p: Section 1. The qualified electors for State and county officers, who shall have resided three months next preceding an election, within the corporate limits of the city, shall be allowed to vote for all elective officers of the corporation.

div4.head: Article Eleventh. General Provisions.
div4.p: Section 1. Upon the passage of this act, the persons now filling the offices of the city of Indianola, shall continue in office, subject to the provisions of an act entitled “An act to authorize the Governor to fill vacancies,” passed by this Legislature.

Sec. 2. In all questions of conflict arising out of the terms used and provisions made in the original and amended acts of incorporation, of the city of Indianola, and the terms used and provisions made in this act, this act shall have the preference, and govern.
Sec. 3. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXVI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the town of Hallville, in Harrison county, Texas.

div3.p:
Section. 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the citizens of Hallville, in Harrison county, be and they are here-
by created a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of “The Corporation of the town of Hallville,” and by that name shall have power to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, and to hold and dispose of real and personal property; provided, such real prop-
erty is situated within the limits of said corporation.

Sec. 2. That it shall be the duty of the citizens of said corpo-
Laws of the State of Texas.ration to elect a mayor, five aldermen, a collector and a constable. A treasurer and a secretary shall be elected by said aldermen. The treas-
urer and collector shall be required to give bond with sufficient security, to be approved by the presiding officer, for the faithful performance of their duties, and to make reports when required by the mayor or board of aldermen; and the mayor shall have power, when necessary, to sup-
press riots and disturbances, and to call out the citizens of said corpora-
tion for the purpose of restoring order; and the collector also to act as assessor, if so required by the board of aldermen.

Sec. 3. That the first election shall be held under the orders of the district judge of said county, after having given ten days’ notice there-
of, and annually thereafter under the direction of the mayor at least ten days before his term of office expires; and in case of death or resig-
nation of any officer except mayor, the vacancy shall be filled by men elected as ordered by the mayor; and in case the office of mayor shall become vacant, then the aldermen shall elect one of their own number to act as mayor until the next annual election.

Sec. 4. That no person shall be eligible to any office, under the pro-
visions of this charter, who is not a qualified elector of this State, and a resident within the limits of this corporation, nor shall any person have a right to vote for officers who is not a qualified elector and resides within its limits.

Sec. 5. The mayor and board of aldermen shall have power to pass such rules and ordinances as may be necessary for the regulation of the police and the preservation of order within the corporate limits, to levy taxes for the removal of nuisances and keeping the streets in good order, and to prescribe penalties for the violation of ordinances and by-
laws of the corporation; provided, that in no case such penalties shall exceed one hundred dollars.
Sec. 6. That the limits of said corporation shall be the metes and bounds as they were surveyed, and the map recorded in the proper office in Marshall, Texas.

Sec. 7. That the major, with a majority of the said aldermen, shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business, and shall enact and enforce such rules and regulations as they may deem necessary for the government of said corporation.
Sec. 8. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.
