hibitions, shows and amusements, billiard tables, nine and ten pin alleys, groceries, tippling houses and dram shops, and to determine the amount of tax upon the same, and to suppress gaming or gambling houses by whatever description known, and all disorderly houses.

Sec. 17. That all officers of said corporation shall, before en-
tering upon the duties of their office, take and subscribe the oath prescribed by the Constitution; and the mayor, constable and treasurer shall also enter into a bond, with two good securities to be
Laws of the State of Texas.approved by the board of aldermen, for the faithful performance of their duties, payable to the said corporation in such sum as the board of alder-
men may require, which bond shall not be void on first recovery.

Sec. 18. That the constable, in addition to his powers aand privileges as such, be and he is hereby vested with all the powers and privileges which are now or may be, by law, exercised by the constable of the beat in which said corporation is situated, and for all services which may be rendered by him, he shall have the same fees which are or may be by law allowed to constables of the beat for similar services.

Sec. 19. That the fees of the aldermen shall not be more than two dollars for each and every regular meeting of the board at which they may be in attendance; provided, they shall not be entitled to charge for more than twelve meetings in any one year; that the fees of the recorder shall not be more than two dollars for each and every meeting of the board at which he may be in attendance; the fees of the treasurer shall not be more than five per centum upon all moneys received and paid out by him; the corporation attorney shall be entitled to have and re-
ceive a tax fee of two dollars and fifty cents on each and every conviction under this act and the by-laws of said corporation, which fee the mayor shall include and tax in the bill of costs on said conviction; provided, that when any person shall have committed any offense against the law of said corporation, and shall plead guilty of the same, said tax shall not be allowed nor taxed; and the board of aldermen shall have the power to regulate the compensation of the officers of said corporation, not def-
initely fixed and provided for in this act.

Sec. 20. That in all prosecutions, trials, and proceedings under this act and the by-laws of said corporation, the mayor and constable shall be governed by the laws regulating proceedings in justices’ courts, in force at the time of said proceedings, prosecutions and trials, and shall be entitled to the same fees as justices of the peace and constables for similar services.

Sec. 21. That the first election, as provided for in the fourth section of this act, for corporate officers, shall be held as may be provided for by law; that, for the present, the Governor be requested to appoint the officers for said corporation.
Sec. 22. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the City of Columbus, and for other purposes.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the inhabitants of the town of Columbus, in Colorado county, to-
gether with those now or hereafter resident within boundaries hereinafter named, be and they are hereby incorporated under the name and style of the “City of Columbus,” and in addition to the former corporate limits of the town of Columbus, the said city of Columbus shall extend to and include the following boundaries, to-wit: beginning at the south-eastern corner of said town of Columbus, at high water mark, on the east bank of the river Colorado, and thence clown said river on the east bank thereof, to a point from which a due west line will pass parallel to, and one-half mile due south of Wallace street; thence due west to a point in said line intersected by a line due north from said point, one-half miles west of Rampart street; thence due north with said parallel line, west of said Rampart street to the north bank of Colorado river, at high water mark; thence down said river, at high water mark, to a point opposite to where the fence, known as George Little,s pasture fence, below the beef packery; thence due east across said river, and to the first bluff above the low bot-
tom lands next the river; then following the lower edge of said bluff, in a southern direction, until the same intersects the former corporate limits, of the town of Columbus; thence due west to the north-eastern corner of said town; thence down said river to the beginning, following the highest bank thereof.

Sec. 2. The former public streets and squares of said town of Colum-
bus, together with any other public streets and squares to be hereafter laid out and established by the city council of the city of Columbus, shall be the public streets and squares of said city; but no new street shall be opened, nor public square laid off, without paying to the owners of the soil a fair and just compensation therefor.

Sec. 3. The city council of the city of Columbus shall be composed of one mayor, one recorder and five aldermen, who shall be appointed by the Governor, and hold their offices for four years, unless sooner re-
moved, and until their successors are duly appointed and qualified.

Sec. 4. The mayor shall preside at all sessions of the city council, if present, and, if not present, the recorder shall in all
Laws of the State of Texas.cases discharge the duties of the mayor. Four members of the city council, including either the mayor, or recorder, in his absence, shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of any business, and said quorum shall have power to enact such by-laws and ordinances, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of the United States, or of this State, as may be by said city council deemed proper for the government of said city; and to this end said city council shall have power to levy and collect taxes upon persons, occupations and property within the limits of said city; to prevent nuisances, after having defined them, and cause them to be removed or abated at the expense of the persons occasioning them, or upon whose property they may be found. The said city council shall establish and regulate markets, and do whatever else may be deemed necessary to give effect to the powers herein granted, and generally to do and perform all legislative acts for and within said corporate limits of said city for the benefit of law and order, and especially to create such offices as may be deemed necessary, and to fill them by appointment by said city council or its authority, and to prescribe the duties, powers and responsibilities, as well as qualifications, of the appointees.

Sec. 5. The city council shall, at their first session, appoint a city marshal for and during his good behavior, who shall, if his appointment be approved by the Governor, qualify as such in the manner prescribed by law. His duties and powers shall be co-extensive with the limits of said city, and similar to those of the sheriff or constables of said county,

Sec. 6. The mayor, or in his absence, the recorder of said city, shall have the same jurisdiction and powers, in criminal cases, that are con-
ferred on justices of the peace, and exclusive jurisdiction in all cases of offenses against the by-laws and ordinances of said city.

Sec. 7. No written process shall be necessary for the arrest of offend-
ers against the by-laws and ordinances of said city, or against the laws of the State. Should the mayor, recorder, a member of the city council, or the city marshal so direct, arrests shall be made without warrants therefor, in all cases where escapes would otherwise be the consequence.

Sec. 8. All persons shall have the right of trial by jury, upon de-
positing the jury fee of three dollars with the marshal, or by making oath, in writing, that he is too poor to do so, in which case he shall be allowed a jury trial; but in the trial of all criminal cases, where the penalty does not exceed ten dollars, shall be before the mayor or recorder, and with-
out the intervention of a jury.

Sec. 9. The payment of all fines shall be enforced by hard labor upon the public streets, squares or works of said city, until said fine and costs are paid; for which capias may issue immediately after-
Laws of the State of Texas.the trial; and all expenses incurred in the custody and safe keeping of the offender shall be considered a part of the costs, and he or she, as the case may be, shall not be discharged until said fine and costs are fully paid, or secured to be paid, as may be prescribed by the by-laws and ordi-
nances of said city.

Sec. 10. All sales of real estate within said city limits for fines, pen-
alties of taxes, may be redeemed by the payment of such sum as the by-
laws and ordinances may prescribe, within twelve months thereafter, but not otherwise.

Sec. 11. The city marshal shall be the assessor and collector of all taxes, fines and penalties due the city, and the city council shall appoint, with his approbation, or he may appoint, with their approval, as many deputies, for this or any other purpose, as may be deemed necessary, under such by-laws and ordinances as may be enacted by the city council; but nothing in this section shall prevent the city council, if deemed ex-
pedient, from creating, by lawful ordinances, the office of assessor and collector of city taxes, and prescribing his duties, which shall be, as near as may be, like unto those of justices of the peace for assessing through-
out the State, or those of the sheriff of the counties for collecting.

Sec. 12. All by-laws and ordinances shall take effect the day after their publication in a newspaper within the city, which shall publish the same upon a certified copy by the proper officer under the seal of the city, which the city council shall, as may be, adopt and procure.

Sec. 13. Said city of Columbus shall have power to sue and be sued; to plead and be impleaded; to purchase, own or inherit real or personal estate, in such manner as real persons of right may do according to the laws of the State, and in accordance with the by-laws and ordinances of said city; but nothing herein contained shall be taken or construed to deprive any person of any right which he or she may have against said city, on account of the fact that the same is a body corporate, but all such rights shall be as valid as if said corporation were a person. Said city council shall have full power to enforce, for the public safety, all ordinances for quarantine purposes, for the public safety of said city against infectious or contagious diseases, or those deemed as such, of which said city council shall be the exclusive judges, and any intentional violation of said ordinances shall be held and deemed to be an attempt to enforce the infection of contagion within said city, and shall be pun-
ished as a violation of said ordinances.

Sec. 14. It shall be the duty of the city council to regulate, by law, their regular meetings, at such times and at such place within said city as may be prescribed; and upon the call of the mayor, or
Laws of the State of Texas.the recorder, in his absence, the said aldermen shall assemble at such time and place as may be named in said call, and if a quorum be present, any business may be transacted as well at a called meeting as at a regular meeting; and the mayor, or the recorder, in his absence, shall have power to enforce the attendance of all members at any meeting, upon his own motion, or upon the motion of any other member, and unless by the con-
sent of the quorum no business shall be transacted until the meeting is full, or absent members excused by vote of the city council.

Sec. 15. The fees of the mayor, or, in his absence, the recorder, shall be the same as those prescribed by law for justices of the peace, together with such other salary as may be allowed by a general law of the city council, and the fees of city marshal or his deputies shall be the same as State or county officers are allowed by law for similar services, and no more, but for any extra services the city council may order payment as in other cases.

Sec. 16. The city council, when in session, shall have power to punish for contempt of its proceedings, and at each meeting of the council the doors shall be open, and free access had by the citizens of said city, to all the deliberations of the city council.

Sec. 17. The “per diem” of each member of the city council shall be at the rate of three dollars per day, and a proportionate part of a day shall be paid for, only for the actual time employed, counting one day at eight hours, and the journals of the city council shall show the hour of each meeting and its adjournment.

Sec. 18. It shall be the duty of the city council, at its first meeting, to appoint a city treasurer, who shall possess the same qualifications and perform like duties as county treasurers are required by law to perform, and he shall qualify as may be prescribed by law.

Sec. 19. All officers of the city council not appointed by the Gov-
ernor, but acting by virtue of their appointment by said city council, may be removed at any time by a majority of the city council at a regular or called meeting.

Sec. 20. An order in all instances signed by the mayor, or the recorder, in absence of the mayor, shall be the only voucher allowed the treasurer upon settlement of his accounts; and should the treas-
urer or any other official fail to perform his duties relative to the safe-keeping or payment of money in his hands, whenever required by those entitled to demand the same, it shall be the duty of the mayor, or recorder, in his absence, to cause the arrest of the officer thus offending, and call a meeting of the city council, who shall proceed to hear and determine the accusation, and if a defalca-
tion exists, or a failure to perform any official duty has occurred,
Laws of the State of Texas.said officer shall be dismissed, and held to answer before the mayor or recorder for said defalcation or failure to perform such official duty.

Sec. 21. All laws and parts of laws incorporating the town of Colum-
bus, including the incorporation of said town of Columbus by election of the people and the action of the county court thereon, in pursuance of statutes of this State incorporating towns and cities, excepting as here-
inbefore provided, are hereby repealed; nevertheless the by-laws and ordinances of said town of Columbus, so far as the same may be applica-
ble, shall remain as the by-laws and ordinances of the city of Columbus until repealed by the city council.
Sec. 22. That this act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXIX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Texas Timber and Prairie Railroad Company.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Thos. J. Hall, T. E. Tullis, Hon. Wm. T. Simmons, W. H. Ham-
man, A. B. Hall, J. S. Stewart, Jno. W. Mancourt, and associates, and their successors, are hereby created and erected into a body corporate and politic, by the name and title of the “Texas Timber and Prairie Railroad Company;” and shall, by that name and title, have succession for ninety-
nine years, and a common seal; shall be able to sue and be sued in the courts of the State; to accept to their own use and to hold and enjoy any grant, donation, loan, power, franchise, aid or assistance, which may be granted to or conferred upon said company; to make by-laws for their government and the management of their business; and generally to do and perform all such acts and things as may be proper and necessary to be done to carry into effect the objects of this incorporation, and not in-
consistent with the laws of the State.

Sec. 2. The persons hereinbefore named are hereby constituted and appointed a board of commissioners of the Texas Timber and Prairie Railroad Company, and they shall continue in office one year, or until their successors shall be elected and qualified, as here-
inafter provided, and a majority of them shall constitute a quorum
Laws of the State of Texas.to do business. The first meeting of said board of commissioners shall be held at or near Bremond, on the first day of January, A. D. 1871, or at such time, within three months thereafter, as they shall determine, notice of which shall be given by the two commissioners first named, by publishing said notice in one daily newspaper in the city of Galveston, for at least four weeks previous to the day of meeting.

Sec. 3. Said board of commissioners shall organize by electing, by ballot, from their number, a president, vice-president, secretary, and treasurer, and such other officers as they shall deem necessary and proper for their organization; and they shall require from the treasurer such bonds as they may deem right, and increase the amount from1 from time to time, if necessary. And they shall keep, or cause to be kept, a record of all their proceedings, and an account of their receipts and expendi-
tures, and all such other books as may be proper. The president, or, in his absence, the vice-president, secretary, and treasurer, or any two of them, may, in like manner as hereinbefore provided, call a meeting of said board of directors1.

Sec. 4. It shall be the duty of said board of commisioners to open books, at such times and places as they may determine, to receive sub-
scriptions to the capital stock of said corporation. An so soon as three thousand shares of the stock of said corporation shall, in good faith, be subscribed, the president, or, in his absence, the vice-president, secretary, and treasurer, or any two of them, shall appoint a time and place for the first meeting of the subscribers of the stock of said company, and give notice thereof in at least one daily newspaper published in each State in which subscriptions have been made, for at least thirty days previous to the day of meeting; and such subscribers to said stock as shall attend the meeting so called, either in person or by proxy, authorized by writing, shall then and there elect, by ballot, nine directors for said corporation.
In all elections each share of the capital stock shall entitle the owner to one vote; and no man shall be a director who is not the owner of one or more of the shares of said stock.

Sec. 5. The said board of commissioners, so soon as the said corporation is organzed by the election of directors, as provided for in the preceding section, shall deliver to the directors so elected all the money and property whatsoever, subscription books, and other books in their possession, belonging to said company, taking their receipts therefor. And the organization and duties of said board of commissioners, and such officers as they may have appointed, shall 1 thus, in original.
Laws of the State of Texas.then cease and determine forever; and thereafter the stockholders shall constitute said body politic and corporate.

Sec. 6. And the said Texas Timber and Prairie Railroad Company is hereby invested with the right, and authorized and empowered to lay out, locate, and construct, furnish, maintain, own, operate, and enjoy, a continuous line of telegraph and railroad, together with all the rights and appurtenances to the same, belonging or in any way incident or ap-
pertaining, commencing at the town of Beaumont, in Jefferson county, or at such point on the Texas and New Orleans Railroad, or Eastern Texas Railroad, within the county of Jefferson, as may be deemed most convenient and expedient; and running thence, in a north-westerly direc-
tion, by the most eligible route, to or near the town of Bremond, or some point within the county of Robertson, on the Houston and Texas Central Railroad, as may be deemed most practicable. And the said company shall have a right to form a junction and running connection with the railroads named in this section; to cross the line of any railroad on this route; and to form a junction and running connection with any railroad on this line, with full power to unite and consolidate with any other company, upon such terms as may be agreed to; and, also, the right to cross and bridge all rivers and water-courses along this line, subject to the laws of the State in regard to the navigation thereof. And the said company may commence and carry on the construction of its railroad from such point or points on its line as may be found convenient for the transportation of material and supplies, and as may be found most to the advantage of the corporation.

Sec. 7. That the right of way through the public domain of the State of Texas, to the extent of two hundred feet in width, and to include all necessary ground for station buildings, depots, machine shops, switches, side tracks, etc.; and the right to take from the public lands, stone, tim-
ber, and other material for construction of said railroad, is hereby granted to the said Texas Timber and Prairie Railroad Company.

Sec. 8. That there is hereby granted to said company the right of why over any lands, roads, and premises, for the construction of said railroad; and the said company are hereby authorized and empowered to enter up-
on, purchase, take, and hold any land and premises necessary for the pur-
pose of establishing and constructing said railroad and telegraph line, and all depots, stations, turnouts, or any other structures required in construct-
ing and operating said railroad; provided, always, that the land and prem-
ises so taken for the road-bed shall not exceed two hundred feet in width; and that taken for all depots, turnouts, machine shops, etc., and other pur-
Laws of the State of Texas.poses, only such, further width as may be necessary for such pur-
poses.

Sec. 9. That if any person or persons whose lands and premises may be taken for the purposes aforesaid of said railroad, and the said Texas Timber and Prairie Railroad Company cannot agree upon the value thereof, either party may apply to the District Court of the county in which the land and premises are situated, for the appointment of com-
missioners, whose duty it shall be to assess the value thereof; and upon such application in vacation or term time, the said court shall appoint three disinterested freeholders of said county, who shall thereupon ap-
point a time to view the land and premises aforesaid, and to hear the owner thereof and the said company, to whom shall be given, by said commissioners, reasonable notice of the time and place of said hearing. And the said commissioners, after being duly sworn, and after hearing the parties and such evidence as they may produce, shall determine the amount of compensation, if any, to which the owner of the land and premises shall be entitled, and make return of their proceedings and of their award to the next succeeding term of said court; and said award, if not rejected by said court for cause then shown, shall be entered up as a judgment of said court.

Sec. 10. In determining the amount of compensation for land and premises, said commissioners shall be governed by the actual value of the property at the time it was taken, regarding the benefits and injuries to other lands and premises of the owner, occasioned by the establishment of said railroad. During the inquiry as to the value of said land and premises, said company shall in no manner be molested or hindered in the prosecution of their work thereon, or the occupation of use thereof; provided, however, that the said company shall, for the use of the owner of said land, pay into court a sum equal to that which shall be finally awarded, which shall be held to vest in said company the title to said land and premises, and the right to use and occupy the same for the con-
struction, maintenance, and operation of said railroad.

Sec. 11. And if any of the lands to be taken as aforesaid are owned and held by an infant, insane person, or person subject to any legal disability, the court shall appoint a guardian for such person, who shall give bond, with sufficient securities, for the proper and faithful execution of his trust, and who shall appear and represent the party under disability as aforesaid; and thereupon the same pro-
ceedings shall be had in the appraisement of the land and premises to be taken for the use of the company, and with the same effect as already described. Nor shall the title of said company to the lands
Laws of the State of Texas.and premises taken by virtue of this act be impaired by reason of any failure by the guardian to discharge his trust faithfully.

Sec. 12. When it shall be necessary for said company to enter upon any land and premises as aforesaid, which are unoccupied, and of which there is no known owner or claimant, or the owner of which resides be-
yond the limits of the State, said company may take possession of, and use the same for the purposes aforesaid, and may institute proceedings, in the manner already provided, for the purpose of establishing the value thereof and of acquiring title thereto. But the judge, to whom applica-
tion is made, shall determine upon and prescribe the notice to be given, to such owner or owners, of the application; and the judge may, in his discretion, appoint a guardian or attorney to represent such owner or owners, in case of his or their incapacity or non-appearance. And in the event that no owner shall appear within five years from the time of open-
ing said railroad across any lands, all claim to damage against said com-
pany shall be barred.

Sec. 13. The board of directors, chosen in accordance with the pro-
visions of this act, shall elect, from their own number, a president and vice-president, who shall hold their offices for a period of one year, or until their successors are elected and qualified; and said directors shall appoint a secretary and treasurer, and such inferior officers as they shall deem necessary for the organization of the company, who shall hold their offices at the will and pleasure of said directors, or for such period of time as may be fixed by the by-laws of the company. The secretary and treasurer shall give such bonds, with such securities as the directors may, from time to time, require. If it should so happen that an election of directors shall not be made on any day fixed by the by-laws of the com-
pany, the corporation shall not, for that reason, be dissolved. The board of directors shall have power to fill any vacancy or vacancies that may occur, from any cause, in said board; and the directors so appointed shall hold their offices until the next regular election.

Sec. 14. The immediate control and direction of the business and affairs of said company shall be vested in the board of directors, of whom six, in-
cluding the president, or, in his absence, the vice-president, shall consti-
tute a quorum for the transaction of business. The directors shall have full power to make and publish such by-laws, rules, and regulations, as shall be needful and proper for the management and disposition of the property, stock, and effects of the company; to prescribe the duty of the officers and regulate the conduct of their employes, the election and meetings of the directors, and the general business of the corporation. The board of direc-
tors shall, at the meeting of the stockholders — of which there shall be
Laws of the State of Texas.one a year—submit the by-laws of the company to the stockholder’s, for their ratification or rejection, as may be.

Sec. 15. Thirty-three per centum of the stockholders may call a meet-
ing at the office of the company in the State, for such purpose and for the transaction of such business as shall be named in the notice calling the meeting; and thirty days’ notice thereof shall be given. The president and vice-president, or either of them, and two directors, shall have power to call a meeting of the board of directors at such time and place as may, in their judgment, be necessary and proper; provided, that whenever any called meeting is held in the State, twenty days’ notice thereof shall be given to each director, in writing, either by delivery of the same at his usual place of business, or at his residence, or by mailing the same to him, as may be most convenient; and a like notice of thirty days shall be given when such meeting shall be called to take place outside of the State. The vote of any absent director may at any time be taken by submitting the question to be voted on to him in writing, and his vote shall be re-
turned in writing, endorsed thereon, under such regulations as may be established in the by-laws.

Sec. 16. The board of directors of said company shall cause to be made and published an annual report of the proceedings and expendi-
tures of the corporation, which shall be verified by the oath of the presi-
dent, or, in his absence, by the vice-president, and the secretary and treasurer, a copy of which shall be deposited in the office of the Comp-
troller of the State. And they shall, from time to time, fix, determine upon and regulate the fares, rates and charges to be received and paid for transportation of persons and property over said railroad, or any part thereof, not to exceed in amount the charges prescribed by the laws of the State.

Sec. 17. The capital stock of said company shall not exceed ten mil-
lions of dollars, which shall be divided into shares of one hundred dollars each. Each share thereof shall entitle the owner to one vote, which may be given in person or by proxy, constituted in writing, at all the meet-
ings of the stockholders; provided, that any action or vote of three-
fourths of said stock, by vote cast at any meeting of said stockholders, shall be binding on all the stock of said corporation. Said stock shall, in all respects and for all purposes be deemed personal estate, and shall be transferable in such manner as the by-laws of said corporation may provide.

Sec. 18. The said Texas Timber and Prairie Railroad Com-
pany shall have power, and they are hereby authorized to borrow money and to purchase property upon their own credit, for the pur-
pose of constructing, maintaining and operating their railroad and telegraph lines; to issue their bonds, and to execute their obliga-
Laws of the State of Texas.tions, bearing such rate of interest, not to exceed ten per centum per annum, and payable at such time and place as the board of directors of said company shall fix and determine; provided, always, that the amount for which said company may issue its bonds shall not exceed six millions of dollars. And to secure the payment of their bonds said company may mortgage their railroad and telegraph lines, their capital stock, their cor-
porate franchise, and any and all property, real or personal, or any part or portion thereof, in such manner and form as said company or its directors shall deem best and most expedient.

Sec. 19. It shall be lawful for said company, so soon as they are permanently organized, by the election of a board of directors, to require a payment of five per centum, cash assessment, upon subscriptions of all subscribers; and the payment of the balance of said subscriptions at such times, and in such portions, and on such conditions as they shall deem necessary to complete said railroad and telegraph line within the time prescribed by this act. Sixty days’ notice shall be given of the payments required, and of the time and place of payments, by publishing a notice thereof in some daily newspaper published in each of the States where such stock may be subscribed. And in the event that any stockholder shall refuse or neglect to pay any one of the installments so required, he shall forfeit the right to vote upon his stock at the meetings of the stock-
holders; shall be ineligible thereafter to the office of director, and shall forfeit his stock and such payment, if any, as shall have been made there-
on, to the company; provided, however, that the board of directors may allow the redemption thereof on such terms as they may prescribe; and provided, that said stock at the time of the failure to pay as aforesaid, shall not be the property of a minor or of a person of unsound mind.

Sec. 20. It shall be the duty of the directors of said company to keep, or cause to be kept, a record of all their proceedings; an account of the receipts and expenditures of said company, and of all such other matters as may be proper and necessary to be kept; which records and books shall all be open at all reasonable hours of business for the inspection of any person interested in said company as a stockholder, or haying busi-
ness with the corporation.

Sec. 21. That an office of said company shall be established at such points on the line of their railroad as may be deemed moist convenient for the transaction of their business, and may be moved, from time to time, to such places on said line as the progress of the work of construction may render expedient and necessary.

Sec. 22. The railroad and telegraph line of said company shall be thoroughly and substantially built, and fully equal to the stand-
Laws of the State of Texas.ard of railroads in the southern States. Said company shall provide good and sufficient amount of rolling stock for the prompt and efficient opera-
tion of the road; and shall establish depots and stations at such places as shall be conducive to the interests of the people, and the proper transac-
tion of the business of the corporation.

Sec. 23. The capital stock and property of said company shall be ex-
empt from the payment of all taxes within the State during the time of constructing said railroad and telegraph line, and for a period of ten years after the completion thereof.

Sec. 24. The said Texas Timber and Prairie Railroad Company shall complete fifty miles of said road within three years from the first day of January, A. D. 1871, and shall build fifty miles of their road every two years thereafter, until it is completed; provided, that any failure of said company shall not be caused by domestic violence, epidemics, floods.
Sec. 25. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage; and that it have the effect and force of a public act, and the courts be required to take notice of it.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXX.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the San Antonio and Rio Grande Telegraph Com-
pany.

div3.p:
Whereas, The establishment, at an early day, through the State of Texas, of a telegraphic connection between the United States and the adjoining and sister Republic of Mexico, would be of the utmost im-
portance for the material interests of both countries; that its operations would bring into immediate contact with our State the largest, richest and most densely settled portion of that Republic, establishing immediate social, commercial and political intercourse between both countries for their common benefit.

Whereas, in a military point of view, such a line constituting a direct inland communication, connecting the extreme western frontier with the seat of the general government, through San Antonio and headquarters of the Military Department of Texas, would be of the greatest importance for strategic and defensive purposes;

Whereas, on the side of the United States, telegraphic facilities
Laws of the State of Texas.do not extend westward farther than the city of San Antonio, leaving a wide gap between said place and the Rio Grande; that on the Mexican side the telegraph line connecting Vera Cruz, Orizava, Puebla, the city of Mexico, Zacatecas, San Luis, and several other large cities, reaches al-
ready the town of Saltillo, in the border State of Coahuila; that Mexican telegraph companies, protected and supported by the government, are pushing energetically the completion of their lines, and that they will, in a very short time, reach their frontier on the Rio Grande; that it is of the highest interest for both countries to fill up the gap aforesaid be-
tween San Antonio and the western frontier; therefore,

Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That H. B. Adams, E. D. L. Wicks, Thomas B. Hunt and James M. Rey-
nolds, their associates, successors and assigns, be and they are hereby con-
stituted, for the term of fifty years, from and after the passage of this act, a body politic and corporate, under the name and style of the “San An-
tonio and Rio Grande Telegraph Company,” with powers, in said cor-
porate name, to make contracts, receive donations of real estate, or others; to solicit and receive subscriptions to the general stock; to have succes-
sion and a common seal; to make by-laws for the regulation and govern-
ment of the affairs of said corporation; to sue and be sued; to plead and be impleaded, and generally to do and perform all such acts as may be necessary and proper to the fulfillment of its rights under this act, and not contrary to the Constitution and laws of this State and of the United States.

Sec. 2. The said company and their successors and associates shall be and are hereby invested with the power and authority to establish and keep up a telegraph line from the city of San Antonio, in Bexar county, to some suitable point on the Bio Grande they may select, at or between Laredo and Eagle Pass, with full authority to connect their line with other lines, or to permit other lines to connect with their own, upon such terms as they may agree, and also to stipulate and contract with any other telegraph company with a view to consolidate into one, to be governed by one board of directors; and any alienation of this said charter, for such purposes, shall carry with it all the immunities, privileges and advan-
tages conferred by the present.

Sec. 3. The parties named in this act, with such persons as they may associate with themselves for this purpose, are hereby appointed commissioners, and invested with the right of forming and organizing said company until directors shall be chosen and appointed by such persons entitled to do it, as being stockholders of the same. As soon as the directors shall be elected, the powers of
Laws of the State of Texas.the commissioners shall cease, and it shall be the duty of said commis-
sioners, as soon as ($50,000) fifty thousand dollars shall be subscribed, to order an election to name the directors.

Sec. 4. The capital stock of said company shall not exceed two hun-
dred and fifty thousand dollars ($250,000), nor shall it be used in any other manner or for any other business than that for which the present privilege is granted, as set forth in section two. Said capital shall consist of all its property, real and personal, acquired by gift or purchase, fran-
chises and rights to property. It shall be divided into shares of one hun-
dred dollars each, each share entitling the owner thereof to one vote, by himself or proxy, at all meetings of the company; said shares shall be deemed personal estate, and shall be transferable by any conveyance in writing, recorded by the treasurer in books kept by him at his office, or in such other manner as the by-laws of said comnany shall provide.

Sec. 5. The permanent and regular government and direction of the affairs of the company shall be vested in a board of no less than five di-
rectors, who shall elect one of their number as president of said company. No person shall be eligible to the office of director unless an owner of, or subscriber for at least five shares of the stock of said company. The di-
rectors shall have the power to fill any vacancy that may occur in said board from non-election, death or otherwise, and may appoint and remove the secretary, treasurer and such other agents and officers as they may think proper and necessary, and prescribe and require bonds for the faith-
ful performance of their duties.

Sec. 6. A majority of the board of directors shall have the authority of a full board, and all conveyance and contracts in writing, executed by the president and countersigned by the secretary, or any officer or person authorized by the directors, under the seal of the company and in pursu-
ance of said board of directors, shall be valid and binding. The president and directors shall also have power to borrow money upon the credit of the corporation, and to issue and to dispose of their bonds, either within or without the State, on such terms, as to interest, time and place of pay-
ment, as shall be deemed most advantageous to the company. And for the security of any debt they may contract, and the payment or their bonds, they may mortgage the corporate property and franchise of the said company, or convey the same by deed of trust; and they may con-
fer on any creditor or creditors of the company, or holder of their bonds, the right to convert the principal, due and unpaid, into stock of the company, on such terms and under such regulations as the said directors may adopt; provided, that in no case shall they bor-
row money or issue bonds unless authorized so to do by a resolution
Laws of the State of Texas.of the stockholders representing a majority of the whole stock, or of the shares subscribed. The bonds so issued shall be of the denomination of not more than one hundred dollars each. They shall also establish a tariff of charges on messages sent on said line, and alter the same as they may deem it proper. They may, if not otherwise provided by the by-
laws, determine the manner of conducting all meetings; the number of members and shares represented that shall constitute a quorum; and do, or cause to be done, all other lawful matters and things which they may deem necessary and proper in conducting the business of the company. They shall keep, or cause to be kept, accurate records of all meetings of the directors and company, and accurate books of accounts of the receipts and expenditures of the company, and all other books necessary and proper to be kept by said company, which shall be always open to the in-
spection of any stockholder or creditor of the company.

Sec. 7. The shares shall be disposed of, and books opened for sub-
scription therefor, in such a manner, at such time, in such quantity, at such place or places, and on such terms, as the commissioners or directors shall determine to be best for the interests of said, company; and any agreement in writing, by which any person shall become a subscriber to the capital stock of said company, may be enforced against him according to its terms; and if any subscriber shall fail to pay any amount due upon shares subscribed by him, according to the terms of his subscription, the commissioners or directors may sell, at auction, the shares of such delin-
quent; and if the proceeds of sale shall not be sufficient to pay the amount due on said subscription, with interest and charges, such delinquent shall be held liable to the company for the deficiency; and if the proceeds shall exceed the amount so due, with interest and charges, said delinquent shall be entitled to the surplus.

Sec. 8. After the first general meeting of the stockholders, in which, the first five directors shall be selected, a regular annual meeting of said stockholders shall be held at the time and place appointed for the election of said directors. A meeting of stockholders may, also, be called, at any time between the annual meetings by the president and directors, or by the stockholders owning one-third of the whole stock subscribed, upon giving thirty days’ notice, in at least two public newspapers—one pub-
lished on or near the line of telegraph, and one in San Antonio—of the time and place of holding the same; and when any such meeting is called by the stockholders, such notice shall specify the particular object of the call; and if, at any such called meeting, a majority of the stock of said company, issued or subscribed, is not represented in person, or by proxy, said meeting shall be adjourned for one week, and the
Laws of the State of Texas.subsequent meeting can act and bind the stockholders of said company; likewise, if at any regular meeting, called by the president and directors, the majority of the capital, stock of the company is not represented, the meeting shall be adjourned for one week, and the company shall be bound by the action of this second meeting, without any regard to the quantity of shares represented thereat.

Sec. 9. The directors shall be elected for one year, and can be indef-
initely re-elected, from term to term. They shall continue in office until their successors are qualified. Every president and director of said com-
pany, before he shall act as such, shall swear that he will well and truly perform the duties of said office, to the best of his skill and judgment. The said president and directors shall require a like oath to be admin-
istered to the treasurer and secretary, and to all others in the employ of the company.

Sec. 10. At the regular annual meeting of the stockholders, it shall be the duty of the president and directors in office to exhibit a clear and succinct statement of the business of the corporation, as also to submit, at such meetings, all books and accounts of said company to the inspec-
tion of the stockholders, chiefly those relating to the last term, and also to keep them at all times subject to the inspection of any committee ap-
pointed by the meeting.

Sec. 11. Semi-annual dividends of so much of the profits as the cor-
poration may deem expedient, after having considered the opinion and proposals of the president and board of directors, shall be assessed and paid to the stockholders, on the first of January and July of each year, either at the office of the company, or at the place or places fixed by the board of directors; and no dividend shall be assessed of a greater amount than the net profits, (after deduction of all expenses;) and the president and directors, being duly authorized so to do, may retain a portion of the profits as a contingent fund, reserved to meet subsequent and unexpected expenditures. They may even lawfully retain, without any authoriza-
tion, if they think proper, any sum remaining in excess, after having; paid to the stockholders twelve per cent. interest on their shares.

Sec. 12. It shall be lawful for the company to secure a right of way along their telegraph line; and for the locating, constructing, and main-
taining of said line, to enter upon and take possession of the same, by their engineer or agent, and make agreements with the land owners by purchase or otherwise; and if the aforesaid line pass over any lands or property belonging to the State of Texas, a right of way over the same is hereby granted to said corporation, free of charge.

Sec. 13. All contracts heretofore made by said company, or for its benefit, with contractors, or any other person or corporations,
Laws of the State of Texas.shall be executed under this act, and in the corporate name of said com-
pany.
Sec. 14. In all suits against said company, citations duly served on the president shall be sufficient.

Sec. 15. Said company shall be bound to transmit all messages and dispatches over their line that may be received from other lines connect-
ing with it, to such point on the same as such messages or dispatches may be directed to, at the same rates of charge as may be fixed on their said line.

Sec. 16. If said telegraph line is not commenced within one year after the date of the passage of the present act of incorporation, and if it is not completed within two years after its commencement, then this charter shall be rendered, by such failure, totally null and void.

Sec. 17. No member of the board of directors, agent, officer, or ser-
vant of the company, shall be directly or indirectly, interested in any contract or work, transportation, or sale of materials; and the violating of this provision shall be sufficient cause for the removal by the presi-
dent and a majority of the board of directors, of said director, agent, officer, or servant.

Sec. 18. It is further enacted, that said company, their successors and associates, are also hereby invested with the same power and authority herein above granted to establish and keep up, for the same term of years, and with the same Tights, privileges, immunities, obligations, and restrictions, as many accessory and branching telegraph lines as they may find proper, in order to connect their line, from the city of San An-
tonio and headquarters of the military department of Texas, with the military posts established towards the frontier westward of said place; and in such case they shall be at liberty to increase their capital stock to the maximum of $2,000 for each mile of said accessory line or lines created. And they shall commence the same within six months after having completed their main line; and the date of said completion shall be fixed by the declaration under oath by the president and secretary of the company, before a magistrate, and deposited in the office of the Secretary of State.

Sec. 19. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage, and shall be deemed and taken to be a public act, and construed liberally for the objects therein set forth; and the regular organization of the company under the same shall be presumed and considered as power in all courts of justice; and all laws in conflict with this act are hereby repealed.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXXI.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of W. B. Price.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That whereas, by the Constitution of the Republic of Texas, there was granted to every single man of the age of seventeen years, resident citizen of Texas on the day of the declaration of Independence, one-third of a league of land; and whereas, W. B. Price was a resident citizen of Texas on the said day of the declaration of Independence, to-wit: on the second day of March, 1836; and was seventeen years of age, and a single man; and whereas, said W. B. Price has never applied for or obtained the quan-
tity of land to which he was entitled, under the provisions of said grant; therefore, the Commissioner of the General Land Office is hereby author-
ized and required to issue to the said W. B. Price a certificate for one-
third of a league of land, which land certificate shall be full and ample evidence of said W. B. Price’s right to the said quantity of land under said grant by the said Constitution of the Republic of Texas.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXXII.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of Cain T. Brush.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Commissioner of the General Land Office be and he is hereby authorized and required to issue patent to the legal owners of bounty land warrant No. 593, issued to Cain T. Brush on the eleventh day of January, A. D. 1850, by John D. Pitts, Adjutant General of the State of Texas, calling for twelve hundred and eighty acres of land; and that this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXXIII.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of N. B. McCleland.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Commissioner of the General Land Office is hereby authorized and required to issue to N. B. MeCleland a certificate for three hundred and twenty acres of land.

Sec. 2. The certificate, when issued, shall be a duplicate in lien of un-
conditional certificate No. 58, issued to James J. Bonham for three hun-
dred and twenty acres of land by the County Court of Jackson county, on the 17th day of May, 1852; hut the same shall be issued to the said N. B. McCleland as the assignee of the said James J. Bonham.
Sec. 3. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXXIV.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of the heirs of John B. Craig, deceased.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the Commissioner of the General Land Office is hereby authorized and required to issue a patent to the heirs of John B. Craig, deceased, for two thousand, three hundred and two and one-half acres of land, situated in Hopkins county, about sixteen miles north of the town of Sulphur Springs, in said county, located by the said John B. Craig, by virtue of a headright certificate for a league and labor of land, decreed to Sarah Reed, alias Sarah Burnett, by the District Court of Red River county; provided, nothing in this act shall be construed to interfere with the rights of third persons.
Sec. 2. That this act shall be in force from and after its passage.

div2.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXXV.

opener.salute: An Act for the relief of the heirs of James S. Holman, deceased.

div3.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the donation land certificate No. 341, for 640 acres, issued to James S. Holman by Geo. W. Hockley, Secretary of War, sixteenth June, 1838, is hereby approved, and the Commissioner of the General Land Office is hereby authorized and required to issue patent thereon as in case of any other genuine certificate.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXXVI.

opener.salute: An Act to authorize the Presbyterian Church in Victoria to sell their church square.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the trustees of the Presbyterian church at Victoria be and they are hereby authorized and empowered to alienate, by deed, the church square in said town, bounded on the north by block 129 (one hundred and twen-
ty-nine,) on the east by block 144 (one hundred and forty-four,) on the south by block 128 (one hundred and twenty-eight,) on the west by Con-
stitutional Square—or any part chereof; provided, that the proceeds aris-
ing from said sale shall be used solely for the purpose of building and furnishing a church and improving the church grounds.

Sec. 2. The sale of said square or any part thereof under section one, and the appropriation of the proceeds as therein provided, shall be taken to be a destination and use of said square for a church within the mean-
ing of article 13 of the colonization commissioners’ instructions con-
tained in the colonization laws of the States of Cohahuila and Texas, in the decree of the fourth September, 1827.
Laws of the State of Texas.Sec. 3. That this act take effect and be in force from its passage. Approved August 15, 1870.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXXVII.

opener.salute: An Act to provide substitutes for certain documents and books destroyed by fire in the court-house at Goliad.

div3.p:
Whereas, The fire that destroyed the court-house at Goliad, on the twenty-seventh of June, 1870, destroyed also many public and private documents, and some law books, all deposited in the public offices; there-
fore,

Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, as follows. It shall be the duty of the clerk authorized to make original registrations of documents in said county, to make substituted registra-
tions in the following cases of the destroyed documents; first, in case a document, suitable for registration, had been registered, and the original properly endorsed, showing the previous registration, shall be presented for new registration; second, in case a document had been registered, and an authenticated copy from the record, showing the previous regis-
tration, shall be presented for registration. In a case. of either kind the new registration shall include the principal writing and the requisite endorsements. The original filing and registration of the document shall be established by the new registration; and the registered copy may be used as if it were an original document. And it appearing that one record book, pertaining to the office of said clerk, is only impaired by said fire so as to endanger the perpetuity of the record, said clerk, under supervision of the County Court, shall transcribe each document that may be entire in such book, so that all the mutilated documents shall appear in a new book, which shall have legal effect as the original book; but the latter shall be preserved as far as practicable. The clerk shall procure a suitable book and therein transcribe as aforesaid, for such reasonable compensation as may be determined, by agreement, between the County Court and him, or without such agreement, by an order of the District Court, and payment shall be made by the county treasurer.

Sec. 2. In all the cases of such destroyed documents, not embraced in the preceding section, the District Court of said county
Laws of the State of Texas.shall have jurisdiction to make decrees, which shall be substitutes for such documents. When the State shall be interested in any such docu-
ment, a motion may be filed by a legal representative of the government, showing the destruction and substance of the document, and when a pri-
vate person or persons shall be interested in any such document, a pe-
tition may be filed, with like showing of destruction and substance of the document, and in other respects such motion or petition shall be in conformity with usual practice; and on such motion or petition, such other person or persons as may have an adverse interest, with usual excep-
tions, shall be cited as defendant or defendants, either by personal ser-
vice, or by publication, the latter mode being used without affidavit of cause; and in other respects the procedure shall be as in ordinary suits, except as otherwise provided by this or other law. On the hearing the court may receive any ordinary evidence, and the deposition or testimony of any person including a party, and the legible portions of such mutil-
ated records and documents. Any number of documents pertaining to one interest, may be embraced in one suit. The court, without a jury, shall determine matters of fact as well as of law, except when a party shall require a jury for trying some issue or issues of fact. The destruction and substance of any such document being thus ascertained, the court shall make a corresponding decree; and the court shall award the costs according to equity, the plaintiff or plaintiffs being liable therefor, except in litigated cases that may justify charging the whole or part of the costs against some other party or patties; provided, the State shall not be taxed with costs. Any such decree shall confirm the right or rights con-
ferred by the document or documents thus established. When any such document pertained to a class that was, or shall be embraced within the laws providing for registration of documents, the confirming decree shall be registered as the confirmed document was, or should be, and the decree shall have the effect that the document would have had, if it had not been destroyed, and the date of registering the decree shall determine its effect with reference to the laws for registration, unless the confirmed document should have been registered; and when the effect shall be de-
termined by the date of registering, the confirmed document, as such date, may be established in the decree.

Sec. 3. The fees for registering documents, including decrees under this act, shall be at the usual rates for other registrations of documents; but this section does not apply to transcribing as aforesaid.

Sec. 4. The books of laws and reports that had been furnished to the clerks of the courts of said county, being parts of the de-
Laws of the State of Texas.stroyed articles, the office of the clerk of the District Court of said county shall be furnished with such books in the customary mode.
Sec. 5. This act shall be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXXVIII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the San Antonio Meat Extract Company of the city of San Antonio.

div3.p:
Section. 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That A. Nette, C. Elmendorf, A. E. Wulff, H. Klocke, E. Pentenrieder, A. Siemering and Th. Hertzberg, and their successors in office, be and they are hereby constituted a board of directors of the San Antonio Meat Extract Company, established in the city of San Antonio, which said company is hereby declared a body politic and corporate, by the name of San Antonio Meat Extract Company, established in the city of San Antonio, by which name it shall have succession and be capable of suing and being sued; of defending and being defended in any of the courts of this State; to acquire and hold estate, real, personal and mixed; to en-
cumber, sell or otherwise alienate the same as said company may deem expedient.

Sec. 2. The said corporation shall have power to enact such by-laws, rules and regulations for its government, and generally to do any and all things that may seem proper to its members for the promotion and in-
terests of the company, not repugnant to the Constitution and laws of the United States.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXXXIX.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Houston Hebrew Charitable Society.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That Isaac Colman, Sam. Sterne, Joe. Cramer, A Cramer,
Laws of the State of Texas.M. H. Levy, S. Meyer, Lewis Colman, L. M. Rich, Henry S. Lox, and their associates, be any they are hereby empowered and constituted a body corporate and politic, under the name of the “Houston Hebrew Char-
itable Society,” who, as such, may sue and be sued in the courts of this State; may take, hold, enjoy and grant property, both real and personal; make, execute and enforce all legal contracts; may have a common seal, and shall have the right of succession, and may adopt all such rules, regu-
lations and by-laws as may become necessary to the organization and fu-
ture government of said society.
Sec. 2. That this act take effect from its passage, and continue in force for twenty-five years.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXL.

opener.salute:
An Act to incorporate the “Galveston Savings’ Bank and Trust Com-
pany.”

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That W. E. Gregory, T. E. Thompson, C. W. McLellan, Jr., H. W. Hub-
hard, Marcus Walker, Wm. H. Sinclair, C. D. Chase, Charles Fowler and E. C. Bartholomew, and their associates and successors, and all such per-
sons as shall become stockholders in the corporation hereby created, shall be a body politic and corporate, by the name and style of the “Galveston Savings’ Bank and Trust Company,” and shall have succession, a common seal, with power to plead and be impleaded: to sue and be sued; to ap-
point all necessary assistants, and may have, enjoy and exercise all the powers necessary to carry out and execute all the purposes and intents of a savings’ bank and trust corporation.

Sec. 2. The general business and object of this corporation shall be to receive on deposit or in trust such sum or sums of money as may, from time to time, be offered therefor by tradesmen, merchants, clerks, laborers, servants and others, to be repaid to such depositors when required, at such times, with such interest and under such regulations as the board of directors may, from time to time, prescribe, which regulations shall be posted up in some conspicuous place in the room where the business of said corporation shall be transacted.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 3. The business of the corporation shall be managed by nine di-
rectors, and the persons named in section one shall be the first directors thereof, and shall so continue for one year from the date of the organiza-
tion of the company; and any vacancy which may occur from resignation or other cause, may be filled by a majority of directors remaining.

Sec. 4. The capital stock of said corporation shall be one hundred thousand dollars, divided into shares of one hundred dollars each, paya-
ble in such installments as the directors may, from time to time, elect, under such penalties as they may, in their discretion, adopt; and the directors are hereby appointed and authorized to superintend the sub-
scriptions to the capital stock of the corporation; and it will be com-
petent for said directors to commence the business of the corporation when the full amount of stock shall have been subscribed and at least ten per cent. of it paid into the treasury.

Sec. 5. This corporation may loan money according to the Constitu-
tion and laws of the State, or may discount in accordance with bank usages, taking such security therefor, either real or personal, as the direc-
tors may deem sufficient. Said corporation shall have power to borrow money, buy and sell exchange, bullion, bank notes, government stocks and other securities: but nothing in this act contained shall confer on said corporation the privilege of issuing notes similar to bank notes for the purpose of a circulating medium, unless the same be done in con-
formity with the laws of the United States in such case made and pro-
vided.

Sec. 6. It shall be lawful for this corporation to purchase and hold such real estate as may be convenient and necessary for the transaction of its business, and to take and hold any real estate in trust, or otherwise, as security for, or in payment of any debt or debts due or to become due to the said corporation; to purchase real estate at any sale made by virtue of any loan, debt or mortgage made to or held by said corporation, and to receive and take, in whole or in part satisfaction of any such loan or debt, any real estate, and to hold and convey the same.

Sec. 7. The stockholders of this corporation shall meet at such time, not exceeding one year from the date of organization, as the directors may fix upon, and annually thereafter, and elect by ballot, from their own number, nine directors, to serve for the term of one year, or until their successors are chosen. Each stockholder shall be entitled to one vote for every share of stock standing in his or her name on the books of the corporation, and they may vote in person or by proxy; the name of the stockholder so voting shall be endorsed on the ballot, and a plurality of votes shall elect. The directors shall elect annually, from their number, a president and
Laws of the State of Texas.vice-president, The cashier may be selected from the stockholders by the directors. The directors shall make and execute such by-laws as may be necessary and convenient for the proper prosecution of the business of the corporation, not inconsistent with this act or with the laws of this State or of the United States.

Sec. 8. At any time after the full payment of the original stock of one hundred thousand dollars, as hereinbefore provided, the directors may increase the capital stock of said corporation to any amount, not ex-
ceeding five hundred thousand dollars, in shares of one hundred dol-
lars each, and said increased stock shall be subject to all the liabilities, immunities and privileges of the original stock; stockholders shall have the option of subscribing to such additional stock, pro rata, within such time as the directors may limit.

Sec. 9. When any deposit is made to said corporation by a minor, or by a female being or hereafter becoming a married woman, the said cor-
poration may pay such depositors any sums of money due to them, and their receipt or acquittance shall be a legal discharge to said corporation therefor.

Sec. 10. The stock of this corporation shall be deemed personal prop-
erty, transferable only on the books of the company; and no transfer shall be valid while the stockholder is indebted to the company.

Sec. 11. This corporation shall exist for the term of fifty years next succeeding the first day of October, A. D. 1870. This act shall be void unless said company shall organize and proceed to business within three years after the passage hereof. The said company shall be subject to the provisions of any general law hereafter passed on the subject of bank-
ing, trust or deposit companies.
Sec. 12. Tills act shall be deemed a public act, of which all courts and magistrates shall officially take notice, and shall take effect on and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXLI.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Savings and Trust Company of Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That James B. Simpson, W. T. Clark, Johnson Reed, Hil-
Laws of the State of Texas.liard W. Hays, Samuel Dodge, of Galveston county, and H. C. Jordon, of Travis county, Texas, and their associates and successors are hereby con-
stituted a body corporate and politic, in the city of Galveston, by the name of the “Saving and Trust Company of Texas,” and by that name may sue and be sued in any State or Federal court.

Sec. 2. And be it further enacted, That the persons named in the first section of this act shall be the first trustees of the corporation; and all vacancies by death, resignation or otherwise, in the office of trustee, shall be filled by the board by ballot, without unnecessary delay, and at least five votes shall be necessary for the election of any trustee. The trustees shall hold a regular meeting at least once in each month, to re-
ceive reports of their officers on the affairs of the corporation, and to transact such business as may be necessary; and any trustee omitting to attend the regular meetings of the board for six months in succession, may thereupon be considered as having vacated his place, and a succes-
sor may be elected to fill the same.

Sec. 3. And be it further enacted, That the business of the corpora-
tion shall be managed and directed by the board of trustees, who shall elect from their number a president and one vice-president, and may ap-
point such other officers as they may see fit. Pour of the trustees, of whom the president or vice-president shall be one, shall form a qorum for the transaction of business at any regular or adjourned meeting of the board of trustees; and the affirmative vote of at least five members of the board shall be requisite in making any order for, or authorizing the investment of any moneys, or the sale or transfer of any stock or securi-
ties belonging to the corporation, or the appointment of any officer re-
ceiving any salary therefrom.

Sec. 4. And be it further enacted, That the board of trustees of the corporation shall have power from time to time, to make and establish such by-laws and regulations as they shall judge proper with regard to the elections of officers and their respective functions, and generally for the management of the affairs of the corporation; provided, such by-laws and regulations are not repugnant to this act or the Constitution or laws of the State of Texas.

Sec. 5. And be it further enacted, That the general business and ob-
ject of the corporation hereby created shall be to receive on deposit such sums of money and articles of value as may, from time to time, be of-
fered by any persons whatsoever; and said sums of money so received shall be invested in the stocks, bonds, treasury notes and securities of the United States and the State of Texas, and in such other secure manner as the trustees may direct.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p:
Sec. 6. And be it further enacted, That it shall be the duty of the trustees of the corporation to invest, as soon as practicable, in the securi-
ties named in the nest preceding section, all sums received by them be-
yond an available fund, not exceeding one-third of the total amount of deposits with the corporation, at the discretion of the trustees, which available funds may be kept by the trustees, to meet current payments of the corporation, and may by them be left on deposit, at interest or otherwise, or in such available form as the trustees may direct.

Sec. 7. And be it further enacted, That all sums received on deposit shall be paid to such depositor when required, at such time, with such in-
terest, not exceeding seven per centum per annum, and under such regu-
lations as the board of trustees shall, from time to time, prescribe; which regulations shall be posted up in some conspicuous place in the room where the business of the corporation shall be transacted, but shall not be altered so as to affect any deposit previously made.

Sec. 8. And be it further enacted, That all trusts upon which, and all purposes for which any deposit shall be made, and which shall be in-
dicated in the writing to accompany such deposit, shall be faithfully per-
formed by the corporation, unless the performing of the same is rendered impossible.

Sec. 9. And be it further enacted, That when any depositor shall die, the funds remaining on deposit with the corporation to his credit, and all accumulation thereof, shall belong and be paid to the personal representa-
tives of such depositor, in case he shall have left a last will and testament. And in default of a last will and testament, or of any person qualifying under a last will and testament, competent to act as executor, the cor-
poration shall be entitled, in respect to the funds so remaining on deposit, to the credit of any such depositor, to administration thereon in prefernce to all other persons; and letters of administration shall be granted to the corporation accordingly in the manner prescribed by law in respect to granting of letters of administration, with the will annexed and in cases of intestacy.

Sec. 10. And be it further enacted, That whenever deposits shall be made by any minor, the trustees of the corporation may, at their discretion, pay to such depositor such sums as may be due to him, although no guardian shall have been appointed for such minor; or the guardian of such minor shall not have authorized the drawing of the same; and the check, receipt or acquittance of such minor shall be as valid as if the same were executed by a guardian of such minor, or the minor were of full age, if such deposit was made personally by such minor. And whenever any deposits shall
Laws of the State of Texas.have been made by married women, the trustees may repay the same on their own receipts.

Sec. 11. And be it further enacted, That the president, vice-president, and subordinate officers and agents of the corporation shall respectively give such security for their fidelity and good conduct as the board of trus-
tees may, from time to time, require, and the board shall fix the salaries of such officers and agents.

Sec. 12. And be it further enacted, That the books of the corpora-
tion shall, at all times during the hours of business, be open for inspection and examination to such persons as the Governor of the State shall desig-
nate or appoint.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXLII.

opener.salute: An Act to incorporate the Gymnastic Association of New Braunfels.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That F. Simon, F. Heilig, A. Eikel, E. Von Boeckman, C. Beuder, A. Liehner and J. W. Davis, be and they are hereby, with their associates, constituted a body politic and corporate, for gymnastic purposes, and for the encouragement of bodily exercise and other purposes, under the name and style of the “Gymnastic Association of New Braunfels,” and by that name shall have succession, and be capable of suing and being sued; of defending and being defended, in any of the courts of this State; to ac-
quire and hold estate, both real, personal and mixed; to sell, alienate, trade, traffic, or otherwise dispose of the same, as said association may deem expedient; provided, the amount of property held by said corpora-
tion shall at no time exceed fifty thousand dollars.

Sec. 2. That the property so owned or acquired by said association shall be exempt from all State or county taxes, and not subject to occu-
pation or specific taxes.

Sec. 3. That said association shall be governed and controlled by a president, vice-president, secretary and treasurer, together with a board of trustees, and the said association shall have power to enact by-laws, rules and regulations for its government, and to alter and amend the same, not inconsistent with the laws of this State, and have a seal for the authentication of its acts.
div3.fw: Laws of the State of Texas.
div3.p: Sec. 4. That this act take effect from and after its passage, and remain in force thirty years.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXLIII.

opener.salute: An Act to prohibit the sale of intoxicating and spirituous liquors in the vicinity of Starrville Female High School.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the sale of intoxicating or spirituous liquors is hereby prohibited within two miles of Starrville Female High School, located at Starr-
ville, a town distant some fifteen miles from the county seat of Smith county.

Sec. 2. That any person or persons who shall sell or otherwise dispose of any intoxicating or spirituous liquors within the limits prescribed in section first of this act, except for sacramental or medicinal purposes, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor; and upon conviction thereof, before any court of competent jurisdiction, shall be fined in a sum not less than fifty nor more than one hundred dollars, for each and every offense.
Sec. 3. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXLIV.

opener.salute: An Act to prohibit the sale or otherwise disposing of spirituous or vinous liquors within two miles of Florence Male and Female High School, in Williamson County, Texas.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That the sale of all intoxicating liquors, including all vin-
Laws of the State of Texas.ous, fermented or medicated liquors (except for medical or sacramental purposes) within two miles of Florence Male and Female Fligh School, in Williamson county, Texas, is hereby prohibited, and that the furnish-
ing or the giving away of any intoxicating liquors or drinks to any stu-
dent or students of said high school is hereby prohibited.

Sec. 2. That any person or persons violating the provisions of the foregoing section shall be fined in any sum not less than ten or more than one hundred dollars for each violation of the same, by any court of competent jurisdiction.
Sec. 3. That this act take effect and be in force from and after its passage.

div3.head: CHAPTER CXLV.

opener.salute:
An Act to prohibit, the sale or distribution of spirituous, vinous, or other intoxicating liquors, or the establishing of any drinking saloon, gam-
bling house, or houses of ill fame, within certain limits.

div3.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas, That no person shall be permitted to establish any drinking saloon, or sell, give away, or distribute any spirituous, vinous, or other intoxicating liquors, within two miles of the West Fork Baptist Male and Female Col-
lege, at Red Sulphur Springs, except on the certificate of some practicing physician, for medical purposes; and every person violating this act shall, for every such offense, forfeit and pay the sum of ten dollars, recoverable before any justice of the peace having jurisdiction of the same, to be paid into the county treasurer.

Sec. 2. No person shall be permitted to establish or keep any gam-
